basking shark: One of the largest species of sharks (Cetorhinus maximus), socalled from its habit of basking in the sun; the liver shark, or boneshark. It inhabits the northern seas of Europe and America, and growsto a length of more than forty feet. It is a harmless species.
besprinkler: One who, or that which, besprinkles.
bombard: A piece of heavy ordnance formerly used for throwing stones andother ponderous missiles. It was the earliest kind of cannon.They planted in divers places twelve great bombards, wherewith theythrew huge stones into the air, which, falling down into the city,might break down the houses. Knolles.
burmese: Of or pertaining to Burmah, or its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
butterbur: A broad-leaved plant (Petasites vulgaris) of the Compositefamily, said to have been used in England for wrapping up pats ofbutter.
bion: The physiological individual, characterized by definiteness andindependence of function, in distinction from the morphologicalindividual or morphon.
battle range: The range within which the fire of small arms is verydestructive. With the magazine rifle, this is six hundred yards.
blockhouse: An edifice or structure of heavy timbers or logs for militarydefense, having its sides loopholed for musketry, and often an upperstory projecting over the lower, or so placed upon it as to have itssides make an angle wit the sides of the lower story, thus enablingthe defenders to fire downward, and in all directions; -- formerlymuch used in America and Germany.
beweep: To weep over; to deplore; to bedew with tears. "His timelessdeath beweeping." Drayton.
browsing: Browse; also, a place abounding with shrubs where animals maybrowse.Browsings for the deer. Howell.
beadleship: The state of being, or the personality of, a beadle. A. Wood.
bannerol: A banderole; esp. a banner displayed at a funeral processionand set over the tomb. See Banderole.
ballista: An ancient military engine, in the form of a crossbow, used forhurling large missiles.
bowler: One who plays at bowls, or who rolls the ball in cricket or anyother game.
blow-out: The cleaning of the flues of a boiler from scale, etc., by ablast of steam.
beguine: A woman belonging to one of the religious and charitableassociations or communities in the Netherlands, and elsewhere, whosemembers live in beguinages and are not bound by perpetual vows.
bablah: The ring of the fruit of several East Indian species of acacia;neb-neb. It contains gallic acid and tannin, and is used for dyeingdrab.
bedash: To wet by dashing or throwing water or other liquid upon; tobespatter. "Trees bedashed with rain." Shak.
bipolar: Doubly polar; having two poles; as, a bipolar cell orcorpuscle.
breechloader: A firearm which receives its load at the breech.For cavalry, the revolver and breechloader will supersede the saber.Rep. Sec. War (1860).
balas ruby: A variety of spinel ruby, of a pale rose red, or inclining toorange. See Spinel.
bachelor: A kind of bass, an edible fresh-water fish (Pomoxys annularis)of the southern United States.
boutefeu: An incendiary; an inciter of quarrels. [Obs.]Animated by . . . John à Chamber, a very boutefeu, . . . they enteredinto open rebellion. Bacon.
bucker: A horse or mule that bucks.
bard: Defensive armor formerly worn by a man at arms.
broccoli: A plant of the Cabbage species (Brassica oleracea) of manyvarieties, resembling the cauliflower. The "curd," or flowering head,is the part used for food.
bilingual: Containing, or consisting of, two languages; expressed in twolanguages; as, a bilingual inscription; a bilingual dictionary.-- Bi*lin"gual*ly, adv.
buffoon: A man who makes a practice of amusing others by low tricks,antic gestures, etc.; a droll; a mimic; a harlequin; a clown; amerry-andrew.
brandied: Mingled with brandy; made stronger by the addition of brandy;flavored or treated with brandy; as, brandied peaches.
belswagger: A lewd man; also, a bully. [Obs.] Dryden.
belecture: To vex with lectures; to lecture frequently.
begrime: To soil with grime or dirt deeply impressed or rubbed in.Books falling to pieces and begrimed with dust. Macaulay.
bichir: A remarkable ganoid fish (Polypterus bichir) found in the Nileand other African rivers. See Brachioganoidei.
boatmanship: The art of managing a boat.
bewit: A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to ahawk's legs.
bacchus: The god of wine, son of Jupiter and Semele.
bocardo: A form of syllogism of which the first and third propositionsare particular negatives, and the middle term a universalaffirmative.Baroko and Bocardo have been stumbling blocks to the logicians.Bowen.
bluebreast: A small European bird; the blue-throated warbler.
browse: The tender branches or twigs of trees and shrubs, fit for thefood of cattle and other animals; green food. Spenser.Sheep, goats, and oxen, and the nobler steed, On browse, and corn,and flowery meadows feed. Dryden.
bonfire: A large fire built in the open air, as an expression of publicjoy and exultation, or for amusement.Full soon by bonfire and by bell, We learnt our liege was passingwell. Gay.
blanch: To bleach by excluding the light, as the stalks or leaves ofplants, by earthing them up or tying them together.
by-dependence: An appendage; that which depends on something else, or isdistinct from the main dependence; an accessory. Shak.
blue hen state: The State of Delaware; -- a popular sobriquet. It is said,though the story lacks proof, to have taken its origin from theinsistence of a Delaware Revolutionary captain, named Caldwell, thatno cock could be truly game unless the mother was a blue hen, whenceBlue Hen's Chickens came to be a nickname for the people of Delaware.
brehon: An ancient Irish or Scotch judge. Brehon laws, the ancientIrish laws, -- unwritten, like the common law of England. They wereabolished by statute of Edward III.
blepharitis: Inflammation of the eyelids. -- Bleph`a*rit"ic (#), a.
bonnilass: A "bonny lass"; a beautiful girl. [Obs.] Spenser.
bituminate: To treat or impregnate with bitumen; to cement with bitumen."Bituminated walls of Babylon." Feltham.
belzebuth: A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Brazil.
blandness: The state or quality of being bland.
bridewell: A house of correction for the confinement of disorderlypersons; -- so called from a hospital built in 1553 near St. Bride's(or Bridget's) well, in London, which was subsequently a penalworkhouse.
bisexual: Of both sexes; hermaphrodite; as a flower with stamens andpistil, or an animal having ovaries and testes.
bordar: A villein who rendered menial service for his cottage; acottier.The cottar, the bordar, and the laborer were bound to aid in the workof the home farm. J. R. Green.
broadmouth: One of the Eurylaimidæ, a family of East Indian passerinebirds.
blazoner: One who gives publicity, proclaims, or blazons; esp., one whoblazons coats of arms; a herald. Burke.
braveness: The quality of state or being brave.
bosk: A thicket; a small wood. "Through bosk and dell." Sir W. Scott.
bougie: A long, flexible instrument, that is
brangle: A wrangle; a squabble; a noisy contest or dispute. [R.]A brangle between him and his neighbor. Swift.
bristly: THick set with bristles, or with hairs resembling bristles;rough.The leaves of the black mulberry are somewhat bristly. Bacon.
battlemented: Having battlements.A battlemented portal. Sir W. Scott.
bacchanal: The festival of Bacchus; the bacchanalia.
badaud: A person given to idle observation of everything, with wonderor astonishment; a credulous or gossipy idler.
bete: To better; to mend. See Beete. [Obs.] Chaucer.
baby farm: A place where the nourishment and care of babies are offeredfor hire.
broomstick: A stick used as a handle of a broom.
baton: An ordinary with its ends cut off, borne sinister as a mark ofbastardy, and containing one fourth in breadth of the bend sinister;-- called also bastard bar. See Bend sinister.
bocca: The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory throughwhich the fused glass is taken out. Craig.
barmecide: One who proffers some illusory advantage or benefit. Also usedas an adj.: Barmecidal. "A Barmecide feast." Dickens.
blackfish: A small kind of whale, of the genus Globicephalus, of severalspecies. The most common is G. melas. Also sometimes applied to otherwhales of larger size.
brecciated: Consisting of angular fragments cemented together; resemblingbreccia in appearance.The brecciated appearance of many specimens [of meteorites]. H. A.Newton.
blockage: The act of blocking up; the state of being blocked up.
baccivorous: Eating, or subsisting on, berries; as, baccivorous birds.
buckie: A large spiral marine shell, esp. the common whelk. SeeBuccinum. [Scot.] Deil's buckie, a perverse, refractory youngster.[Slang]
bulky: Of great bulk or dimensions; of great size; large; thick;massive; as, bulky volumes.A bulky digest of the revenue laws. Hawthorne.
bosporus: A strait or narrow sea between two seas, or a lake and a seas;as, the Bosporus (formerly the Thracian Bosporus) or Strait ofConstantinople, between the Black Sea and Sea of Marmora; theCimmerian Bosporus, between the Black Sea and Sea of Azof. [Writtenalso Bosphorus.]
bedsore: A sore on the back or hips caused by lying for a long time inbed.
brightness: An affection of the kidneys, usually inflammatory in character,and distinguished by the occurrence of albumin and renal casts in theurine. Several varieties of Bright's disease are now recognized,differing in the part of the kidney involved, and in the intensityand course of the morbid process.
bezonian: A low fellow or scoundrel; a beggar.Great men oft die by vile bezonians. Shak.
bow hand: The hand that holds the bow, i. e., the left hand.Surely he shoots wide on the bow hand. Spenser.
bunny: A great collection of ore without any vein coming into it orgoing out from it.
bassoon: A wind instrument of the double reed kind, furnished withholes, which are stopped by the fingers, and by keys, as in flutes.It forms the natural bass to the oboe, clarinet, etc.
bockey: A bowl or vessel made from a gourd. [Local, New York] Bartlett.
botheration: The act of bothering, or state of being bothered; cause oftrouble; perplexity; annoyance; vexation. [Colloq.]
beakiron: A bickern; a bench anvil with a long beak, adapted to reach theinterior surface of sheet metal ware; the horn of an anvil.
browbeat: To depress or bear down with haughty, stern looks, or witharrogant speech and dogmatic assertions; to abash or disconcert byimpudent or abusive words or looks; to bully; as, to browbeatwitnesses.My grandfather was not a man to be browbeaten. W. Irving.
bitters: A liquor, generally spirituous in which a bitter herb, leaf, orroot is steeped.
bellflower: A plant of the genus Campanula; -- so named from its bell-shaped flowers.
bassorin: A constituent part of a species of gum from Bassora, as also ofgum tragacanth and some gum resins. It is one of the amyloses. Ure.
batsman: The one who wields the bat in cricket, baseball, etc.
black-jack: A name given by English miners to sphalerite, or zinc blende; -- called also false galena. See Blende.
brushiness: The quality of resembling a brush; brushlike condition;shagginess. Dr. H. More.
bibelot: A small decorative object without practical utility.
blueberry: The berry of several species of Vaccinium, and ericaceousgenus, differing from the American huckleberries in containingnumerous minute seeds instead of ten nutlets. The commonest speciesare V. Pennsylvanicum and V. vacillans. V. corymbosum is the tallblueberry.
berthierite: A double sulphide of antimony and iron, of a dark steel-graycolor.
bateau: A boat; esp. a flat-bottomed, clumsy boat used on the Canadianlakes and rivers. [Written also, but less properly, batteau.] Bateaubridge, a floating bridge supported by bateaux.
bacchius: A metrical foot composed of a short syllable and two long ones;according to some, two long and a short.
black lead: Plumbago; graphite.It leaves a blackish mark somewhat likelead. See Graphite.
black: Sullenly; threateningly; maliciously; so as to produceblackness.
baggala: A two-masted Arab or Indian trading vessel, used in IndianOcean.
becloud: To cause obscurity or dimness to; to dim; to cloud.If thou becloud the sunshine of thine eye. Quarles.
bombilation: A humming sound; a booming.To . . . silence the bombilation of guns. Sir T. Browne.
bearing ring: In a balloon, the braced wooden ring attached to the suspensionropes at the bottom, functionally analogous to the keel of a ship.
brontosaurus: A genus of American jurassic dinosaurs. A length of sixty feetis believed to have been attained by these reptiles.
besetment: The act of besetting, or the state of being beset; also, thatwhich besets one, as a sin. "Fearing a besetment." Kane.
buzzard: A bird of prey of the Hawk family, belonging to the genus Buteoand related genera.
bolognian: Bolognese. Bolognian stone. See Bologna stone, under Bologna.
black hamburg: A sweet and juicy variety of European grape, of a dark purplishblack color, much grown under glass in northern latitudes.
bloodguilty: Guilty of murder or bloodshed. "A bloodguilty life." Fairfax.-- Blood"guilt`i*ness (, n.-- Blood"guilt`less, a.
blackpoll: A warbler of the United States (Dendroica striata).
barretter: A thermal cymoscope which operates by increased resistance whensubjected to the influence of electric waves. The original formconsisted of an extremely fine platinum wire loop attached toterminals and inclosed in a small glass or silver bulb. In a latervariety, called the liquid barretter, wire is replace by a column ofliquid in a very fine capillary tube.
blooming: The process of making blooms from the ore or from cast iron.
beauseant: The black and white standard of the Knights Templars.
bull-necked: Having a short and thick neck like that of a bull. Sir W.Scott.
brail: A thong of soft leather to bind up a hawk's wing.
buffoonism: The practices of a buffoon; buffoonery.
barbarity: The state or manner of a barbarian; lack of civilization.
basifugal: Tending or proceeding away from the base; as, a basifugalgrowth.
bemonster: To make monstrous or like a monster. [Obs.] Shak.
beeswing: The second crust formed in port and some other wines after longkeeping. It consists of pure, shining scales of tartar, supposed toresemble the wing of a bee.
basicerite: The second joint of the antennæ of crustaceans.
belgravian: Belonging to Belgravia (a fashionable quarter of London, aroundPimlico), or to fashionable life; aristocratic.
broadsword: A sword with a broad blade and a cutting edge; a claymore.I heard the broadsword's deadly clang. Sir W. Scott.
burgomaster: An aquatic bird, the glaucous gull (Larus glaucus), common inarctic regions.
basement: The outer wall of the ground story of a building, or of a partof that story, when treated as a distinct substructure. ( See Base,n., 3 (a).) Hence: The rooms of a ground floor, collectively.Basement membrane (Anat.), a delicate membrane composed of a singlelayer of flat cells, forming the substratum upon which, in manyorgans, the epithelioid cells are disposed.
blub: To swell; to puff out, as with weeping. [Obs.]
bedaff: To make a daff or fool of. [Obs.] Chaucer.
byssaceous: Byssuslike; consisting of fine fibers or threads, as some verydelicate filamentous algæ.
bull brier: A species of Smilax (S. Pseudo-China) growing from New Jerseyto the Gulf of Mexico, which has very large tuberous and farinaceousrootstocks, formerly used by the Indians for a sort of bread, and bythe negroes as an ingredient in making beer; -- called also bamboobrier and China brier.
banishment: The act of banishing, or the state of being banished.He secured himself by the banishment of his enemies. Johnson.Round the wide world in banishment we roam. Dryden.
basket: The bell or vase of the Corinthian capital. [Improperly soused.] Gwilt.
blameless: Free from blame; without fault; innocent; guiltless; --sometimes followed by of.A bishop then must be blameless. 1 Tim. iii. 2.Blameless still of arts that polish to deprave. Mallet.We will be blameless of this thine oath. Josh. ii. 17.
boldness: The state or quality of being bold.
baggy: Resembling a bag; loose or puffed out, or pendent, like a bag;flabby; as, baggy trousers; baggy cheeks.
bailpiece: A piece of parchment, or paper, containing a recognizance orbail bond.
banderillero: One who thrusts in the banderillas in bullfighting.  W. D.Howells.
bunsen cell: A zinc-carbon cell in which the zinc (amalgamated) issurrounded by dilute sulphuric acid, and the carbon by nitric acid ora chromic acid mixture, the two plates being separated by a porouscup.
bulkhead: A partition in a vessel, to separate apartments on the samedeck.
buffeter: One who buffets; a boxer. Jonson.
batfish: A name given to several species of fishes: (a) The Malthevespertilio of the Atlantic coast. (b) The flying gurnard of theAtlantic (Cephalacanthus spinarella). (c) The California batfish orsting ray (Myliobatis Californicus.)
beden: The Abyssinian or Arabian ibex (Capra Nubiana). It is probablythe wild goat of the Bible.
bark beetle: A small beetle of many species (family Scolytidæ), which in thelarval state bores under or in the bark of trees, often doing greatdamage.
banat: The territory governed by a ban.
becomingness: The quality of being becoming, appropriate, or fit; congruity;fitness.The becomingness of human nature. Grew.
biltong: Lean meat cut into strips and sun-dried. H. R. Haggard.
biparous: Bringing forth two at a birth.
boundless: Without bounds or confines; illimitable; vast; unlimited. "Theboundless sky." Bryant. "The boundless ocean." Dryden. "Boundlessrapacity." "Boundless prospect of gain." Macaulay.
brim: To be full to the brim. "The brimming stream." Milton. To brimover (literally or figuratively), to be so full that some of thecontents flows over the brim; as, cup brimming over with wine; a manbrimming over with fun.
base: Not held by honorable service; as, a base estate, one held byservices not honorable; held by villenage. Such a tenure is calledbase, or low, and the tenant, a base tenant. Base fee, formerly, anestate held at the will of the lord; now, a qualified fee. See noteunder Fee, n., 4.-- Base metal. See under Metal.
brickle: Brittle; easily broken. [Obs. or Prov.] Spenser.As stubborn steel excels the brickle glass. Turbervile.
boots: A servant at a hotel or elsewhere, who cleans and blacks theboots and shoes.
bryozoa: A class of Molluscoidea, including minute animals which bybudding form compound colonies; -- called also Polyzoa.
broider: To embroider. [Archaic]They shall make a broidered coat. Ex. xxviii. 4.
businesslike: In the manner of one transacting business wisely and by rightmethods.
bordage: The base or servile tenure by which a bordar held his cottage.
biserrate: Doubly serrate, or having the serratures serrate, as in someleaves.
boxen: Made of boxwood; pertaining to, or resembling, the box (Buxus).[R.]The faded hue of sapless boxen leaves. Dryden.
bluethroat: A singing bird of northern Europe and Asia (Cyanecula Suecica),related to the nightingales; -- called also blue-throated robin andblue-throated warbler.
bombardment: An attack upon a fortress or fortified town, with shells, hotshot, rockets, etc.; the act of throwing bombs and shot into a townor fortified place.
bewig: To cover (the head) with a wig. Hawthorne.
bluegown: One of a class of paupers or pensioners, or licensed beggars,in Scotland, to whim annually on the king's birthday were distributedcertain alms, including a blue gown; a beadsman.
balustrade: A row of balusters topped by a rail, serving as an openparapet, as along the edge of a balcony, terrace, bridge, staircase,or the eaves of a building.
brother german: A brother by both the father's and mother's side, incontradistinction to a uterine brother, one by the mother only.Bouvier.
bleeding: Emitting, or appearing to emit, blood or sap, etc.; also,expressing anguish or compassion.
bluff: To deter (an opponent) from taking the risk of betting on hishand of cards, as the bluffer does by betting heavily on his own handalthough it may be of less value. [U. S.]
bespeckle: To mark with speckles or spots. Milton.
balearic: Of or pertaining to the isles of Majorca, Minorca, Ivica, etc.,in the Mediterranean Sea, off the coast of Valencia. Balearic crane.(Zoöl.) See Crane.
bash: To abash; to disconcert or be disconcerted or put out ofcountenance. [Obs.]His countenance was bold and bashed not. Spenser.
breastpin: A pin worn on the breast for a fastening, or for ornament; abrooch.
barograph: An instrument for recording automatically the variations ofatmospheric pressure.
breton: Of or relating to Brittany, or Bretagne, in France.-- n.
bass horn: A modification of the bassoon, much deeper in tone.
bandoline: A glutinous pomatum for the fair.
bladed: Composed of long and narrow plates, shaped like the blade of aknife.
bioplast: A tiny mass of bioplasm, in itself a living unit and havingformative power, as a living white blood corpuscle; bioblast.
backs: Among leather dealers, the thickest and stoutest tanned hides.
bushing: A bush or lining; -- sometimes called . See 4th Bush.
bilirubin: A reddish yellow pigment present in human bile, and in thatfrom carnivorous and herbivorous animals; the normal biliary pigment.
biddery ware: A kind of metallic ware made in India. The material is acomposition of zinc, tin, and lead, in which ornaments of gold andsilver are inlaid or damascened. [Spelt also bidry, bidree, bedery,beder.]
by-room: A private room or apartment. "Stand in some by-room" Shak.
blazer: One who spreads reports or blazes matters abroad. "Blazers ofcrime." Spenser.
bawl: To proclaim with a loud voice, or by outcry, as a hawker ortown-crier does. Swift.
bounder: One who, or that which, limits; a boundary. Sir T. Herbert.
buddhist: One who accepts the teachings of Buddhism.
buckety: Paste used by weavers to dress their webs. Buchanan.
bat printing: A mode of printing on glazed ware.
barometer: An instrument for determining the weight or pressure of theatmosphere, and hence for judging of the probable changes of weather,or for ascertaining the height of any ascent.
brabantine: Pertaining to Brabant, an ancient province of the Netherlands.
bootjack: A device for pulling off boots.
ballast: Any heavy substance, as stone, iron, etc., put into the hold tosink a vessel in the water to such a depth as to prevent capsizing.
brawler: One that brawls; wrangler. Common brawler (Law), one whodisturbs a neighborhood by brawling (and is therefore indictable atcommon law as a nuisance). Wharton.
blindfish: A small fish (Amblyopsis spelæus) destitute of eyes, found inthe waters of the Mammoth Cave, in Kentucky. Related fishes fromother caves take the same name.
bloody-minded: Having a cruel, ferocious disposition; bloodthirsty. Dryden.
banding plane: A plane used for cutting out grooves and inlaying strings andbands in straight and circular work.
beatification: The act of beatifying, or the state of being beatified; esp.,in the R. C. Church, the act or process of ascertaining and declaringthat a deceased person is one of "the blessed," or has attained thesecond degree of sanctity, -- usually a stage in the process ofcanonization. "The beatification of his spirit." Jer. Taylor.
blottesque: Characterized by blots or heavy touches; coarsely depicted;wanting in delineation. Ruskin.
bete noire: Something especially hated or dreaded; a bugbear.
bigamous: Guilty of bigamy; involving bigamy; as, a bigamous marriage.
blow-off: as, a blow-off cock or pipe.
bedevilment: The state of being bedeviled; bewildering confusion; vexatioustrouble. [Colloq.]
bung: To stop, as the orifice in the bilge of a cask, with a bung; toclose; -- with up. To bung up, to use up, as by bruising or overexertion; to exhaust or incapacitate for action. [Low]He had bunged up his mouth that he should not have spoken these threeyears. Shelton (Trans. Don Quixote).
belonite: Minute acicular or dendritic crystalline forms sometimesobserved in glassy volcanic rocks.
bookworm: Any larva of a beetle or moth, which is injurious to books.Many species are known.
belle: A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsomelady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.
benefit: Natural advantaged; endowments; accomplishments. [R.] "Thebenefits of your own country." Shak. Benefit of clergy. (Law) Seeunder Clergy.
branchiomerism: The state of being made up of branchiate segments. R.Wiedersheim.
backhand: A kind of handwriting in which the downward slope of theletters is from left to right.
bitless: Not having a bit or bridle.
bilocular: Divided into two cells or compartments; as, a bilocularpericarp. Gray.
brachiopoda: A class of Molluscoidea having a symmetrical bivalve shell,often attached by a fleshy peduncle.
boracous: Relating to, or obtained from, borax; containing borax.
bund: League; confederacy; esp. the confederation of German states.
blench: A looking aside or askance. [Obs.]These blenches gave my heart another youth. Shak.
barege: A gauzelike fabric for ladies' dresses, veils, etc. of worsted,silk and worsted, or cotton and worsted.
biogenist: A believer in the theory of biogenesis.
barringout: The act of closing the doors of a schoolroom against aschoolmaster; -- a boyish mode of rebellion in schools. Swift.
bilateral: Of or pertaining to the two sides of a central area or organ,or of a central axis; as, bilateral symmetry in animals, where thereis a similarity of parts on the right and left sides of the body.
bundle: A number of things bound together, as by a cord or envelope,into a mass or package convenient for handling or conveyance; a loosepackage; a roll; as, a bundle of straw or of paper; a bundle of oldclothes.The fable of the rods, which, when united in a bundle, no strengthcould bend. Goldsmith.Bundle pillar (Arch.), a column or pier, with others of smalldimensions attached to it. Weale.
barky: Covered with, or containing, bark. "The barky fingers of theelm." Shak.
bite: A blank on the edge or corner of a page, owing to a portion ofthe frisket, or something else, intervening between the type andpaper.
bedded: Provided with a bed; as, double-bedded room; placed or arrangedin a bed or beds.
brothel: A house of lewdness or ill fame; a house frequented byprostitutes; a bawdyhouse.
bayamo: A violent thunder squall occurring on the south coast of Cuba,esp. near Bayamo. The gusts, called bayamo winds, are modified foehnwinds.
bibliopegic: Relating to the binding of books. [R.]
bulk: The cargo of a vessel when stowed.
blocage: The roughest and cheapest sort of rubblework, in masonry.
bumbailiff: See Bound bailiff, under Bound, a.
broidery: Embroidery. [Archaic]The golden broidery tender Milkah wove. Tickell.
billon: An alloy of gold and silver with a large proportion of copperor other base metal, used in coinage.
broggle: To sniggle, or fish with a brog. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
bemire: To drag through, encumber with, or fix in, the mire; to soil bypassing through mud or dirt.Bemired and benighted in the dog. Burke.
bisulphate: A sulphate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid isreplaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportionof the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in thenormal sulphates; an acid sulphate.
boatful: The quantity or amount that fills a boat.
brandish: A flourish, as with a weapon, whip, etc. "Brandishes of thefan." Tailer.
beseeming: Becoming; suitable. [Archaic] -- Be*seem"ing*ly, adv.-- Be*seem"ing*ness, n.
biplicity: The state of being twice folded; reduplication. [R.] Bailey.
blockheadism: That which characterizes a blockhead; stupidity. Carlyle.
batule: A springboard in a circus or gymnasium; -- called also batuleboard.
bongrace: A projecting bonnet or shade to protect the complexion; also, awide-brimmed hat. [Obs.]
brutish: Pertaining to, or resembling, a brute or brutes; of a cruel,gross, and stupid nature; coarse; unfeeling; unintelligent.O, let all provocation Take every brutish shape it can devise. LeighHunt.Man may . . . render himself brutish, but it is in vain that he wouldseek to take the rank and density of the brute. I. Taylor.
blooded: Having pure blood, or a large admixture or pure blood; ofapproved breed; of the best stock.
brantail: The European redstart; -- so called from the red color of itstail.
backwoods: The forests or partly cleared grounds on the frontiers.
beautify: To make or render beautiful; to add beauty to; to adorn; todeck; to grace; to embellish.The arts that beautify and polish life. Burke.
bemean: To make mean; to lower. C. Reade.
borele: The smaller two-horned rhinoceros of South Africa (Atelodusbicornis).
bloodwood: A tree having the wood or the sap of the color of blood.
bark louse: An insect of the family Coccidæ, which infests the bark oftrees and vines.
begrave: To bury; also, to engrave. [Obs.] Gower.
brinishness: State or quality of being brinish.
botfly: A dipterous insect of the family (Estridæ, of many differentspecies, some of which are particularly troublesome to domesticanimals, as the horse, ox, and sheep, on which they deposit theireggs. A common species is one of the botflies of the horse(Gastrophilus equi), the larvæ of which (bots) are taken into thestomach of the animal, where they live several months and passthrough their larval states. In tropical America one speciessometimes lives under the human skin, and another in the stomach. SeeGadfly.
balance wheel: A wheel which imparts regularity to the movements of any engineor machine; a fly wheel.
betrayer: One who, or that which, betrays.
boxing: The external case of thin material used to bring any member toa required form.
brindled: Having dark streaks or spots on a gray or tawny ground;brinded. "With a brindled lion played." Churchill.
besieger: One who besieges; -- opposed to the besieged.
bleaching: The act or process of whitening, by removing color or stains;esp. the process of whitening fabrics by chemical agents. Ure.Bleaching powder, a powder for bleaching, consisting of chloride oflime, or some other chemical or chemicals.
blowy: Windy; as, blowy weather; a blowy upland.
bolt: To refuse to support, as a nomination made by a party to whichone has belonged or by a caucus in which one has taken part.
bibliography: A history or description of books and manuscripts, with noticesof the different editions, the times when they were printed, etc.
booly: A company of Irish herdsmen, or a single herdsman, wanderingfrom place to place with flocks and herds, and living on their milk,like the Tartars; also, a place in the mountain pastures inclosed forthe shelter of cattle or their keepers. [Obs.] [Written also boley,bolye, bouillie.] Spenser.
brewing: A gathering or forming of a storm or squall, indicated bythick, dark clouds.
bequeathal: The act of bequeathing; bequeathment; bequest. Fuller.
bred: imp. & p. p. of Breed. Bred out, degenerated. "The strain ofman's bred out into baboon and monkey." Shak.-- Bred to arms. See under Arms.-- Well bred. (a) Of a good family; having a good pedigree. "Agentleman well bred and of good name." Shak. [Obs., except as appliedto domestic animals.] (b) Well brought up, as shown in having goodmanners; cultivated; refined; polite.
batta: Extra pay; esp. an extra allowance to an English officerserving in India. Whitworth.
bursa: Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovialsacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposedbetween tendons and bony prominences.
blandly: In a bland manner; mildly; suavely.
broncho-pneumonia: Inflammation of the bronchi and lungs; catarrhal pneumonia.
butt joint: A joint in which the edges or ends of the pieces united comesquarely together instead of overlapping. See 1st Butt, 8.
bear-trap dam: A kind of movable dam, in one form consisting of two leavesresting against each other at the top when raised and folding downone over the other when lowered, for deepening shallow parts in ariver.
battology: A needless repetition of words in speaking or writing. Milton.
bimonthly: Occurring, done, or coming, once in two months; as, bimonthlyvisits; bimonthly publications.-- n.
ballooning: The process of temporarily raising the value of a stock, as byfictitious sales. [U.S.]
buckboard: A four-wheeled vehicle, having a long elastic board or frameresting on the bolsters or axletrees, and a seat or seats placedtransversely upon it; -- called also buck wagon.
bo tree: The peepul tree; esp., the very ancient tree standing atAnurajahpoora in Ceylon, grown from a slip of the tree under whichGautama is said to have received the heavenly light and so to havebecome Buddha.The sacred bo tree of the Buddhists (Ficus religiosa), which isplanted close to every temple, and attracts almost as much venerationas the status of the god himself. . . . It differs from the banyan(Ficus Indica) by sending down no roots from its branches. Tennent.
barratrous: Tainter with, or constituting, barratry.-- Bar"ra*trous*ly, adv. Kent.
blanket clause: A clause, as in a blanket mortgage or policy, that includes agroup or class of things, rather than a number mentioned individuallyand having the burden, loss, or the like, apportioned among them.
buddhism: The religion based upon the doctrine originally taught by theHindoo sage Gautama Siddartha, surnamed Buddha, "the awakened orenlightened," in the sixth century b.c., and adopted as a religion bythe greater part of the inhabitants of Central and Eastern Asia andthe Indian Islands. Buddha's teaching is believed to have beenatheistic; yet it was characterized by elevated humanity andmorality. It presents release from existence (a beatificenfranchisement, Nirvâna) as the greatest good. Buddhists believe intransmigration of souls through all phases and forms of life. Theirnumber was estimated in 1881 at 470,000,000.
burring machine: A machine for cleansing wool of burs, seeds, and othersubstances.
britannia: A white-metal alloy of tin, antimony, bismuth, copper, etc. Itsomewhat resembles silver, and isused for table ware. Called alsoBritannia metal.
brancard: A litter on which a person may be carried. [Obs.] Coigrave.
barnyard: A yard belonging to a barn.
bone: The hard, calcified tissue of the skeleton of vertebrateanimals, consisting very largely of calcic carbonate, calcicphosphate, and gelatine; as, blood and bone.
bedding: The state or position of beds and layers.
beautifier: One who, or that which, beautifies or makes beautiful.
bronzist: One who makes, imitates, collects, or deals in, bronzes.
benedictory: Expressing wishes for good; as, a benedictory prayer.Thackeray.
burghmaster: An officer who directs and lays out the meres or boundaries forthe workmen; -- called also bailiff, and barmaster. [Eng.]
boyau: A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication fromone siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
brinded: Of a gray or tawny color with streaks of darker hue; streaked;brindled. "Three brinded cows," Dryden. "The brinded cat." Shak.
bimembral: Having two members; as, a bimembral sentence. J. W. Gibbs.
bouleversement: Complete overthrow; disorder; a turning upside down.
boat-tail: A large grackle or blackbird (Quiscalus major), found in theSouthern United States.
bowline: A rope fastened near the middle of the leech or perpendicularedge of the square sails, by subordinate ropes, called bridles, andused to keep the weather edge of the sail tight forward, when theship is closehauled. Bowline bridles, the ropes by which the bowlineis fastened to the leech of the sail.-- Bowline knot. See Illust. under Knot.-- On a bowline, close-hauled or sailing close to the wind; -- saidof a ship.
bay: Reddish brown; of the color of a chestnut; -- applied to thecolor of horses. Bay cat (Zoöl.), a wild cat of Africa and the EastIndies (Felis aurata).-- Bay lynx (Zoöl.), the common American lynx (Felis, or Lynx,rufa).
bovate: An oxgang, or as much land as an ox can plow in a year; anancient measure of land, of indefinite quantity, but usuallyestimated at fifteen acres.
by-wash: The outlet from a dam or reservoir; also, a cut to divert theflow of water.
biddy: A name used in calling a hen or chicken. Shak.
boul: A curved handle. Sir W. Scott.
blatterer: One who blatters; a babbler; a noisy, blustering boaster.
by-lane: A private lane, or one opening out of the usual road.
bas-relief: Low relief; sculpture, the figures of which project less thanhalf of their true proportions; -- called also bassrelief and basso-rilievo. See Alto-rilievo.
bemuddle: To muddle; to stupefy or bewilder; to confuse.
bashaw: A very large siluroid fish (Leptops olivaris) of theMississippi valley; -- also called goujon, mud cat, and yellow cat.
beseem: Literally: To appear or seem (well, ill, best, etc.) for (one)to do or to have. Hence: To be fit, suitable, or proper for, orworthy of; to become; to befit.A duty well beseeming the preachers. Clarendon.What form of speech or behavior beseemeth us, in our prayers to GodHocker.
beaumontague: A cement used in making joints, filling cracks, etc.  For iron,the principal constituents are iron borings and sal ammoniac; forwood, white lead or litharge, whiting, and linseed oil.
bolty: An edible fish of the Nile (genus Chromis). [Written alsobulti.]
billiard: Of or pertaining to the game of billiards. "Smooth as is abilliard ball." B. Jonson.
bellwort: A genus of plants (Uvularia) with yellowish bell-shapedflowers.
bicrescentic: Having the form of a double crescent.
bonne bouche: A delicious morsel or mouthful; a tidbit.
bayardly: Blind; stupid. [Obs.] "A formal and bayardly round of duties."Goodman.
band fish: A small red fish of the genus Cepola; the ribbon fish.
buffo: The comic actor in an opera.
brachelytra: A group of beetles having short elytra, as the rove beetles.
blissom: To be lustful; to be lascivious. [Obs.]
bald: Destitute of a beard or awn; as, bald wheat.
birrus: A coarse kind of thick woolen cloth, worn by the poor in theMiddle Ages; also, a woolen cap or hood worn over the shoulders orover the head.
boxthorn: A plant of the genus Lycium, esp. Lycium barbarum.
bond: The state of being bound; imprisonment; captivity, restraint."This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds." Acts xxvi.
bulb: A spheroidal body growing from a plant either above or belowthe ground (usually below), which is strictly a bud, consisting of acluster of partially developed leaves, and producing, as it grows, astem above, and roots below, as in the onion, tulip, etc. It differsfrom a corm in not being solid.
baldrib: A piece of pork cut lower down than the sparerib, and destituteof fat. [Eng.] Southey.
boat: To go or row in a boat.I boated over, ran my craft aground. Tennyson.
bank: A sort of table used by printers.
boa constrictor: A large and powerful serpent of tropical America, sometimestwenty or thirty feet long. See Illustration in Appendix.
baldric: A broad belt, sometimes richly ornamented, worn over oneshoulder, across the breast, and under the opposite arm; lessproperly, any belt. [Also spelt bawdrick.]A radiant baldric o'er his shoulder tied Sustained the sword thatglittered at his side. Pope.
bogberry: The small cranberry (Vaccinium oxycoccus), which grows in boggyplaces.
bdelloidea: The order of Annulata which includes the leeches. SeeHirudinea.
bicrenate: Twice crenated, as in the case of leaves whose crenatures arethemselves crenate.
bluff-bowed: Built with the stem nearly straight up and down.
barmote: A court held in Derbyshire, in England, for decidingcontroversies between miners. Blount.
booster: An instrument for regulating the electro-motive force in analternating-current circuit; -- so called because used to "boost", orraise, the pressure in the circuit.
boatwoman: A woman who manages a boat.
bindheimite: An amorphous antimonate of lead, produced from the alterationof other ores, as from jamesonite.
benzoinated: Containing or impregnated with benzoin; as, benzoinated lard.
borrow: To take (one or more) from the next higher denomination inorder to add it to the next lower; -- a term of subtraction when thefigure of the subtrahend is larger than the corresponding one of theminuend.
bufonite: An old name for a fossil consisting of the petrified teeth andpalatal bones of fishes belonging to the family of Pycnodonts (thickteeth), whose remains occur in the oölite and chalk formations;toadstone; -- so named from a notion that it was originally formed inthe head of a toad.
butter-scotch: A kind of candy, mainly composed of sugar and butter. [Colloq.]Dickens.
bloedite: A hydrous sulphate of magnesium and sodium.
benevolent: Having a disposition to do good; possessing or manifesting loveto mankind, and a desire to promote their prosperity and happiness;disposed to give to good objects; kind; charitable.-- Be*nev"o*lent*ly, adv.
brennage: A tribute which tenants paid to their lord, in lieu of bran,which they were obliged to furnish for his hounds.
browbound: Crowned; having the head encircled as with a diadem. Shak.
bristle: A stiff, sharp, roundish hair. Gray.
blue: Low spirits; a fit of despondency; melancholy. [Colloq.] Berlinblue, Prussian blue.-- Mineral blue. See under Mineral.-- Prussian blue. See under Prussian.
begrease: To soil or daub with grease or other oily matter.
bated: Reduced; lowered; restrained; as, to speak with bated breath.Macaulay.
berry: A small fruit that is pulpy or succulent throughout, havingseeds loosely imbedded in the pulp, as the currant, grape, blueberry.
benzile: A yellowish crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.CO.C6H5, formed frombenzoin by the action of oxidizing agents, and consisting of adoubled benzoyl radical.
banter: The act of bantering; joking or jesting; humorous or good-humored raillery; pleasantry.Part banter, part affection. Tennyson.
blue grass: A species of grass (Poa compressa) with bluish green stems,valuable in thin gravelly soils; wire grass. Kentucky blue grass, aspecies of grass (Poa pratensis) which has running rootstocks andspreads rapidly. It is valuable as a pasture grass, as it enduresboth winter and drought better than other kinds, and is verynutritious.
bedim: To make dim; to obscure or darken. Shak.
boviform: Resembling an ox in form; ox-shaped. [R.]
basigynium: The pedicel on which the ovary of certain flowers, as thepassion flower, is seated; a carpophore or thecaphore.
buckra: A white man; -- a term used by negroes of the African coast,West Indies, etc.
bonze: A Buddhist or Fohist priest, monk, or nun.
benne: The name of two plants (Sesamum orientale and S. indicum),originally Asiatic; -- also called oil plant. From their seeds an oilis expressed, called benne oil, used mostly for making soap. In thesouthern United States the seeds are used in candy.
bacterioscopic: Relating to bacterioscopy; as, a bacterioscopic examination.
boreal: Northern; pertaining to the north, or to the north wind; as, aboreal bird; a boreal blast.So from their own clear north in radiant streams, Bright over Europebursts the boreal morn. Thomson.
blemishment: The state of being blemished; blemish; disgrace; damage;impairment.For dread of blame and honor's blemishment. Spenser.
bury: The ground or place for burying the dead; burial place.
basswood: The bass (Tilia) or its wood; especially, T. Americana. SeeBass, the lime tree.All the bowls were made of basswood, White and polished verysmoothly. Longfellow.
bombic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the silkworm; as, bombic acid.
bubaline: Resembling a buffalo. Bubaline antelope (Zoöl.), the bubale.
broadcloth: A fine smooth-faced woolen cloth for men's garments, usually ofdouble width (i.e., a yard and a half); -- so called in distinctionfrom woolens three quarters of a yard wide.
bilboquet: The toy called cup and ball.
balefire: A signal fire; an alarm fire.Sweet Teviot! on thy silver tide The glaring balefires blaze no more.Sir W. Scott.
bungler: A clumsy, awkward workman; one who bungles.If to be a dunce or a bungler in any profession be shameful, how muchmore ignominious and infamous to a scholar to be such! Barrow.
besmut: To blacken with smut; to foul with soot.
beef: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, beef. Beef tea, essence ofbeef, or strong beef broth.
bathybius: A name given by Prof. Huxley to a gelatinous substance found inmud dredged from the Atlantic and preserved in alcohol. He supposedthat it was free living protoplasm, covering a large part of theocean bed. It is now known that the substance is of chemical, not oforganic, origin.
busy: To make or keep busy; to employ; to engage or keep engaged; tooccupy; as, to busy one's self with books.Be it thy course to busy giddy minds With foreign quarrels. Shak.
blucher: A kind of half boot, named from the Prussian general Blücher.Thackeray.
biquadratic: Of or pertaining to the biquadrate, or fourth power.Biquadratic equation (Alg.), an equation of the fourth degree, or anequation in some term of which the unknown quantity is raised to thefourth power.-- Biquadratic root of a number, the square root of the square rootof that number. Thus the square root of 81 is 9, and the square rootof 9 is 3, which is the biquadratic root of 81. Hutton.
bow-pen: Bow-compasses carrying a drawing pen. See Bow-compass.
bearing: Any single emblem or charge in an escutcheon or coat of arms --commonly in the pl.A carriage covered with armorial bearings. Thackeray.
bedquilt: A quilt for a bed; a coverlet.
breastfast: A large rope to fasten the midship part of a ship to a wharf,or to another vessel.
bezoardic: Pertaining to, or compounded with, bezoar.-- n.
bromeliaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, a family of endogenous and mostlyepiphytic or saxicolous plants of which the genera Tillandsia andBillbergia are examples. The pineapple, though terrestrial, is alsoof this family.
bobstay: A rope or chain to confine the bowsprit of a ship downward tothe stem or cutwater; -- usually in the pl.
birdie: A pretty or dear little bird; -- a pet name. Tennyson.
bedchamber: A chamber for a bed; an apartment form sleeping in. Shak. Lordsof the bedchamber, eight officers of the royal household, all ofnoble families, who wait in turn a week each. [Eng.] -- Ladies of thebedchamber, eight ladies, all titled, holding a similar officialposition in the royal household, during the reign of a queen. [Eng.]
bewilder: To lead into perplexity or confusion, as for want of a plainpath; to perplex with mazes; or in general, to perplex or confusegreatly.Lost and bewildered in the fruitless search. Addison.
beak: 1. (Zoöl.) (a) The bill or nib of a bird, consisting of a hornysheath, covering the jaws. The form varied much according to the foodand habits of the bird, and is largely used in the classification ofbirds. (b) A similar bill in other animals, as the turtles. (c) Thelong projecting sucking mouth of some insects, and otherinvertebrates, as in the Hemiptera. (d) The upper or projecting partof the shell, near the hinge of a bivalve. (e) The prolongation ofcertain univalve shells containing the canal.
beehouse: A house for bees; an apiary.
bouilli: Boiled or stewed meat; beef boiled with vegetables in waterfrom which its gravy is to be made; beef from which bouillon or souphas been made.
briolette: An oval or pearshaped diamond having its entire surface cut intriangular facets.
biconcave: Concave on both sides; as, biconcave vertebræ.
bend: To fasten, as one rope to another, or as a sail to its yard orstay; or as a cable to the ring of an anchor. Totten. To bend thebrow, to knit the brow, as in deep thought or in anger; to scowl; tofrown. Camden.
barmy: Full of barm or froth; in a ferment. "Barmy beer." Dryden.
biologist: A student of biology; one versed in the science of biology.
bog: To sink, as into a bog; to submerge in a bog; to cause to sinkand stick, as in mud and mire.At another time, he was bogged up to the middle in the slough ofLochend. Sir W. Scott.
behold: To have in sight; to see clearly; to look at; to regard withthe eyes.When he beheld the serpent of brass, he lived. Num. xxi. 9.Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world. John.i. 29.
bespew: To soil or daub with spew; to vomit on.
black vomit: A copious vomiting of dark-colored matter; or the substance sodischarged; -- one of the most fatal symptoms in yellow fever.
blessedly: Happily; fortunately; joyfully.We shall blessedly meet again never to depart. Sir P. Sidney.
bobwhite: The common qua(Colinus, or Ortyx, Virginianus); -- so calledfrom its note.
bibliopegistic: Pertaining to the art of binding books. [R.] Dibdin.
bump: To strike, as with or against anything large or solid; tothump; as, to bump the head against a wall.
bihydroguret: A compound of two atoms of hydrogen with some other substance.[Obs.]
balance: A balance wheel, as of a watch, or clock. See Balance wheel (inthe Vocabulary).
bungo: A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kindof boat used in the Southern United States. Bartlett.
bomb: A shell; esp. a spherical shell, like those fired from mortars.See Shell.
bell pepper: A species of Capsicum, or Guinea pepper (C. annuum). It is thered pepper of the gardens.
barnstormer: An itinerant theatrical player who plays in barns when atheatre is lacking; hence, an inferior actor, or one who plays in thecountry away from the larger cities. --Barn"storm`ing, n. [TheatricalCant]
badigeon: A cement or paste (as of plaster and freestone, or of sawdustand glue or lime) used by sculptors, builders, and workers in wood orstone, to fill holes, cover defects, or finish a surface.
bemaze: To bewilder.Intellects bemazed in endless doubt. Cowper.
blite: A genus of herbs (Blitum) with a fleshy calyx. Blitum capitatumis the strawberry blite.
bowenite: A hard, compact variety of serpentine found in Rhode Island. Itis of a light green color and resembles jade.
binbashi: A major in the Turkish army.
billboard: A piece of thick plank, armed with iron plates, and fixed onthe bow or fore channels of a vessel, for the bill or fluke of theanchor to rest on. Totten.
bolus: A rounded mass of anything, esp. a large pill.
bonanza: In mining, a rich mine or vein of silver or gold; hence,anything which is a mine of wealth or yields a large income. [Colloq.U. S.]
breakwater: Any structure or contrivance, as a mole, or a wall at the mouthof a harbor, to break the force of waves, and afford protection fromtheir violence.
braky: Full of brakes; abounding with brambles, shrubs, or ferns;rough; thorny.In the woods and braky glens. W. Browne.
broadness: The condition or quality of being broad; breadth; coarseness;grossness.
barghest: A goblin, in the shape of a large dog, portending misfortune.[Also written barguest.]
bossage: A stone in a building, left rough and projecting, to beafterward carved into shape. Gwilt.
bockelet: A kind of long-winged hawk; -- called also bockerel, andbockeret. [Obs.]
backwardation: The seller's postponement of delivery of stock or shares, withthe consent of the buyer, upon payment of a premium to the latter; --also, the premium so paid. See Contango. Biddle.
boar: The uncastrated male of swine; specifically, the wild hog.
bellied: , a. Having (such) a belly; puffed out; -- used in composition;as, pot-bellied; shad-bellied.
blackheart: A heart-shaped cherry with a very dark-colored skin.
belomancy: A kind of divination anciently practiced by means of markedarrows drawn at random from a bag or quiver, the marks on the arrowsdrawn being supposed to foreshow the future. Encyc. Brit.
baal: The supreme male divinity of the Phoenician and Canaanitishnations.
burgrass: Grass of the genus Cenchrus, growing in sand, and having bursfor fruit.
but: The outer apartment or kitchen of a two-roomed house; --opposed to ben, the inner room. [Scot.]
belaying pin: A strong pin in the side of a vessel, or by the mast, roundwhich ropes are wound when they are fastened or belayed.
blurt: To utter suddenly and unadvisedly; to divulge inconsiderately;to ejaculate; -- commonly with out.Others . . . can not hold, but blurt out, those words which afterwardthey forced to eat. Hakewill.To blurt at, to speak contemptuously of. [Obs.] Shak.
blackwork: Work wrought by blacksmiths; -- so called in distinction fromthat wrought by whitesmiths. Knight.
buck-basket: A basket in which clothes are carried to the wash. Shak.
breme: To burn. [Obs.] Chaucer.Consuming fire brent his shearing house or stall. W. Browne.
bafta: A coarse stuff, usually of cotton, originally made in India.Also, an imitation of this fabric made for export.
barway: A passage into a field or yard, closed by bars made to take outof the posts.
boulter: A long, stout fishing line to which many hooks are attached.
bedrabble: To befoul with rain and mud; to drabble.
butylamine: A colorless liquid base, C4H9NH2, of which there are fourisomeric varieties.
bombolo: A thin spheroidal glass retort or flask, used in thesublimation of camphor. [Written also bumbelo, and bumbolo.]
bestir: To put into brisk or vigorous action; to move with life andvigor; -- usually with the reciprocal pronoun.You have so bestirred your valor. Shak.Rouse and bestir themselves ere well awake. Milton.
bannock: A kind of cake or bread, in shape flat and roundish, commonlymade of oatmeal or barley meal and baked on an iron plate, orgriddle; -- used in Scotland and the northern counties of England.Jamieson. Bannock fluke, the turbot. [Scot.]
bane: To be the bane of; to ruin. [Obs.] Fuller.
bleyme: An inflammation in the foot of a horse, between the sole andthe bone. [Obs.]
betrim: To set in order; to adorn; to deck, to embellish; to trim.Shak.
barbicel: One of the small hooklike processes on the barbules offeathers.
brassicaceous: Related to, or resembling, the cabbage, or plants of theCabbage family.
bottomless: Without a bottom; hence, fathomless; baseless; as, a bottomlessabyss. "Bottomless speculations." Burke.
become: To suit or be suitable to; to be congruous with; to befit; toaccord with, in character or circumstances; to be worthy of, orproper for; to cause to appear well; -- said of persons and things.It becomes me so to speak of so excellent a poet. Dryden.I have known persons so anxious to have their dress become them, asto convert it, at length, into their proper self, and thus actuallyto become the dress. Coleridge.
batrachomyomachy: The battle between the frogs and mice; -- a Greek parody on theIliad, of uncertain authorship.
birl: To revolve or cause to revolve; to spin. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
buss: A kiss; a rude or playful kiss; a smack. Shak.
butyric: Pertaining to, or derived from, butter. Butyric acid,C3H7.CO2H, an acid found in butter; an oily, limpid fluid, having thesmell of rancid butter, and an acrid taste, with a sweetishaftertaste, like that of ether. There are two metameric butyricacids, called in distinction the normal- and iso-butyric acid. Thenormal butyric acid is the one common in rancid butter.
bam: An imposition; a cheat; a hoax. Garrick.To relieve the tediumbams. Prof. Wilson.
bordland: Either land held by a bordar, or the land which a lord kept forthe maintenance of his board, or table. Spelman.
bedrop: To sprinkle, as with drops.The yellow carp, in scales bedropped with gold. Pope.
bysmottered: Bespotted with mud or dirt. [Obs.] Chaucer.
brize: The breeze fly. See Breeze. Shak.
butty: One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.
becket: A small grommet, or a ring or loop of rope
bravado: Boastful and threatening behavior; a boastful menace.In spite of our host's bravado. Irving.
buttercup: A plant of the genus Ranunculus, or crowfoot, particularly R.bulbosus, with bright yellow flowers; -- called also butterflower,golden cup, and kingcup. It is the cuckoobud of Shakespeare.
battening: Furring done with small pieces nailed directly upon the wall.
belling: A bellowing, as of a deer in rutting time. Johnson.
barrage: An artificial bar or obstruction placed in a river or watercourse to increase the depth of water; as, the barrages of the Nile.
bitterweed: A species of Ambrosia (A. artemisiæfolia); Roman worm wood.Gray.
biblicist: One skilled in the knowledge of the Bible; a demonstrator ofreligious truth by the Scriptures.
bushless: Free from bushes; bare.O'er the long backs of the bushless downs. Tennyson.
bewitchedness: The state of being bewitched. Gauden.
bacillary: Of or pertaining to little rods; rod-shaped.
bucephalus: The celebrated war horse of Alexander the Great.
breeding: A fly of various species, of the family Tabanidæ, noted forbuzzing about animals, and tormenting them by sucking their blood; --called also horsefly, and gadfly. They are among the largest of two-winged or dipterous insects. The name is also given to differentspecies of botflies. [Written also breese and brize.]
bicched: Pecked; pitted; notched. [Obs.] Chaucer. Bicched bones, pecked,or notched, bones; dice.
boweled: Having bowels; hollow. "The boweled cavern." Thomson.
boottree: An instrument to stretch and widen the leg of a boot,consisting of two pieces, together shaped like a leg, between which,when put into the boot, a wedge is driven.The pretty boots trimly stretched on boottrees. Thackeray.
bock beer: A strong beer, originally made in Bavaria. [Also written buckbeer.]
bardiglio: An Italian marble of which the principal varieties occur in theneighborhood of Carrara and in Corsica. It commonly shows a dark grayor bluish ground traversed by veins.
beyond: Further away; at a distance; yonder.Lo, where beyond he lyeth languishing. Spenser.
barbaresque: Barbaric in form or style; as, barbaresque architecture. DeQuincey.
bayard: Properly, a bay horse, but often any horse. Commonly in thephrase blind bayard, an old blind horse.Blind bayard moves the mill. Philips.
bregma: The point of junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures ofthe skull.
bicyclism: The art of riding a bicycle.
ballotade: A leap of a horse, as between two pillars, or upon a straightline, so that when his four feet are in the air, he shows only theshoes of his hind feet, without jerking out.
bile: A yellow, or greenish, viscid fluid, usually alkaline inreaction, secreted by the liver. It passes into the intestines, whereit aids in the digestive process. Its characteristic constituents arethe bile salts, and coloring matters.
bigeye: A fish of the genus Priacanthus, remarkable for the large sizeof the eye.
bethink: To call to mind; to recall or bring to recollection,reflection, or consideration; to think; to consider; -- generallyfollowed by a reflexive pronoun, often with of or that before thesubject of thought.I have bethought me of another fault. Shak.The rest . . . may . . . bethink themselves, and recover. Milton.We bethink a means to break it off. Shak.
bulbel: A separable bulb formed on some flowering plants.
bardish: Pertaining to, or written by, a bard or bards. "Bardishimpostures." Selden.
befriend: To act as a friend to; to favor; to aid, benefit, orcountenance.By the darkness befriended. Longfellow.
backslide: To slide back; to fall away; esp. to abandon gradually thefaith and practice of a religion that has been professed.
binomial: An expression consisting of two terms connected by the signplus (+) or minus (-); as, a+b, or 7-3.
bisk: Soup or broth made by boiling several sorts of flesh together.King.
bushhammer: A hammer with a head formed of a bundle of square bars, withpyramidal points, arranged in rows, or a solid head with a face cutinto a number of rows of such points; -- used for dressing stone.
busybody: One who officiously concerns himself with the affairs ofothers; a meddling person.And not only idle, but tattlers also and busybodies, speaking thingswhich they ought not. 1 Tim. v. 13.
biseye: of Besee. [Obs.] Chaucer. Evil biseye, ill looking. [Obs.]
based: Wearing, or protected by, bases. [Obs.] "Based in lawnyvelvet." E. Hall.
by-passage: A passage different from the usual one; a byway.
butterine: A substance prepared from animal fat with some otheringredients intermixed, as an imitation of butter.The manufacturers ship large quantities of oleomargarine to England,Holland, and other countries, to be manufactured into butter, whichis sold as butterine or suine. Johnson's Cyc.
bedstraw: A genus of slender herbs, usually with square stems, whorledleaves, and small white flowers. Our Lady's bedstraw, which hasyellow flowers, is Galium verum.-- White bedstraw is G. mollugo.
barouche: A four-wheeled carriage, with a falling top, a seat on theoutside for the driver, and two double seats on the inside arrangedso that the sitters on the front seat face those on the back seat.
broaden: To grow broad; to become broader or wider.The broadening sun appears. Wordsworth.
block signal: One of the danger signals or safety signals which guide themovement of trains in a block system. The signal is often so coupledwith a switch that act of opening or closing the switch operates thesignal also.
bench mark: Any permanent mark to which other levels may be referred.Specif. : A horizontal mark at the water's edge with reference towhich the height of tides and floods may be measured.
breech-loading: Receiving the charge at the breech instead of at the muzzle.
beylic: The territory ruled by a bey.
billhead: A printed form, used by merchants in making out bills orrendering accounts.
branny: Having the appearance of bran; consisting of or containingbran. Wiseman.
bud: A small protuberance on the stem or branches of a plant,containing the rudiments of future leaves, flowers, or stems; anundeveloped branch or flower.
bangle: To waste by little and little; to fritter away. [Obs.]
buntline: One of the ropes toggled to the footrope of a sail, used tohaul up to the yard the body of the sail when taking it in. Totten.
belam: To beat or bang. [Prov. & Low, Eng.] Todd.
bull terrier: A breed of dogs obtained by crossing the bulldog and theterrier.
bewrap: To wrap up; to cover. Fairfax.
buffel duck: A small duck (Charitonetta albeola); the spirit duck, orbutterball. The head of the male is covered with numerous elongatedfeathers, and thus appears large. Called also bufflehead.
ballroom: A room for balls or dancing.
barometrically: By means of a barometer, or according to barometricobservations.
brocade: Silk stuff, woven with gold and silver threads, or ornamentedwith raised flowers, foliage, etc.; -- also applied to other stuffsthus wrought and enriched.A gala suit of faded brocade. W. Irving.
boiling: Heated to the point of bubbling; heaving with bubbles; intumultuous agitation, as boiling liquid; surging; seething; swellingwith heat, ardor, or passion. Boiling point, the temperature at whicha fluid is converted into vapor, with the phenomena of ebullition.This is different for different liquids, and for the same liquidunder different pressures. For water, at the level of the sea,barometer 30 in., it is 212 º Fahrenheit; for alcohol, 172.96º; forether, 94.8º; for mercury, about 675º. The boiling point of water islowered one degree Fahrenheit for about 550 feet of ascent above thelevel of the sea.-- Boiling spring, a spring which gives out very hot water, or waterand steam, often ejecting it with much force; a geyser.-- To be at the boiling point, to be very angry.-- To keep the pot boiling, to keep going on actively, as in certaingames. [Colloq.]
boost: To lift or push from behind (one who is endeavoring to climb);to push up; hence, to assist in overcoming obstacles, or in makingadvancement. [Colloq. U. S.]
bed steps: Steps for mounting a bed of unusual height.
bellycheat: An apron or covering for the front of the person. [Obs.] Beau.& Fl.
beery: Of or resembling beer; affected by beer; maudlin.
bedeck: To deck, ornament, or adorn; to grace.Bedecked with boughs, flowers, and garlands. Pennant.
betumble: To throw into disorder; to tumble. [R.]From her betumbled couch she starteth. Shak.
behooveful: Advantageous; useful; profitable. [Archaic] -- Be*hoove"ful*ly,adv.-- Be*hoove"ful*ness, n. [Archaic]
branchless: Destitude of branches or shoots; without any valuable product;barren; naked.
baronet: A dignity or degree of honor next below a baron and above aknight, having precedency of all orders of knights except those ofthe Garter. It is the lowest degree of honor that is hereditary. Thebaronets are commoners.
brunswick green: An oxychloride of copper, used as a green pigment; also, acarbonate of copper similarly employed.
burlesque: Tending to excite laughter or contempt by extravagant images,or by a contrast between the subject and the manner of treating it,as when a trifling subject is treated with mock gravity; jocular;ironical.It is a dispute among the critics, whether burlesque poetry runs bestin heroic verse, like that of the Dispensary, or in doggerel, likethat of Hudibras. Addison.
bolete: any fungus of the family Boletaceae.[WordNet 1.5]
berretta: A square cap worn by ecclesiastics of the Roman CatholicChurch. A cardinal's berretta is scarlet; that worn by other clericsis black, except that a bishop's is lined with green. [Also speltberetta, biretta, etc.]
bow-legged: Having crooked legs, esp. with the knees bent outward. Johnson.
breastplate: A part of the vestment of the high priest, worn upon the frontof the ephod. It was a double piece of richly embroidered stuff, aspan square, set with twelve precious stones, on which were engravedthe names of the twelve tribes of Israel. See Ephod.
bigamist: One who is guilty of bigamy. Ayliffe.
beholding: Obliged; beholden. [Obs.]I was much bound and beholding to the right reverend father. Robynson(More's Utopia).So much hath Oxford been beholding to her nephews, or sister'schildren. Fuller.
biliation: The production and excretion of bile.
bag: A certain quantity of a commodity, such as it is customary tocarry to market in a sack; as, a bag of pepper or hops; a bag ofcoffee. Bag and baggage, all that belongs to one.-- To give one the bag, to disappoint him. [Obs.] Bunyan.
bhunder: An Indian monkey (Macacus Rhesus), protected by the Hindoos assacred. See Rhesus.
buckthorn: A genus (Rhamnus) of shrubs or trees. The shorter branches ofsome species terminate in long spines or thorns. See Rhamnus. Seabuckthorn, a plant of the genus Hippophaë.
bostryx: A form of cymose inflorescence with all the flowers on one sideof the rachis, usually causing it to curl; -- called also a uniparoushelicoid cyme.
bryony: The common name of several cucurbitaceous plants of the genusBryonia. The root of B. alba (rough or white bryony) and of B. dioicais a strong, irritating cathartic. Black bryony, a plant (Tamuscommunis) so named from its dark glossy leaves and black root; blackbindweed.
bletonism: The supposed faculty of perceiving subterraneous springs andcurrents by sensation; -- so called from one Bleton, of France.
brabbler: A clamorous, quarrelsome, noisy fellow; a wrangler. [R] Shak.
bosa: A drink, used in the East. See Boza.
belgard: A sweet or loving look. [Obs.] Spenser.
baby farming: The business of keeping a baby farm.
bastardism: The state of being a bastard; bastardy.
blouse: A light, loose over-garment, like a smock frock, wornespecially by workingmen in France; also, a loose coat of anymaterial, as the undress uniform coat of the United States army.
bicuspid: One of the two double-pointed teeth which intervene between thecanines (cuspids) and the molars, on each side of each jaw. SeeTooth, n.
bonded: Placed under, or covered by, a bond, as for the payment ofduties, or for conformity to coertain regulations. Bonded goods,goods placed in a bonded warehouse; goods, for the duties on whichbonds are given at the customhouse.-- Bonded warehouse, a warehouse in which goods on which the dutiesare unpaid are stored under bond and in the joint custody of theimporter, or his agent, and the customs officers.
brazenness: The quality or state of being brazen. Johnson.
boastingly: Boastfully; with boasting. "He boastingly tells you." Burke.
bergander: A European duck (Anas tadorna). See Sheldrake.
bawbee: A halfpenny. [Spelt also baubee.] [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
ballotation: Voting by ballot. [Obs.] Sir H. Wotton.
birch: Of or pertaining to the birch; birchen.
baume: Designating or conforming to either of the scales used by theFrench chemist Antoine Baumé in the graduation of his hydrometers; ofor relating to Baumé's scales or hydrometers. There are two Bauméhydrometers. One, which is used with liquids heavier than water,sinks to 0º in pure water, and to 15º in a 15 per cent salt solution;the other, for liquids lighter than water, sinks to 0º in a 10 percent salt solution and to 10º in pure water. In both cases thegraduation, based on the distance between these fundamental points,is continued along the stem as far as desired. Since all the degreeson a Baumé scale are thus equal in length, while those on a specific-gravity scale grow smaller as the density increases, there is nosimple relation between degrees Bé. and Sp. gr. However, readings onBaumés scale may be approximately reduced to specific gravities bythe following formulæ (x in each case being the reading on Baumé'sscale) : (a) for liquids heavier than water, sp. gr. = 144 ÷ (144 -x);(b) for liquids lighter than water, sp. gr. = 144 ÷ (134 + x).
blowzy: Coarse and ruddy-faced; fat and ruddy; high colored; frowzy.
ballastage: A toll paid for the privilege of taking up ballast in a port orharbor.
blue jay: The common jay of the United States (Cyanocitta, or Cyanura,cristata). The predominant color is bright blue.
bitangent: Possessing the property of touching at two points.-- n.
blandishment: The act of blandishing; a word or act expressive of affectionor kindness, and tending to win the heart; soft words and artfulcaresses; cajolery; allurement.Cowering low with blandishment. Milton.Attacked by royal smiles, by female blandishments. Macaulay.
briarean: Pertaining to, or resembling, Briareus, a giant fabled to havea hundred hands; hence, hundred-handed or many-handed.
buzzingly: In a buzzing manner; with a buzzing sound.
bonnaz: A kind of embroidery made with a complicated sewing machine,said to have been originally invented by a Frenchman of the name ofBonnaz. The work is done either in freehand or by following aperforated design.
byssine: Made of silk; having a silky or flaxlike appearance. Coles.
breathlessness: The state of being breathless or out of breath.
bearishness: Behavior like that of a bear.
bafflement: The process or act of baffling, or of being baffled;frustration; check.
bivalve: A mollusk having a shell consisting of two lateral plates orvalves joined together by an elastic ligament at the hinge, which isusually strengthened by prominences called teeth. The shell is closedby the contraction of two transverse muscles attached to the innersurface, as in the clam, -- or by one, as in the oyster. SeeMollusca.
belt: Same as Band, n., 2. A very broad band is more properly termeda belt.
biarticulate: Having, or consisting of, tow joints.
bywork: Work aside from regular work; subordinate or secondarybusiness.
beat: To give the signal for, by beat of drum; to sound by beat ofdrum; as, to beat an alarm, a charge, a parley, a retreat; to beatthe general, the reveille, the tattoo. See Alarm, Charge, Parley,etc. To beat down, to haggle with (any one) to secure a lower price;to force down. [Colloq.] -- To beat into, to teach or instill, byrepetition.-- To beat off, to repel or drive back.-- To beat out, to extend by hammering.-- To beat out of a thing, to cause to relinquish it, or give it up."Nor can anything beat their posterity out of it to this day." South.-- To beat the dust. (Man.) (a) To take in too little ground withthe fore legs, as a horse. (b) To perform curvets too precipitatelyor too low.-- To beat the hoof, to walk; to go on foot.-- To beat the wing, to flutter; to move with fluttering agitation.-- To beat time, to measure or regulate time in music by the motionof the hand or foot.-- To beat up, to attack suddenly; to alarm or disturb; as, to beatup an enemy's quarters.
becard: A South American bird of the flycatcher family. (Tityrainquisetor).
blockhead: A stupid fellow; a dolt; a person deficient in understanding.The bookful blockhead, ignorantly read, With loads of learned lumberin his head. Pope.
bitterroot: A plant (Lewisia rediviva) allied to the purslane, but withfleshy, farinaceous roots, growing in the mountains of Idaho,Montana, etc. It gives the name to the Bitter Root mountains andriver. The Indians call both the plant and the river Spæt'lum.
blazonment: The act or blazoning; blazoning; emblazonment.
bearish: Partaking of the qualities of a bear; resembling a bear intemper or manners. Harris.
binervate: Two-nerved; -- applied to leaves which have two longitudinalribs or nerves.
bronchus: One of the subdivisions of the trachea or windpipe; esp. one ofthe two primary divisions.
bioplasmic: Pertaining to, or consisting of, bioplasm.
barillet: A little cask, or something resembling one. Smart.
bumbelo: A glass used in subliming camphor. [Spelled also bombolo andbumbolo.]
bunchiness: The quality or condition of being bunchy; knobbiness.
bicentennial: The two hundredth year or anniversary, or its celebration.
basaltic: Pertaining to basalt; formed of, or containing, basalt; asbasaltic lava.
biscutate: Resembling two bucklers placed side by side.
buffin: A sort of coarse stuff; as, buffin gowns. [Obs.]
bedewy: Moist with dew; dewy. [Obs.]Night with her bedewy wings. A. Brewer.
bryozoan: Of or pertaining to the Bryozoa.-- n.
burden: The tops or heads of stream-work which lie over the stream oftin.
bermuda lily: The large white lily (Lilium longiflorum eximium, syn. L.Harrisii) which is extensively cultivated in Bermuda.
beaconage: Money paid for the maintenance of a beacon; also, beacons,collectively.
beautiful: Having the qualities which constitute beauty; pleasing to thesight or the mind.A circle is more beautiful than a square; a square is more beautifulthan a parallelogram. Lord Kames.
bushiness: The condition or quality of being bushy.
bottle-nosed: Having the nose bottleshaped, or large at the end. Dickens.
bona fides: Good faith; honesty; freedom from fraud or deception.
bookful: As much as will fill a book; a book full. Shak.-- a.
bilbo: A long bar or bolt of iron with sliding shackles, and a lock atthe end, to confine the feet of prisoners or offenders, esp. on boardof ships.Methought I lay Worse than the mutines in the bilboes. Shak.
bewash: To drench or souse with water. "Let the maids bewash the men."Herrick.
blotter: A wastebook, in which entries of transactions are made as theytake place.
bushelman: A tailor's assistant for repairing garments; -- called alsobusheler. [Local, U.S.]
borne: Carried; conveyed; supported; defrayed. See Bear, v. t.
brigade: A body of troops, whether cavalry, artillery, infantry, ormixed, consisting of two or more regiments, under the command of abrigadier general.
brashy: An artificer who works in brass. Franklin.
bolero: A Spanish dance, or the lively music which accompanies it.
bunch-backed: Having a bunch on the back; crooked. "Bunch-backed toad." Shak.
bondmaid: A female slave, or one bound to service without wages, asdistinguished from a hired servant.
bird pepper: A species of capsicum (Capsicum baccatum), whose small,conical, coral-red fruit is among the most piquant of all redpeppers.
beehive: A hive for a swarm of bees. Also used figuratively.
beard: Long or stiff hairs on a plant; the awn; as, the beard ofgrain.
batavian: Of or pertaining to (a) the Batavi, an ancient Germanic tribe;or to (b) as, a Batavian legion. Batavian Republic, the name given toHolland by the French after its conquest in 1795.
blue-grass state: The Sate of Kentucky; -- a nickname alluding to the blue-grassregion, where fine horses are bred.
breadless: Without bread; destitude of food.Plump peers and breadless bards alike are dull. P. Whitehead.
bloody flux: The dysentery, a disease in which the flux or discharge fromthe bowels has a mixture of blood. Arbuthnot.
boomer: A North American rodent, so named because it is said to make abooming noise. See Sewellel.
broche: Woven with a figure; as, broché goods.
buccinator: A muscle of the cheek; -- so called from its use in blowingwind instruments.
boncilate: A substance composed of ground bone, mineral matters, etc.,hardened by pressure, and used for making billiard balls, boxes, etc.
bondsman: A surety; one who is bound, or who gives security, for another.
bolster: A cushioned or a piece part of a saddle.
bepaint: To paint; to cover or color with, or as with, paint.Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek. Shak.
block: The perch on which a bird of prey is kept.
bogsucker: The American woodcock; -- so called from its feeding among thebogs.
balder: The most beautiful and beloved of the gods; the god of peace;the son of Odin and Freya. [Written also Baldur.]
boomerang: A very singular missile weapon used by the natives of Australiaand in some parts of India. It is usually a curved stick of hardwood, from twenty to thirty inches in length, from two to threeinches wide, and half or three quarters of an inch thick. When thrownfrom the hand with a quick rotary motion, it describes veryremarkable curves, according to the shape of the instrument and themanner of throwing it, often moving nearly horizontally a longdistance, then curving upward to a considerable height, and finallytaking a retrograde direction, so as to fall near the place fromwhich it was thrown, or even far in the rear of it.
brother: To make a brother of; to call or treat as a brother; to admitto a brotherhood. Sir W. Scott.
baxter: A baker; originally, a female baker. [Old Eng. & Scotch]
backsettler: One living in the back or outlying districts of a community.The English backsettlers of Leinster and Munster. Macaulay.
bohemianism: The characteristic conduct or methods of a Bohemian. [Modern]
burnt: Consumed with, or as with, fire; scorched or dried, as withfire or heat; baked or hardened in the fire or the sun. Burnt ear, ablack, powdery fungus which destroys grain. See Smut.-- Burnt offering, something offered and burnt on an altar, as anatonement for sin; a sacrifice. The offerings of the Jews were aclean animal, as an ox, a calf, a goat, or a sheep; or some vegetablesubstance, as bread, or ears of wheat or barley. Called also burntsacrifice. [2 Sam. xxiv. 22.]
bordeller: A keeper or a frequenter of a brothel. [Obs.] Gower.
ban: A calling together of the king's (esp. the French king's)vassals for military service; also, the body of vassals thusassembled or summoned. In present usage, in France and Prussia, themost effective part of the population liable to military duty and notin the standing army.
bark: The short, loud, explosive sound uttered by a dog; a similarsound made by some other animals.
bicorporate: Double-bodied, as a lion having one head and two bodies.
biostatics: The physical phenomena of organized bodies, in opposition totheir organic or vital phenomena.
barbel: A slender tactile organ on the lips of certain fished.
balderdash: To mix or adulterate, as liquors.The wine merchants of Nice brew and balderdash, and even mix it withpigeon's dung and quicklime. Smollett.
bois durci: A hard, highly polishable composition, made of fine sawdustfrom hard wood (as rosewood) mixed with blood, and pressed.
blowgun: A tube, as of cane or reed, sometimes twelve feet long, throughwhich an arrow or other projectile may be impelled by the force ofthe breath. It is a weapon much used by certain Indians of Americaand the West Indies; -- called also blowpipe, and blowtube. SeeSumpitan.
benthamism: That phase of the doctrine of utilitarianism taught by JeremyBentham; the doctrine that the morality of actions is estimated anddetermined by their utility; also, the theory that the sensibility topleasure and the recoil from pain are the only motives whichinfluence human desires and actions, and that these are thesufficient explanation of ethical and jural conceptions.
