boomorah: A small West African chevrotain (Hyæmoschus aquaticus),resembling the musk deer.
ball: A flaming, roundish body shot into the air; a case filled withcombustibles intended to burst and give light or set fire, or toproduce smoke or stench; as, a fire ball; a stink ball.
boggy: Consisting of, or containing, a bog or bogs; of the nature of abog; swampy; as, boggy land.
black death: A pestilence which ravaged Europe and Asia in the fourteenthcentury.
botryogen: A hydrous sulphate of iron of a deep red color. It often occursin botryoidal form.
bulger: A driver or a brassy with a convex face.
burletta: A comic operetta; a music farce. Byron.
boroughmaster: The mayor, governor, or bailiff of a borough.
bethlehem: In the Ethiopic church, a small building attached to a churchedifice, in which the bread for the eucharist is made. Audsley.
brittle star: Any species of ophiuran starfishes. See Ophiuroidea.
blubbering: The act of weeping noisily.He spake well save that his blubbering interrupted him. Winthrop.
bassetto: A tenor or small bass viol.
bede: To pray; also, to offer; to proffer. [Obs.] R. of Gloucester.Chaucer.
bamboozle: To deceive by trickery; to cajole by confusing the senses; tohoax; to mystify; to humbug. [Colloq.] Addison.What oriental tomfoolery is bamboozling you J. H. Newman.
bind: Indurated clay, when much mixed with the oxide of iron. Kirwan.
burglarious: Pertaining to burglary; constituting the crime of burglary.To come down a chimney is held a burglarious entry. Blackstone.
bargainer: One who makes a bargain; -- sometimes in the sense ofbargainor.
bitternut: The swamp hickory (Carya amara). Its thin-shelled nuts arebitter.
black-hearted: Having a wicked, malignant disposition; morally bad.
bird-eyed: Quick-sighted; catching a glance as one goes.
berseem: An Egyptian clover (Trifolium alexandrinum) extensivelycultivated as a forage plant and soil-renewing crop in the alkalinesoils of the Nile valley, and now introduced into the southwesternUnited States. It is more succulent than other clovers or thanalfalfa. Called also Egyptian clover.
barbarian: Of, or pertaining to, or resembling, barbarians; rude;uncivilized; barbarous; as, barbarian governments or nations.
blin: To stop; to cease; to desist. [Obs.] Spenser.
badiaga: A fresh-water sponge (Spongilla), common in the north ofEurope, the powder of which is used to take away the livid marks ofbruises.
balm: An aromatic plant of the genus Melissa.
bunko: A kind of swindling game or scheme, by means of cards or by asham lottery. [Written also bunco.] Bunko steerer, a person employedas a decoy in bunko. [Slang, U.S.]
bike: A nest of wild bees, wasps, or ants; a swarm. [Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
bankrupt: A trader who secretes himself, or does certain other actstending to defraud his creditors. Blackstone.
bird of paradise: The name of several very beautiful birds of the genus Paradiseaand allied genera, inhabiting New Guinea and the adjacent islands.The males have brilliant colors, elegant plumes, and often remarkabletail feathers.
blindly: Without sight, discernment, or understanding; without thought,investigation, knowledge, or purpose of one's own.By his imperious mistress blindly led. Dryden.
broadside: The side of a ship above the water line, from the bow to thequarter.
brunette: A girl or woman with a somewhat brown or dark complexion.-- a.
besprinkle: To sprinkle over; to scatter over.The bed besprinkles, and bedews the ground. Dryden.
bisulphite: A salt of sulphurous acid in which the base replaces but halfthe hydrogen of the acid; an acid sulphite.
besetting: Habitually attacking, harassing, or pressing upon or about; as,a besetting sin.
bemock: To mock; to ridicule.Bemock the modest moon. Shak.
bowhead: The great Arctic or Greenland whale. (Balæna mysticetus). SeeBaleen, and Whale.
bayou state: Mississippi; -- a nickname, from its numerous bayous.
bumboat: A clumsy boat, used for conveying provisions, fruit, etc., forsale, to vessels lying in port or off shore.
boucherize: To impregnate with a preservative solution of copper sulphate,as timber, railroad ties, etc.
brachydome: A dome parallel to the shorter lateral axis. See Dome.
beurre: A beurré (or buttery) pear, one with the meas, Beurré d'Anjou;Beurré Clairgeau.
butterfly: A general name for the numerous species of diurnal Lepidoptera.
bindingness: The condition or property of being binding; obligatory quality.Coleridge.
beardlessness: The state or quality of being destitute of beard.
barricade: A fortification, made in haste, of trees, earth, palisades,wagons, or anything that will obstruct the progress or attack of anenemy. It is usually an obstruction formed in streets to block anenemy's access.
bon ton: The height of the fashion; fashionable society.
boarder: One who boards a ship; one selected to board an enemy's ship.Totten.
boardable: That can be boarded, as a ship.
bantingism: A method of reducing corpulence by avoiding food containingmuch farinaceous, saccharine, or oily matter; -- so called fromWilliam Banting of London.
bedrench: To drench; to saturate with moisture; to soak. Shak.
blackboard: A broad board painted black, or any black surface on whichwriting, drawing, or the working of mathematical problems can be donewith chalk or crayons. It is much used in schools.
bucolic: Of or pertaining to the life and occupation of a shepherd;pastoral; rustic.
basioccipital: Of or pertaining to the bone in the base of the cranium,frequently forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but usuallydistinct in the young.-- n.
borosilicate: A double salt of boric and silicic acids, as in the naturalminerals tourmaline, datolite, etc.
banco: A bank, especially that of Venice.
booty: That which is seized by violence or obtained by robbery,especially collective spoil taken in war; plunder; pillage. Milton.To play booty, to play dishonestly, with an intent to lose; to allowone's adversary to win at cards at first, in order to induce him tocontinue playing and victimize him afterwards. [Obs.] L'Estrange.
bobtail: An animal (as a horse or dog) with a short tail. Rag, tag, andbobtail, the rabble.
buckwheat: A plant (Fagopyrum esculentum) of the Polygonum family, theseed of which is used for food.
backstay: A rope or stay extending from the masthead to the side of aship, slanting a little aft, to assist the shrouds in supporting themast. [ Often used in the plural.]
bordman: A bordar; a tenant in bordage.
baffling: Frustrating; discomfiting; disconcerting; as, bafflingcurrents, winds, tasks.-- Bafflingly, adv.-- Bafflingness, n.
bull: The male of any species of cattle (Bovidæ); hence, the male ofany large quadruped, as the elephant; also, the male of the whale.
billiards: A game played with ivory balls o a cloth-covered, rectangulartable, bounded by elastic cushions. The player seeks to impel hisball with his cue so that it shall either strike (carom upon) twoother balls, or drive another ball into one of the pockets with whichthe table sometimes is furnished.
bivalved: Having two valves, as the oyster and some seed pods; bivalve.
bigotedly: In the manner of a bigot.
belvedere: A small building, or a part of a building, more or less open,constructed in a place commanding a fine prospect.
bribable: Capable of being bribed.A more bribable class of electors. S. Edwards.
blackness: The quality or state of being black; black color; atrociousnessor enormity in wickedness.They're darker now than blackness. Donne.
bespawl: To daub, soil, or make foul with spawl or spittle. [Obs.]Milton.
birthless: Of mean extraction. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
bullish: Partaking of the nature of a bull, or a blunder.Let me inform you, a toothless satire is as improper as a toothedsleek stone, and as bullish. Milton.
boll: To form a boll or seed vessel; to go to seed.The barley was in the ear, and the flax was bolled. Ex. ix. 31.
bookbindery: A bookbinder's shop; a place or establishment for bindingbooks.
bulse: A purse or bag in which to carry or measure diamonds, etc.[India] Macaulay.
bosset: A rudimental antler of a young male of the red deer.
brinish: Like brine; somewhat salt; saltish. "Brinish tears." Shak.
beechnut: The nut of the beech tree.
benzene: A volatile, very inflammable liquid, C6H6, contained in thenaphtha produced by the destructive distillation of coal, from whichit is separated by fractional distillation. The name is sometimesapplied also to the impure commercial product or benzole, and also,but rarely, to a similar mixed product of petroleum. Benzene nucleus,Benzene ring (Chem.), a closed chain or ring, consisting of sixcarbon atoms, each with one hydrogen atom attached, regarded as thetype from which the aromatic compounds are derived. This ring formulais provisionally accepted as representing the probable constitutionof the benzene molecule, C6H6, and as the type on which itsderivatives are formed.
bellman: A man who rings a bell, especially to give notice of anythingin the streets. Formerly, also, a night watchman who called thehours. Milton.
breeching: A strong rope rove through the cascabel of a cannon and securedto ringbolts in the ship's side, to limit the recoil of the gun whenit is discharged.
butyl: A compound radical, regarded as butane, less one atom ofhydrogen.
basi-: A combining form, especially in anatomical and botanical words,to indicate the base or position at or near a base; forming a base;as, basibranchials, the most ventral of the cartilages or bones ofthe branchial arches; basicranial, situated at the base of thecranium; basifacial, basitemporal, etc.
blanketing: One that covers a group or class of things or propertiesinstead of one or more things mentioned individually, as where amortgage secures various debts as a group, or subjects a group orclass of different pieces of property to one general lien.
backsight: The reading of the leveling staff in its unchanged positionwhen the leveling instrument has been taken to a new position; asight directed backwards to a station previously occupied. Cf.Foresight, n., 3.
blancmange: A preparation for desserts, etc., made from isinglass, seamoss, cornstarch, or other gelatinous or starchy substance, withmild, usually sweetened and flavored, and shaped in a mold.
bandon: Disposal; control; license. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
berg: A large mass or hill, as of ice.Glittering bergs of ice. Tennyson.
build: Form or mode of construction; general figure; make; as, thebuild of a ship.
butyrone: A liquid ketone obtained by heating calcium butyrate.
basque: Pertaining to Biscay, its people, or their language.
beguilement: The act of beguiling, or the state of being beguiled.
beefwood: An Australian tree (Casuarina), and its red wood, used forcabinetwork; also, the trees Stenocarpus salignus of New South Wales,and Banksia compar of Queensland.
bestialize: To make bestial, or like a beast; to degrade; to brutalize.The process of bestializing humanity. Hare.
bibliomaniacal: Pertaining to a passion for books; relating to a bibliomaniac.
bald eagle: The white-headed eagle (Haliæetus leucocephalus) of America.The young, until several years old, lack the white feathers on thehead.
bordelais: Of or pertaining to Bordeaux, in France, or to the districtaround Bordeaux.
bully tree: The name of several West Indian trees of the order Sapotaceæ,as Dipholis nigra and species of Sapota and Mimusops. Most of themyield a substance closely resembling gutta-percha.
brand spore: One of several spores growing in a series or chain, andproduced by one of the fungi called brand.
bearberry: A trailing plant of the heath family (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi),having leaves which are tonic and astringent, and glossy red berriesof which bears are said to be fond.
bigamy: The offense of marrying one person when already legally marriedto another. Wharton.
bendlet: A narrow bend, esp. one half the width of the bend.
bathos: A ludicrous descent from the elevated to the low, in writing orspeech; anticlimax.
bank book: A book kept by a depositor, in which an officer of a bankenters the debits and credits of the depositor's account with thebank.
bankside: The slope of a bank, especially of the bank of a steam.
bema: A platform from which speakers addressed an assembly. Mitford.
boza: An acidulated fermented drink of the Arabs and Egyptians, madefrom millet seed and various astringent substances; also, anintoxicating beverage made from hemp seed, darnel meal, and water.[Written also bosa, bozah, bouza.]
blackcap: An apple roasted till black, to be served in a dish of boiledcustard.
briny: Of or pertaining to brine, or to the sea; partaking of thenature of brine; salt; as, a briny taste; the briny flood.
bird: A warm-blooded, feathered vertebrate provided with wings. SeeAves.
baboon: One of the Old World Quadrumana, of the genera Cynocephalus andPapio; the dog-faced ape. Baboons have dog-like muzzles and largecanine teeth, cheek pouches, a short tail, and naked callosities onthe buttocks. They are mostly African. See Mandrill, and Chacma, andDrill an ape.
bergschrund: The crevasse or series of crevasses, usually deep and oftenbroad, frequently occurring near the head of a mountain glacier,about where the névé field joins the valley portion of the glacier.
brisk: To make or become lively; to enliven; to animate; to take, orcause to take, an erect or bold attitude; -- usually with up.
bristliness: The quality or state of having bristles.
be: A prefix, originally the same word as by; joined with verbs, itserves: (a) To intensify the meaning; as, bespatter, bestir. (b) Torender an intransitive verb transitive; as, befall (to fall upon);bespeak (to speak for). (c) To make the action of a verb particularor definite; as, beget (to get as offspring); beset (to set around).
bonbonniere: A small fancy box or dish for bonbons.
bondholder: A person who holds the bonds of a public or private corporationfor the payment of money at a certain time.
birkie: A lively or mettlesome fellow. [Jocular, Scot.] Burns.
brewhouse: A house or building appropriated to brewing; a brewery.
booker: One who enters accounts or names, etc., in a book; abookkeeper.
batardeau: A wall built across the ditch of a fortification, with a sluicegate to regulate the height of water in the ditch on both sides ofthe wall.
between: Intermediate time or space; interval. [Poetic & R.] Shak.
bead: To ornament with beads or beading.
beauish: Like a beau; characteristic of a beau; foppish; fine. "Abeauish young spark." Byrom.
breedbate: One who breeds or originates quarrels. [Obs.] "No telltale norno breedbate." Shak.
backhandedness: State of being backhanded; the using of backhanded or indirectmethods.
bestrew: To strew or scatter over; to besprinkle. [Spelt also bestrow.]Milton.
blastomere: One of the segments first formed by the division of the ovum.Balfour.
bezzle: To plunder; to waste in riot. [Obs.]
boracic: Pertaining to, or produced from, borax; containing boron;boric; as, boracic acid.
brassica: A genus of plants embracing several species ad varietiesdiffering much in appearance and qualities: such as the commoncabbage (B. oleracea), broccoli, cauliflowers, etc.; the wild turnip(B. campestris); the common turnip (B. rapa); the rape of coleseed(B. napus), etc.
barrenness: The condition of being barren; sterility; unproductiveness.A total barrenness of invention. Dryden.
black art: The art practiced by conjurers and witches; necromancy;conjuration; magic.
becoming: Appropriate or fit; congruous; suitable; graceful; befitting.A low and becoming tone. Thackeray.
beath: To bathe; also, to dry or heat, as unseasoned wood. [Obs.]Spenser.
bible: A book with an authoritative exposition of some topic,respected by many experts on the field. Bible Society, an associationfor securing the multiplication and wide distribution of the Bible.-- Douay Bible. See Douay Bible.-- Geneva Bible. See under Geneva.
brose: Pottage made by pouring some boiling liquid on meal (esp.oatmeal), and stirring it. It is called beef brose, water brose,etc., according to the name of the liquid (beef broth, hot water,etc.) used. [Scot.]
bagwig: A wig, in use in the 18th century, with the hair at the back ofthe head in a bag.
bloomery: A furnace and forge in which wrought iron in the form of bloomsis made directly from the ore, or (more rarely) from cast iron.
blacksmith: A fish of the Pacific coast (Chromis, or Heliastes,punctipinnis), of a blackish color.
beggarhood: The condition of being a beggar; also, the class of beggars.
binnacle: A case or box placed near the helmsman, containing the compassof a ship, and a light to show it at night. Totten.
blatherskite: A blustering, talkative fellow. [Local slang, U. S.] Barllett.
blote: To cure, as herrings, by salting and smoking them; to bloat.[Obs.]
bishop sleeve: A wide sleeve, once worn by women.
bridalty: Celebration of the nuptial feast. [Obs.] "In honor of thisbridalty." B. Jonson.
bottomry: A contract in the nature of a mortgage, by which the owner of aship, or the master as his agent, hypothecates and binds the ship(and sometimes the accruing freight) as security for the repayment ofmoney advanced or lent for the use of the ship, if she terminates hervoyage successfully. If the ship is lost by perils of the sea, thelender loses the money; but if the ship arrives safe, he is toreceive the money lent, with the interest or premium stipulated,although it may, and usually does, exceed the legal rate of interest.See Hypothecation.
blinder: One of the leather screens on a bridle, to hinder a horse fromseeing objects at the side; a blinker.
bunch grass: A grass growing in bunches and affording pasture. InCalifornia, Atropis tenuifolia, Festuca scabrella, and several kindsof Stipa are favorite bunch grasses. In Utah, Eriocoma cuspidata is agood bunch grass.
binocle: A dioptric telescope, fitted with two tubes joining, so as toenable a person to view an object with both eyes at once; a double-barreled field glass or an opera glass.
baya: The East Indian weaver bird (Ploceus Philippinus).
burghbrech: The offense of violating the pledge given by every inhabitantof a tithing to keep the peace; breach of the peace. Burrill.
broad-brimmed: Having a broad brim.A broad-brimmed flat silver plate. Tatler.
beholden: Obliged; bound in gratitude; indebted.But being so beholden to the Prince. Tennyson.
barbastel: A European bat (Barbastellus communis), with hairy lips.
bombycid: Like or pertaining to the genus Bombyx, or the familyBombycidæ.
berberine: An alkaloid obtained, as a bitter, yellow substance, from theroot of the barberry, gold thread, and other plants.
biprism: A prism whose refracting angle is very nearly 180 degrees.
bunchberry: The dwarf cornel (Cornus Canadensis), which bears a densecluster of bright red, edible berries.
bigness: The state or quality of being big; largeness; size; bulk.
balaustine: The pomegranate tree (Punica granatum). The bark of the root,the rind of the fruit, and the flowers are used medicinally.
bivious: Having, or leading, two ways.Bivious theorems and Janus-faced doctrines. Sir T. Browne.
boxhauling: A method of going from one tack to another. See Boxhaul.
birlaw: A law made by husbandmen respecting rural affairs; a rustic orlocal law or by-law. [Written also byrlaw, birlie, birley.]
blaze: A white spot on the forehead of a horse.
birr: To make, or move with, a whirring noise, as of wheels inmotion.
birdcatcher: One whose employment it is to catch birds; a fowler.
beaverteen: A kind of fustian made of coarse twilled cotton, shorn afterdyeing. Simmonds.
birdbolt: A short blunt arrow for killing birds without piercing them.Hence: Anything which smites without penetrating. Shak.
buzzer: One who, or that which, buzzes; a whisperer; a talebearer.And wants not buzzers to infect his ear With pestilent speeches ofhis father's death. Shak.
brand: Any minute fungus which produces a burnt appearance in plants.The brands are of many species and several genera of the orderPucciniæi.
backdown: A receding or giving up; a complete surrender. [Colloq.]
bardic: Of or pertaining to bards, or their poetry. "The bardic lays ofancient Greece." G. P. Marsh.
biventral: (Anat.) Having two bellies or protuberances; as, a biventral,or digastric, muscle, or the biventral lobe of the cerebellum.
blob: A small fresh-water fish (Uranidea Richardsoni); the miller'sthumb.
bridgepot: The adjustable socket, or step, of a millstone spindle. Knight.
bayadere: A female dancer in the East Indies. [Written also bajadere.]
brumaire: The second month of the calendar adopted by the first Frenchrepublic. It began thirty days after the autumnal equinox. SeeVendemiaire.
blackfeet: A tribe of North American Indians formerly inhabiting thecountry from the upper Missouri River to the Saskatchewan, but nowmuch reduced in numbers.
backwash: To clean the oil from (wood) after combing.
barrack: A building for soldiers, especially when in garrison. Commonlyin the pl., originally meaning temporary huts, but now usuallyapplied to a permanent structure or set of buildings.He lodged in a miserable hut or barrack, composed of dry branches andthatched with straw. Gibbon.
brachyceral: Having short antennæ, as certain insects.
bromanil: A substance analogous to chloranil but containing bromine inplace of chlorine.
brobdingnagian: Colossal' of extraordinary height; gigantic.-- n.
bifilar: Two-threaded; involving the use of two threads; as, bifilarsuspension; a bifilar balance. Bifilar micrometer (often called abifilar), an instrument form measuring minute distances or angles bymeans of two very minute threads (usually spider lines), one ofwhich, at least, is movable; -- more commonly called a filarmicrometer.
brouded: Braided; broidered. [Obs.]Alle his clothes brouded up and down. Chaucer.
by-stroke: An accidental or a slyly given stroke.
bismuthic: Of or pertaining to bismuth; containing bismuth, when thiselement has its higher valence; as, bismuthic oxide.
buttony: Ornamented with a large number of buttons. "The buttony boy."Thackeray. "My coat so blue and buttony." W. S. Gilbert.
benedictine: Pertaining to the monks of St. Benedict, or St. Benet.
barothermograph: An instrument for recording both pressure and temperature, asof the atmosphere.
benzosol: Guaiacol benzoate, used as an intestinal antiseptic and as asubstitute for creosote in phthisis. It is a colorless crystallinepewder.
bower-barff process: A certain process for producing upon articles of iron or steelan adherent coating of the magnetic oxide of iron (which is notliable to corrosion by air, moisture, or ordinary acids). This isaccomplished by producing, by oxidation at about 1600º F. in a closedspace, a coating containing more or less of the ferric oxide (Fe2O3)and the subsequent change of this in a reduced atmosphere to themagnetic oxide (Fe2O4).
borax: A white or gray crystalline salt, with a slight alkaline taste,used as a flux, in soldering metals, making enamels, fixing colors onporcelain, and as a soap. It occurs native in certain mineralsprings, and is made from the boric acid of hot springs in Tuscany.It was originally obtained from a lake in Thibet, and was sent toEurope under the name of tincal. Borax is a pyroborate or tetraborateof sodium, Na2B4O7.10H2O. Borax bead. (Chem.) See Bead, n., 3.
bellibone: A woman excelling both in beauty and goodness; a fair maid.[Obs.] Spenser.
boulangism: The spirit or principles of a French political movementidentified with Gen. Georges Boulanger (d. 1891), whose militarismand advocacy of revenge on Germany attracted to him a miscellaneousparty of monarchists and Republican malcontents. -- Bou*lan"gist (#),n.
blushingly: In a blushing manner; with a blush or blushes; as, to answer orconfess blushingly.
blocking course: The finishing course of a wall showing above a cornice.
bemaul: To maul or beat severely; to bruise. "In order to bemaulYorick." Sterne.
breviloquence: A brief and pertinent mode of speaking. [R.]
barbate: Bearded; beset with long and weak hairs.
bonapartean: Of or pertaining to Napoleon Bonaparte or his family.
bismuth: One of the elements; a metal of a reddish white color,crystallizing in rhombohedrons. It is somewhat harder than lead, andrather brittle; masses show broad cleavage surfaces when brokenacross. It melts at 507º Fahr., being easily fused in the flame of acandle. It is found in a native state, and as a constituent of someminerals. Specific gravity 9.8. Atomic weight 207.5. Symbol Bi.
bordlode: The service formerly required of a tenant, to carry timber fromthe woods to the lord's house. Bailey. Mozley & W.
boride: A binary compound of boron with a more positive or basicelement or radical; -- formerly called boruret.
bescratch: To tear with the nails; to cover with scratches.
beslobber: To slobber on; to smear with spittle running from the mouth.Also Fig.: as, to beslobber with praise.
bullantic: Pertaining to, or used in, papal bulls. Fry. Bullantic letters,Gothic letters used in papal bulls.
biometry: Measurement of life; calculation of the probable duration ofhuman life.
brae: A hillside; a slope; a bank; a hill. [Scot.] Burns.
beamed: Furnished with beams, as the head of a stag.Tost his beamed frontlet to the sky. Sir W. Scott.
beleper: To infect with leprosy. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
badian: An evergreen Chinese shrub of the Magnolia family (Illiciumanisatum), and its aromatic seeds; Chinese anise; star anise.
beelzebub: The title of a heathen deity to whom the Jews ascribed thesovereignty of the evil spirits; hence, the Devil or a devil. SeeBaal.
bagman: A commercial traveler; one employed to solicit orders formanufacturers and tradesmen. Thackeray.
biographer: One who writes an account or history of the life of aparticular person; a writer of lives, as Plutarch.
boyer: A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end. Sir W. Raleigh.
bibacity: The practice or habit of drinking too much; tippling. Blount.
breve: A note or character of time, equivalent to two semibreves orfour minims. When dotted, it is equal to three semibreves. It wasformerly of a square figure (as thus: Moore.
biblicality: The quality of being biblical; a biblical subject. [R.]
bachelordom: The state of bachelorhood; the whole body of bachelors.
bobfly: The fly at the end of the leader; an end fly.
buckstall: A toil or net to take deer.
bridesman: A male friend who attends upon a bridegroom and bride at theirmarriage; the "best man." Sir W. Scott.
briticism: A word, phrase, or idiom peculiar to Great Britain; any mannerof using a word or words that is peculiar to Great Britain.
blooth: Bloom; a blossoming. [Prov. Eng.]All that blooth means heavy autumn work for him and his hands. T.Hardy.
bilk: To frustrate or disappoint; to deceive or defraud, bynonfulfillment of engagement; to leave in the lurch; to give the slipto; as, to bilk a creditor. Thackeray.
brainpan: The bones which inclose the brain; the skull; the cranium.
bookstall: A stall or stand where books are sold.
bardism: The system of bards; the learning and maxims of bards.
brevipennate: Short-winged; -- applied to birds which can not fly, owing totheir short wings, as the ostrich, cassowary, and emu.
bushido: The unwritten code of moral principles regulating the actionsof the Japanese knighthood, or Samurai; the chivalry of Japan.
bireme: An ancient galley or vessel with two banks or tiers of oars.
broad seal: The great seal of England; the public seal of a country orstate.
beaucatcher: A small flat curl worn on the temple by women. [Humorous]
brillante: In a gay, showy, and sparkling style.
buccaneer: A robber upon the sea; a pirate; -- a term applied especiallyto the piratical adventurers who made depredations on the Spaniardsin America in the 17th and 18th centuries. [Written also bucanier.]
bleacher: One who whitens, or whose occupation is to whiten, bybleaching.
blissless: Destitute of bliss. Sir P. Sidney.
brew: The mixture formed by brewing; that which is brewed. Bacon.
bougainvillaea: A genus of plants of the order Nyctoginaceæ, from tropicalSouth America, having the flowers surrounded by large bracts.
bondage: Villenage; tenure of land on condition of doing the meanestservices for the owner.
bell metal: A hard alloy or bronze, consisting usually of about three partsof copper to one of tin; -- used for making bells. Bell metal ore, asulphide of tin, copper, and iron; the mineral stannite.
bromidiom: A conventional comment or saying, such as those characteristicof bromides. [Slang]
broker: An agent employed to effect bargains and contracts, as amiddleman or negotiator, between other persons, for a compensationcommonly called brokerage. He takes no possession, as broker, of thesubject matter of the negotiation. He generally contracts in thenames of those who employ him, and not in his own. Story.
black letter: The old English or Gothic letter, in which the Early Englishmanuscripts were written, and the first English books were printed.It was conspicuous for its blackness. See Type.
basseting: The upward direction of a vein in a mine; the emergence of astratum at the surface.
bettor: One who bets; a better. Addison.
baptismal: Pertaining to baptism; as, baptismal vows. Baptismal name, theChristian name, which is given at baptism.
backdoor: Acting from behind and in concealment; as backdoor intrigues.
bejewel: To ornament with a jewel or with jewels; to spangle. "Bejeweledhands." Thackeray.
bedlamite: An inhabitant of a madhouse; a madman. "Raving bedlamites."Beattie.
bicarinate: Having two keel-like projections, as the upper palea ofgrasses.
beau ideal: A conception or image of consummate beauty, moral or physical,formed in the mind, free from all the deformities, defects, andblemishes seen in actual existence; an ideal or faultless standard ormodel.
bashi-bazouk: A soldier belonging to the irregular troops of the Turkisharmy.
befuddle: To becloud and confuse, as with liquor.
beetle-browed: Having prominent, overhanging brows; hence, lowering or sullen.
breadthwise: In the direction of the breadth.
bine: The winding or twining stem of a hop vine or other climbingplant.
bullate: Appearing as if blistered; inflated; puckered. Bullate leaf(Bot.), a leaf, the membranous part of which rises between the veinspuckered elevations convex on one side and concave on the other.
balladry: Ballad poems; the subject or style of ballads. "Base balladryis so beloved." Drayton.
bound: The external or limiting line, either real or imaginary, of anyobject or space; that which limits or restrains, or within whichsomething is limited or restrained; limit; confine; extent; boundary.He hath compassed the waters with bounds. Job xxvi. 10.On earth's remotest bounds. Campbell.And mete the bounds of hate and love. Tennyson.To keep within bounds, not to exceed or pass beyond assigned limits;to act with propriety or discretion.
boy scout: Orig., a member of the "Boy Scouts," an organization of boysfounded in 1908, by Sir R. S. S. Baden-Powell, to promote goodcitizenship by creating in them a spirit of civic duty and ofusefulness to others, by stimulating their interest in wholesomemental, moral, industrial, and physical activities, etc. Hence, amember of any of the other similar organizations, which are nowworldwide. In "The Boy Scouts of America" the local councils aregenerally under a scout commissioner, under whose supervision arescout masters, each in charge of a troop of two or more patrols ofeight scouts each, who are of three classes, tenderfoot, second-classscout, and first-class scout.
bowable: Capable of being bowed or bent; flexible; easily influenced;yielding. [Obs.]
branlin: A young salmon or parr, in the stage in which it has transverseblack bands, as if burned by a gridiron.
brevetcy: The rank or condition of a brevet officer.
bachelry: The body of young aspirants for knighthood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
bindery: A place where books, or other articles, are bound; abookbinder's establishment.
bissell truck: A truck for railroad rolling stock, consisting of two ordinaryaxle boxes sliding in guides attached to a triangular frame; --called also pony truck.
barbarousness: The quality or state of being barbarous; barbarity; barbarism.
buster: Something huge; a roistering blade; also, a spree. [Slang,U.S.] Bartlett.
buhrstone: A cellular, flinty rock, used for mill stones. [Written alsoburrstone.]
biscotin: A confection made of flour, sugar, marmalade, and eggs; a sweetbiscuit.
bit: To put a bridle upon; to put the bit in the mouth of.
bonny: A round and compact bed of ore, or a distinct bed, notcommunicating with a vein.
breechblock: The movable piece which closes the breech of a breech-loadingfirearm, and resists the backward force of the discharge. It iswithdrawn for the insertion of a cartridge, and closed again beforethe gun is fired.
bake: The process, or result, of baking.
brahmo-somaj: A modern reforming theistic sect among the Hindos. [Writtenalso Brahma-samaj.]
bricklayer: One whose pccupation is to build with bricks. Bricklayer'sitch. See under Itch.
brownist: A follower of Robert Brown, of England, in the 16th century,who taught that every church is complete and independent in itselfwhen organized, and consists of members meeting in one place, havingfull power to elect and depose its officers.
bruisewort: A plant supposed to heal bruises, as the true daisy, thesoapwort, and the comfrey.
bogtrotter: One who lives in a boggy country; -- applied in derision to thelowest class of Irish. Halliwell.
backside: The hinder part, posteriors, or rump of a person or animal.
beakhead: An ornament used in rich Norman doorways, resembling a headwith a beak. Parker.
bromine: One of the elements, related in its chemical qualities tochlorine and iodine. Atomic weight 79.8. Symbol Br. It is a deepreddish brown liquid of a very disagreeable odor, emitting a brownishvapor at the ordinary temperature. In combination it is found inminute quantities in sea water, and in many saline springs. It occursalso in the mineral bromyrite.
billow: To surge; to rise and roll in waves or surges; to undulate."The billowing snow." Prior.
bollard: An upright wooden or iron post in a boat or on a dock, used inveering or fastening ropes. Bollard timber (Naut.), a timber, alsocalled a knighthead, rising just within the stem in a ship, on eitherside of the bowsprit, to secure its end.
bridecake: Rich or highly ornamented cake, to be distributed to the guestsat a wedding, or sent to friends after the wedding.
brewer: One who brews; one whose occupation is to prepare malt liquors.
barocyclonometer: An aneroid barometer for use with accompanying graphic diagramsand printed directions designed to aid mariners to interpret theindications of the barometer so as to determine the existence of aviolent storm at a distance of several hundred miles.
buoy: A float; esp. a floating object moored to the bottom, to mark achannel or to point out the position of something beneath the water,as an anchor, shoal, rock, etc. Anchor buoy, a buoy attached to, ormarking the position of, an anchor.-- Bell buoy, a large buoy on which a bell is mounted, to be rung bythe motion of the waves.-- Breeches buoy. See under Breeches.-- Cable buoy, an empty cask employed to buoy up the cable in rockyanchorage.-- Can buoy, a hollow buoy made of sheet or boiler iron, usuallyconical or pear-shaped.-- Life buoy, a float intended to support persons who have falleninto the water, until a boat can be dispatched to save them.-- Nut or Nun buoy, a buoy large in the middle, and tapering nearlyto a point at each end.-- To stream the buoy, to let the anchor buoy fall by the ship'sside into the water, before letting go the anchor.-- Whistling buoy, a buoy fitted with a whistle that is blown by theaction of the waves.
backbiter: One who backbites; a secret calumniator or detractor.
bilin: A name applied to the amorphous or crystalline mass obtainedfrom bile by the action of alcohol and ether. It is composed of amixture of the sodium salts of the bile acids.
bedbug: A wingless, bloodsucking, hemipterous insect (CimexLectularius), sometimes infesting houses and especially beds. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
bronzine: A metal so prepared as to have the appearance of bronze.-- a.
bronzewing: An Australian pigeon of the genus Phaps, of several species; --so called from its bronze plumage.
bulwark: A rampart; a fortification; a bastion or outwork.
blemish: Any mark of deformity or injury, whether physical or moral;anything; that diminishes beauty, or renders imperfect that which isotherwise well formed; that which impairs reputation.He shall take two he lambs without blemish, and one ewe lamb of thefirst year without blemish. Lev. xiv. 10.The reliefs of an envious man are those little blemishes andimperfections that discover themselves in an illustrious character.Spectator.
burrel shot: A mixture of shot, nails, stones, pieces of old iron, etc.,fired from a cannon at short range, in an emergency. [R.]
brattishing: Carved openwork, as of a shrine, battlement, or parapet.
bichromate: A salt containing two parts of chromic acid to one of the otheringredients; as, potassium bichromate; -- called also dichromate.
broken-backed: Hogged; so weakened in the frame as to droop at each end; --said of a ship. Totten.
botchery: A botching, or that which is done by botching; clumsy orcareless workmanship.
babingtonite: A mineral occurring in triclinic crystals approaching pyroxenein angle, and of a greenish black color. It is a silicate of iron,manganese, and lime.
bridle: The piece in the interior of a gun lock, which holds in placethe timbler, sear, etc.
blesser: One who blesses; one who bestows or invokes a blessing.
buffoonish: Like a buffoon; consisting in low jests or gestures. Blair.
basion: The middle of the anterior margin of the great foramen of theskull.
buttery: Having the qualities, consistence, or appearance, of butter.
baenopod: One of the thoracic legs of Arthropods.
bilalo: A two-masted passenger boat or small vessel, used in the bay ofManila.
bruckeled: Wet and dirty; begrimed. [Obs. or Dial.] Herrick.
bob-cherry: A play among children, in which a cherry, hung so as to bobagainst the mouth, is to be caught with the teeth.
bondar: A small quadruped of Bengal (Paradoxurus bondar), allied to thegenet; -- called also musk cat.
bryological: Relating to bryology; as, bryological studies.
beefsteak: A steak of beef; a slice of beef broiled or suitable forbroiling.
bobolink: An American singing bird (Dolichonyx oryzivorus). The male isblack and white; the female is brown; -- called also, ricebird,reedbird, and Boblincoln.The happiest bird of our spring is the bobolink. W. Irving.
breeze: Refuse coal, coal ashes, and cinders, used in the burning ofbricks.
breastbone: The bone of the breast; the sternum.
belgian: Of or pertaining to Belgium.-- n.
beton: The French name for concrete; hence, concrete made after theFrench fashion.
bigeminate: Having a forked petiole, and a pair of leaflets at the end ofeach division; biconjugate; twice paired; -- said of a decompoundleaf.
bleater: One who bleats; a sheep.In cold, stiff soils the bleaters oft complain Of gouty ails. Dyer.
barefoot: With the feet bare; without shoes or stockings.
banjo: A stringed musical instrument having a head and neck like theguitar, and its body like a tambourine. It has five strings, and isplayed with the fingers and hands.
benzamide: A transparent crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.NH2, obtained bythe action of ammonia upon chloride of benzoyl, as also by severalother reactions with benzoyl compounds.
bin: A box, frame, crib, or inclosed place, used as a receptacle forany commodity; as, a corn bin; a wine bin; a coal bin.
beholdingness: , The state of being obliged or beholden. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
besort: To assort or be congruous with; to fit, or become. [Obs.]Such men as may besort your age. Shak.
brambly: Pertaining to, resembling, or full of, brambles. "In bramblywildernesses." Tennyson.
bawdyhouse: A house of prostitution; a house of ill fame; a brothel.
bibber: One given to drinking alcoholic beverages too freely; atippler; -- chiefly used in composition; as, winebibber.
bucktooth: Any tooth that juts out.When he laughed, two white buckteeth protruded. Thackeray.
brachypinacoid: A plane of an orthorhombic crystal which is parallel both tothe vertical axis and to the shorter lateral (brachydiagonal) axis.
borecole: A brassicaceous plant of many varieties, cultivated for itsleaves, which are not formed into a compact head like the cabbage,but are loose, and are generally curled or wrinkled; kale.
bavarian: Of or pertaining to Bavaria.-- n.
bantam work: Carved and painted work in imitation of Japan ware.
barbule: One of the processes along the edges of the barbs of a feather,by which adjacent barbs interlock. See Feather.
biogeography: The branch of biology which deals with the geographicaldistribution of animals and plants. It includes both zoögeography andphytogeography. -- Bi`o*ge`o*graph"ic (#), a. --Bi`o*ge`o*graph"ic*al*ly (#), adv.
bleak: A small European river fish (Leuciscus alburnus), of the familyCyprinidæ; the blay. [Written also blick.]
bird cherry: A shrub (Prunus Padus ) found in Northern and Central Europe.It bears small black cherries.
borachte: A large leather bottle for liquors, etc., made of the skin of agoat or other animal. Hence: A drunkard. [Obs.]You're an absolute borachio. Congreve.
brachystochrone: A curve, in which a body, starting from a given point, anddescending solely by the force of gravity, will reach another givenpoint in a shorter time than it could by any other path. This curveof quickest descent, as it is sometimes called, is, in a vacuum, thesame as the cycloid.
barathea: A soft fabric with a kind of basket weave and a diaperedpattern.
berrying: A seeking for or gathering of berries, esp. of such as growwild.
barley-bree: Liquor made from barley; strong ale. [Humorous] [Scot.] Burns.
bipupillate: Having an eyelike spot on the wing, with two dots within it ofa different color, as in some butterflies.
boat bug: An aquatic hemipterous insect of the genus Notonecta; -- socalled from swimming on its back, which gives it the appearance of alittle boat. Called also boat fly, boat insect, boatman, and waterboatman.
bey: A governor of a province or district in the Turkish dominions;also, in some places, a prince or nobleman; a beg; as, the bey ofTunis.
binocular: A binocular glass, whether opera glass, telescope, ormicroscope.
bencher: One of the senior and governing members of an Inn of Court.
basipterygoid: Applied to a protuberance of the base of the sphenoid bone.
bailor: One who delivers goods or money to another in trust.
bookmate: A schoolfellow; an associate in study.
bicolligate: Having the anterior toes connected by a basal web.
bidigitate: Having two fingers or fingerlike projections.
bodleian: Of or pertaining to Sir Thomas Bodley, or to the celebratedlibrary at Oxford, founded by him in the sixteenth century.
bedstead: A framework for supporting a bed.
bronchotomy: An incision into the windpipe or larynx, including theoperations of tracheotomy and laryngotomy.
batlet: A short bat for beating clothes in washing them; -- called alsobatler, batling staff, batting staff. Shak.
blackfoot: Of or pertaining to the Blackfeet; as, a Blackfoot Indian.-- n.
bricky: Full of bricks; formed of bricks; resembling bricks or brickdust. [R.] Spenser.
bogey: A goblin; a bugbear. See Bogy.
bellow: To emit with a loud voice; to shout; -- used with out. "Wouldbellow out a laugh." Dryden.
beta rays: Penetrating rays readily deflected by a magnetic or electricfield, emitted by radioactive substances, as radium. They consist ofnegatively charged particles or electrons, apparently the same inkind as those of the cathode rays, but having much higher velocities(about 35,000 to 180,000 miles per second).
brandy: A strong alcoholic liquor distilled from wine. The name is alsogiven to spirit distilled from other liquors, and in the UnitedStates to that distilled from cider and peaches. In northern Europe,it is also applied to a spirit obtained from grain. Brandy fruit,fruit preserved in brandy and sugar.
braze: To cover or ornament with brass. Chapman.
beaver: An amphibious rodent, of the genus Castor.
bantu: A member of one of the great family of Negroid tribes occupyingequatorial and southern Africa. These tribes include, as importantdivisions, the Kafirs, Damaras, Bechuanas, and many tribes whosenames begin with Aba-, Ama-, Ba-, Ma-, Wa-, variants of the Bantuplural personal prefix Aba-, as in Ba-ntu, or Aba-ntu, itself acombination of this prefix with the syllable -ntu, a person. --Ban"tu, a.
burgage: A tenure by which houses or lands are held of the king or otherlord of a borough or city; at a certain yearly rent, or by servicesrelating to trade or handicraft. Burrill.
braille: A system of printing or writing for the blind in which thecharacters are represented by tangible points or dots. It wasinvented by Louis Braille, a French teacher of the blind.
boce: A European fish (Box vulgaris), having a compressed body andbright colors; -- called also box, and bogue.
burrel fly: The botfly or gadfly of cattle (Hypoderma bovis). See Gadfly.
black hand: A Spanish anarchistic society, many of the members of whichwere imprisoned in 1883.
busto: A bust; a statue.With some antick bustoes in the niches. Ashmole.
boilingly: With boiling or ebullition.And lakes of bitumen rise boiling higher. Byron.
bour: A chamber or a cottage. [Obs.] Chaucer.
bookbinding: The art, process, or business of binding books.
burgh: A borough or incorporated town, especially, one in Scotland.See Borough.
becquerel rays: Radiations first observed by the French physicist HenriBecquerel, in working with uranium and its compounds. They consist ofa mixture of alpha, beta, and gamma rays.
bath: A medium, as heated sand, ashes, steam, hot air, through whichheat is applied to a body.
brand goose: A species of wild goose (Branta bernicla) usually called inAmerica brant. See Brant.
byre: A cow house. [N. of Eng.& Scot.]
bairn: A child. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]Has he not well provided for the bairn ! Beau. & Fl.
beflower: To besprinkle or scatter over with, or as with, flowers.Hobbes.
binny: A large species of barbel (Barbus bynni), found in the Nile,and much esteemed for food.
bombax: A genus of trees, called also the silkcotton tree; also, a treeof the genus Bombax.
banzai: Lit., May you live ten thousand years; -- used in salutation ofthe emperor and as a battle cry. [Japan]
box kite: A kite, invented by Lawrence Hargrave, of Sydney, Australia,which consist of two light rectangular boxes, or cells open on twosides, and fastened together horizontally. Called also Hargrave, orcellular, kite.
bicarbonate: A carbonate in which but half the hydrogen of the acid isreplaced by a positive element or radical, thus making the proportionof the acid to the positive or basic portion twice what it is in thenormal carbonates; an acid carbonate; -- sometimes calledsupercarbonate.
bacillar: Shaped like a rod or staff.
balsamine: The Impatiens balsamina, or garden balsam.
barmaster: Formerly, a local judge among miners; now, an officer of thebarmote. [Eng.]
buchu: A South African shrub (Barosma) with small leaves that aredotted with oil dlands; also, the leaves themselves, which are usedin medicine for diseases of the urinary organs, etc. Several speciesfurnish the leaves.
brow: To bound to limit; to be at, or form, the edge of. [R.]Tending my flocks hard by i' the hilly crofts That brow this bottomglade. Milton.
bailie: An officer in Scotland, whose office formerly corresponded tothat of sheriff, but now corresponds to that of an English alderman.
bookkeeper: One who keeps accounts; one who has the charge of keeping thebooks and accounts in an office.
bichloride: A compound consisting of two atoms of chlorine with one or moreatoms of another element; -- called also dichloride. Bichloride ofmercury, mercuric chloride; -- sometimes called corrosive sublimate.
beach comber: A long, curling wave rolling in from the ocean. See Comber.[Amer.]
blotting paper: A kind of thick, bibulous, unsized paper, used to absorbsuperfluous ink from freshly written manuscript, and thus preventblots.
backbiting: Secret slander; detraction.Backbiting, and bearing of false witness. Piers Plowman.
buckram: A plant. See Ramson. Dr. Prior.
babyhouse: A place for children's dolls and dolls' furniture. Swift.
blink: The dazzling whiteness about the horizon caused by thereflection of light from fields of ice at sea; ice blink.
bewreke: To wreak; to avenge. [Obs.] Ld. Berners.
black flags: An organization composed originally of Chinese rebels that hadbeen driven into Tonkin by the suppression of the Taiping rebellion,but later increased by bands of pirates and adventurers. It took aprominent part in fighting the French during their hostilities withAnam, 1873-85.
bothrenchyma: Dotted or pitted ducts or vessels forming the pores seen inmany kinds of wood.
bilifuscin: A brownish green pigment found in human gallstones and in oldbile. It is a derivative of bilirubin.
bierbalk: A church road (e. g., a path across fields) for funerals.[Obs.] Homilies.
broad gauge: A wider distance between the rails than the "standard" gauge offour feet eight inches and a half. See Gauge.
bridgetree: The beam which supports the spindle socket of the runner in agrinding mill. Knight.
bolling: A tree from which the branches have been cut; a pollard.
bombyx: A genus of moths, which includes the silkworm moth. SeeSilkworm.
blameworthy: Deserving blame; culpable; reprehensible.-- Blame"wor`thi*ness, n.
blendous: Pertaining to, consisting of, or containing, blende.
biotic: Relating to life; as, the biotic principle.
boke: To poke; to thrust. [Obs. or Dial.]
belly-pinched: Pinched with hunger; starved. "The belly-pinched wolf." Shak.
bezel: The rim which encompasses and fastens a jewel or other object,as the crystal of a watch, in the cavity in which it is set.
barad: The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as aunit of pressure.
booming: The act of producing a hollow or roaring sound; a violentrushing with heavy roar; as, the booming of the sea; a deep, hollowsound; as, the booming of bitterns. Howitt.
batrachia: The order of amphibians which includes the frogs and toads; theAnura. Sometimes the word is used in a wider sense as equivalent toAmphibia.
besom: A brush of twigs for sweeping; a broom; anything which sweepsaway or destroys. [Archaic or Fig.]I will sweep it with the besom of destruction. Isa. xiv. 23.The housemaid with her besom. W. Irving.
biconvex: Convex on both sides; as, a biconvex lens.
burl: To dress or finish up (cloth); to pick knots, burs, loosethreads, etc., from, as in finishing cloth. Burling iron, a peculiarkind of nippers or tweezers used in burling woolen cloth.
boneset: A medicinal plant, the thoroughwort (Eupatorium perfoliatum).Its properties are diaphoretic and tonic.
buck fever: Intense excitement at the sight of deer or other game, such asoften unnerves a novice in hunting. [Colloq.]
betulin: A substance of a resinous nature, obtained from the outer barkof the common European birch (Betula alba), or from the tar preparedtherefrom; -- called also birch camphor. Watts.
burr: A guttural pronounciation of the letter r, produced by trillingthe extremity of the soft palate against the back part of the tongue;rotacism; -- often called the Newcastle, Northumberland, orTweedside, burr.
brickmaker: One whose occupation is to make bricks.-- Brick"mak*ing, n.
breadroot: The root of a leguminous plant (Psoralea esculenta), found nearthe Rocky Mountains. It is usually oval in form, and abounds infarinaceous matter, affording sweet and palatable food.
bondwoman: A woman who is a slave, or in bondage.He who was of the bondwoman. Gal. iv. 23.
bis: Twice; -- a word showing that something is, or is to be,repeated; as a passage of music, or an item in accounts.
boragineous: Relating to the Borage tribe; boraginaceous.
bay rum: A fragrant liquid, used for cosmetic and medicinal purposes.
burgee: A swallow-tailed flag; a distinguishing pen
bitter spar: A common name of dolomite; -- so called because it containsmagnesia, the soluble salts of which are bitter. See Dolomite.
booby: Having the characteristics of a booby; stupid.
blemishless: Without blemish; spotless.A life in all so blemishless. Feltham.
black friday: Any Friday on which a public disaster has occurred, as: InEngland, December 6, 1745, when the news of the landing of thePretender reached London, or May 11, 1866,  when a financial paniccommenced. In the United States, September 24, 1869, and September18, 1873, on which financial panics began.
bituminize: To prepare, treat, impregnate, or coat with bitumen.
branchy: Full of branches; having wide-spreading branches; consisting ofbranches.Beneath thy branchy bowers of thickest gloom. J. Scott.
bespot: To mark with spots, or as with spots.
been: The past participle of Be. In old authors it is also the pr.tense plural of Be. See 1st Bee.Assembled been a senate grave and stout. Fairfax.
bistoury: A surgical instrument consisting of a slender knife, eitherstraight or curved, generally used by introducing it beneath the partto be divided, and cutting towards the surface.
bedabble: To dabble; to sprinkle or wet. Shak.
bullirag: To intimidate by bullying; to rally contemptuously; to badger.[Low]
birectangular: Containing or having two right angles; as, a birectangularspherical triangle.
bigwig: A person of consequence; as, the bigwigs of society. [Jocose]In our youth we have heard him spoken of by the bigwigs with extremecondescension. Dickens.
bespit: To daub or soil with spittle. Johnson.
benumbed: Made torpid; numbed; stupefied; deadened; as, a benumbed bodyand mind.-- Be*numbed"ness, n.
buffalo: A species of the genus Bos or Bubalus (B. bubalus), originallyfrom India, but now found in most of the warmer countries of theeastern continent. It is larger and less docile than the common ox,and is fond of marshy places and rivers.
bridle iron: A strong flat bar of iron, so bent as to support, as in astirrup, one end of a floor timber, etc., where no sufficient bearingcan be had; -- called also stirrup and hanger.
botany bay: A harbor on the east coast of Australia, and an English convictsettlement there; -- so called from the number of new plants found onits shore at its discovery by Cook in 1770.
barrister: Counselor at law; a counsel admitted to plead at the bar, andundertake the public trial of causes, as distinguished from anattorney or solicitor. See Attorney. [Eng.]
barycentric: Of or pertaining to the center of gravity. See Barycentriccalculus, under Calculus.
blastopore: The pore or opening leading into the cavity of invagination, orarchenteron.
bleach: To make white, or whiter; to remove the color, or stains, from;to blanch; to whiten.The destruction of the coloring matters attached to the bodies to bebleached is effected either by the action of the air and light, ofchlorine, or of sulphurous acid. Ure.Immortal liberty, whose look sublime Hath bleached the tyrant's cheekin every varying clime. Smollett.
blast pipe: The exhaust pipe of a steam engine, or any pipe deliveringsteam or air, when so constructed as to cause a blast.
bloodwort: A plant, Rumex sanguineus, or bloody-veined dock. The name isapplied also to bloodroot (Sanguinaria Canadensis), and to anextensive order of plants (Hæmodoraceæ), the roots of many species ofwhich contain a red coloring matter useful in dyeing.
bliss: Orig., blithesomeness; gladness; now, the highest degree ofhappiness; blessedness; exalted felicity; heavenly joy.An then at last our bliss Full and perfect is. Milton.
bean trefoil: A leguminous shrub of southern Europe, with trifoliate leaves(Anagyris foetida).
blastocarpous: Germinating inside the pericarp, as the mangrove. Brande & C.
branchiostege: The branchiostegal membrane. See Illustration in Appendix.
bedust: To sprinkle, soil, or cover with dust. Sherwood.
balancereef: The last reef in a fore-and-aft sail, taken to steady the ship.
balaenoidea: A division of the Cetacea, including the right whale and allother whales having the mouth fringed with baleen. See Baleen.
bell-shaped: Having the shape of a widemouthed bell; campanulate.
barometz: The woolly-skinned rhizoma or rootstock of a fern (Dicksoniabarometz), which, when specially prepared and inverted, somewhatresembles a lamb; -- called also Scythian lamb.
boast: To dress, as a stone, with a broad chisel. Weale.
bestud: To set or adorn, as with studs or bosses; to set thickly; tostud; as, to bestud with stars. Milton.
bolden: To make bold; to encourage; to embolden.Ready speakers, being boldened with their present abilities to saymore, . . . use less help of diligence and study. Ascham.
ballooner: One who goes up in a balloon; an aëronaut.
buffet: To deaden the sound of (bells) by muffling the clapper.
bronchitic: Of or pertaining to bronchitis; as, bronchitic inflammation.
baggage master: One who has charge of the baggage at a railway station or upona line of public travel. [U.S.]
billot: Bullion in the bar or mass.
buff: The grayish viscid substance constituting the buffy coat. SeeBuffy coat, under Buffy, a.
bitumed: Smeared with bitumen. [R.] "The hatches caulked and bitumed."Shak.
borough-english: A custom, as in some ancient boroughs, by which lands andtenements descend to the youngest son, instead of the eldest; or, ifthe owner have no issue, to the youngest brother. Blackstone.
barn: A covered building used chiefly for storing grain, hay, andother productions of a farm. In the United States a part of the barnis often used for stables. Barn owl (Zoöl.), an owl of Europe andAmerica (Aluco flammeus, or Strix flammea), which frequents barns andother buildings.-- Barn swallow (Zoöl.), the common American swallow (Hirundohorreorum), which attaches its nest of mud to the beams and raftersof barns.
basket ball: A game, usually played indoors, in which two parties of playerscontest with each other to toss a large inflated ball into oppositegoals resembling baskets.
burgonet: A kind of helmet. [Written also burganet.] Shak.
brob: A peculiar brad-shaped spike, to be driven alongside the end ofan abutting timber to prevent its slipping.
banquette: A raised way or foot bank, running along the inside of aparapet, on which musketeers stand to fire upon the enemy.
boyishly: In a boyish manner; like a boy.
blister: To be affected with a blister or blisters; to have a blisterform on.Let my tongue blister. Shak.
buceros: A genus of large perching birds; the hornbills.
byname: To give a nickname to. Camden.
bidentate: Having two teeth or two toothlike processes; two-toothed.
barrowist: A follower of Henry Barrowe, one of the founders ofIndependency or Congregationalism in England. Barrowe was executedfor nonconformity in 1953.
blackcoat: A clergyman; -- familiarly so called, as a soldier is sometimescalled a redcoat or a bluecoat.
batter: To flatten (metal) by hammering, so as to compress it inwardlyand spread it outwardly.
bisection: Division into two parts, esp. two equal parts.
balneal: Of or pertaining to a bath. Howell.
branular: Relating to the brain; cerebral. I. Taylor.
bicipital: Dividing into two parts at one extremity; having two heads ortwo supports; as, a bicipital tree.
bryozoum: An individual zooid of a bryozoan coralline, of which there maybe two or more kinds in a single colony. The zooecia usually have awreath of tentacles around the mouth, and a well developed stomachand intestinal canal; but these parts are lacking in the other zooids(Avicularia, Ooecia, etc.).
bigha: A measure of land in India, varying from a third of an acre toan acre.
begem: To adorn with gems, or as with gems.Begemmed with dewdrops. Sir W. Scott.Those lonely realms bright garden isles begem. Shelley.
belluine: Pertaining to, or like, a beast; brutal. [R.]Animal and belluine life. Atterbury.
blacktail: A fish; the ruff or pope.
bargainor: One who makes a bargain, or contracts with another; esp., onewho sells, or contracts to sell, property to another. Blackstone.
browning: A smooth coat of brown mortar, usually the second coat, and thepreparation for the finishing coat of plaster.
baldness: The state or condition of being bald; as, baldness of the head;baldness of style.This gives to their syntax a peculiar character of simplicity andbaldness. W. D. Whitney.
boomdas: A small African hyracoid mammal (Dendrohyrax arboreus)resembling the daman.
boulangerite: A mineral of a bluish gray color and metallic luster, usuallyin plumose masses, also compact. It is sulphide of antimony and lead.
biodynamics: The doctrine of vital forces or energy.
balkingly: In manner to balk or frustrate.
bergmeal: (Min.) An earthy substance, resembling fine flour. It iscomposed of the shells of infusoria, and in Lapland and Sweden issometimes eaten, mixed with flour or ground birch bark, in times ofscarcity. This name is also given to a white powdery variety ofcalcite.
bracken: A brake or fern. Sir W. Scott.
boarding: The act of entering a ship, whether with a hostile or afriendly purpose.Both slain at one time, as they attempted the boarding of a frigate.Sir F. Drake.
brackishness: The quality or state of being brackish, or somewhat salt.
blastula: That stage in the development of the ovum in which the outercells of the morula become more defined and form the blastoderm.
blastoidea: One of the divisions of Crinoidea found fossil in paleozoicrocks; pentremites. They are so named on account of their budlikeform.
buscon: One who searches for ores; a prospector. [U.S.]
blanket: A piece of rubber, felt, or woolen cloth, used in the tympan tomake it soft and elastic.
batz: A small copper coin, with a mixture of silver, formerly currentin some parts of Germany and Switzerland. It was worth about fourcents.
bayed: Having a bay or bays. "The large bayed barn." Drayton.
binaural: Of or pertaining to, or used by, both ears.
batman: A weight used in the East, varying according to the locality;in Turkey, the greater batman is about 157 pounds, the lesser only afourth of this; at Aleppo and Smyrna, the batman is 17 pounds.Simmonds.
bevel gear: A kind of gear in which the two wheels working together lie indifferent planes, and have their teeth cut at right angles to thesurfaces of two cones whose apices coincide with the point where theaxes of the wheels would meet.
barefacedness: The quality of being barefaced; shamelessness; assurance;audaciousness.
burgess-ship: The state of privilege of a burgess. South.
behither: On this side of. [Obs.]Two miles behither Clifden. Evelyn.
badger game: The method of blackmailing by decoying a person into acompromising situation and extorting money by threats of exposure.[Cant]
biscuit: A species of white, unglazed porcelain, in which vases,figures, and groups are formed in miniature. Meat biscuit, analimentary preparation consisting of matters extracted from meat byboiling, or of meat ground fine and combined with flour, so as toform biscuits.
bulldoze: To intimidate; to restrain or coerce by intimidation orviolence; -- used originally of the intimidation of negro voters, inLouisiana. [Slang, U.S.]
blanquillo: A large fish of Florida and the W. Indies (Caulolatiluschrysops). It is red, marked with yellow.
birthdom: The land of one's birth; one's inheritance. [R.] Shak.
benjamite: A descendant of Benjamin; one of the tribe of Benjamin. Judg.iii. 15.
bespice: To season with spice, or with some spicy drug. Shak.
byssolite: An olive-green fibrous variety of hornblende.
budlet: A little bud springing from a parent bud.We have a criterion to distinguish one bud from another, or theparent bud from the numerous budlets which are its offspring. E.Darwin.
believe: To exercise belief in; to credit upon the authority ortestimony of another; to be persuaded of the truth of, upon evidencefurnished by reasons, arguments, and deductions of the mind, or bycircumstances other than personal knowledge; to regard or accept astrue; to place confidence in; to think; to consider; as, to believe aperson, a statement, or a doctrine.Our conqueror (whom I now Of force believe almighty). Milton.King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets Acts xxvi.Often followed by a dependent clause. I believe that Jesus Christ isthe Son of God. Acts viii. 37.
blowball: The downy seed head of a dandelion, which children delight toblow away. B. Jonson.
brocard: An elementary principle or maximum; a short, proverbial rule,in law, ethics, or metaphysics.The legal brocard, "Falsus in uno, falsus in omnibus," is a rule notmore applicable to other witness than to consciousness. Sir W.Hamilton.
bewilderedness: The state of being bewildered; bewilderment. [R.]
bolivian: Of or pertaining to Bolivia.-- n.
barbara: The first word in certain mnemonic lines which represent thevarious forms of the syllogism. It indicates a syllogism whose threepropositions are universal affirmatives. Whately.
belittle: To make little or less in a moral sense; to speak of in adepreciatory or contemptuous way. T. Jefferson.
brill: A fish allied to the turbot (Rhombus levis), much esteemed inEngland for food; -- called also bret, pearl, prill. See Bret.
bocal: A cylindrical glass vessel, with a large and short neck.
briskness: Liveliness; vigor in action; quickness; gayety; vivacity;effervescence.
bezoar: A calculous concretion found in the intestines of certainruminant animals (as the wild goat, the gazelle, and the Peruvianllama) formerly regarded as an unfailing antidote for poison, and acertain remedy for eruptive, pestilential, or putrid diseases. Hence:Any antidote or panacea.
biographize: To write a history of the life of. Southey.
birthwort: A genus of herbs and shrubs (Aristolochia), reputed to havemedicinal properties.
belly: The hollow part of a curved or bent timber, the convex part ofwhich is the back. Belly doublet, a doublet of the 16th century,hanging down so as to cover the belly. Shak.-- Belly fretting, the chafing of a horse's belly with a girth.Johnson.-- Belly timber, food. [Ludicrous] Prior.-- Belly worm, a worm that breeds or lives in the belly (stomach orintestines). Johnson.
bluets: A name given to several different species of plants having blueflowers, as the Houstonia coerulea, the Centaurea cyanus orbluebottle, and the Vaccinium angustifolium.
bell-mouthed: Expanding at the mouth; as, a bell-mouthed gun. Byron.
bravura: A florid, brilliant style of music, written for effect, to showthe range and flexibility of a singer's voice, or the technical forceand skill of a performer; virtuoso music. Aria di bravura ( Etym:[It.], a florid air demanding brilliant execution.
beal: A small inflammatory tumor; a pustule. [Prov. Eng.]
blackburnian warbler: A beautiful warbler of the United States (DendroicaBlackburniæ). The male is strongly marked with orange, yellow, andblack on the head and neck, and has an orange-yellow breast.
bichromatize: To combine or treat with a bichromate, esp. with bichromate ofpotassium; as, bichromatized gelatine.
backing: The preparation of the back of a book with glue, etc., beforeputting on the cover.
benefit society: A society or association formed for mutual insurance, as amongtradesmen or in labor unions, to provide for relief in sickness, oldage, and for the expenses of burial. Usually called friendly societyin Great Britain.
blent: Mingled; mixed; blended; also, polluted; stained.Rider and horse, friend, foe, in one red burial blent. Byron.
bloodroot: A plant (Sanguinaria Canadensis), with a red root and red sap,and bearing a pretty, white flower in early spring; -- called alsopuccoon, redroot, bloodwort, tetterwort, turmeric, and Indian paint.It has acrid emetic properties, and the rootstock is used as astimulant expectorant. See Sanguinaria.
basal: Relating to, or forming, the base. Basal cleavage. See underCleavage.-- Basal plane (Crystallog.), one parallel to the lateral orhorizontal axis.
beaked: Furnished with a process or a mouth like a beak; rostrate.Beaked whale (Zoöl.), a cetacean of the genus Hyperoodon; thebottlehead whale.
brook: A natural stream of water smaller than a river or creek.The Lord thy God bringeth thee into a good land, a land of brooks ofwater. Deut. viii. 7.Empires itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters.Shak.
blackberry: The fruit of several species of bramble (Rubus); also, theplant itself. Rubus fruticosus is the blackberry of England; R.villosus and R. Canadensis are the high blackberry and low blackberryof the United States. There are also other kinds.
begum: In the East Indies, a princess or lady of high rank. Malcom.
butterwort: A genus of low herbs (Pinguicula) having simple leaves whichsecrete from their glandular upper surface a viscid fluid, to whichinsects adhere, after which the margin infolds and the insects aredigested by the plant. The species are found mostly in the NorthTemperate zone.
bighorn: The Rocky Mountain sheep (Ovis or Caprovis montana).
buffle-headed: Having a large head, like a buffalo; dull; stupid; blundering.[Obs.]So fell this buffle-headed giant. Gayton.
bodian: A large food fish (Diagramma lineatum), native of the EastIndies.
biacid: Having two hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by negativeatoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of bases. See Diacid.
baptism: The act of baptizing; the application of water to a person, asa sacrament or religious ceremony, by which he is initiated into thevisible church of Christ. This is performed by immersion, sprinkling,or pouring.
blacklead: To coat or to polish with black lead.
bridestake: A stake or post set in the ground, for guests at a wedding todance round.Divide the broad bridecake Round about the bridestake. B. Jonson.
beambird: A small European flycatcher (Muscicapa gricola), so calledbecause it often nests on a beam in a building.
bidding prayer: The prayer for the souls of benefactors, said before thesermon.
biliverdin: A green pigment present in the bile, formed from bilirubin byoxidation.
butterman: A man who makes or sells butter.
bivector: A term made up of the two parts
boracite: A mineral of a white or gray color occurring massive and inisometric crystals; in composition it is a magnesium borate withmagnesium chloride.
bringer: One who brings.Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news Hath but a losing office.Shak.Bringer in, one who, or that which, introduces.
barbed: Accoutered with defensive armor; -- said of a horse. See Barded( which is the proper form.) Sir W. Raleigh.
bass: ; pl. Bass, and sometimes Basses. Etym: [A corruption ofbarse.] (Zoöl.)
brocket: A male red deer two years old; -- sometimes called brock.
bottle: To put into bottles; to inclose in, or as in, a bottle orbottles; to keep or restrain as in a bottle; as, to bottle wine orporter; to bottle up one's wrath.
bow-bells: The bells of Bow Church in London; cockneydom.People born within the sound of Bow-bells are usually calledcockneys. Murray's Handbook of London.
benefactress: A woman who confers a benefit.His benefactress blushes at the deed. Cowper.
blindage: A cover or protection for an advanced trench or approach,formed of fascines and earth supported by a framework.
bab: Lit., gate; -- a title given to the founder of Babism, andtaken from that of Bab-ud-Din, assumed by him.
box-iron: A hollow smoothing iron containing a heater within.
brutely: In a rude or violent manner.
batrachoid: Froglike. Specifically: Of or pertaining to the Batrachidæ, afamily of marine fishes, including the toadfish. Some have poisonousdorsal spines.
backlash: The distance through which one part of connected machinery, asa wheel, piston, or screw, can be moved without moving the connectedparts, resulting from looseness in fitting or from wear; also, thejarring or reflex motion caused in badly fitting machinery byirregularities in velocity or a reverse of motion.
blowze: A ruddy, fat-faced woman; a wench. [Obs.] Shak.
beneficent: , a. Doing or producing good; performing acts of kindness andcharity; characterized by beneficence.The beneficent fruits of Christianity. Prescott.
binary: Compounded or consisting of two things or parts; characterizedby two (things). Binary arithmetic, that in which numbers areexpressed according to the binary scale, or in which two figuresonly, 0 and 1, are used, in lieu of ten; the cipher multiplyingeverything by two, as in common arithmetic by ten. Thus, 1 is one; 10is two; 11 is three; 100 is four, etc. Davies & Peck.-- Binary compound (Chem.), a compound of two elements, or of anelement and a compound performing the function of an element, or oftwo compounds performing the function of elements.-- Binary logarithms, a system of logarithms devised by Euler forfacilitating musical calculations, in which 1 is logarithm of 2,instead of 10, as in the common logarithms, and the modulus 1.442695instead of .43429448.-- Binary measure (Mus.), measure divisible by two or four; commontime.-- Binary nomenclature (Nat. Hist.), nomenclature in which the namesdesignate both genus and species.-- Binary scale (Arith.), a uniform scale of notation whose ratio istwo.-- Binary star (Astron.), a double star whose members have arevolution round their common center of gravity.-- Binary theory (Chem.), the theory that all chemical compoundsconsist of two constituents of opposite and unlike qualities.
bravo: A daring villain; a bandit; one who sets law at defiance; aprofessional assassin or murderer.Safe from detection, seize the unwary prey. And stab, like bravoes,all who come this way. Churchill.
bullet-proof: Capable of resisting the force of a bullet. Bullet tree. SeeBully tree.-- Bullet wood, the wood of the bullet tree.
buzz: To make a low, continuous, humming or sibilant sound, like thatmade by bees with their wings. Hence: To utter a murmuring sound; tospeak with a low, humming voice.Like a wasp is buzzed, and stung him. Longfellow.However these disturbers of our peace Buzz in the people's ears.Shak.
bournonite: A mineral of a steel-gray to black color and metallic luster,occurring crystallized, often in twin crystals shaped like cogwheels(wheel ore), also massive. It is a sulphide of antimony, lead, andcopper.
binoxalate: A salt having two equivalents of oxalic acid to one of thebase; an acid oxalate.
bribeless: Incapable of being bribed; free from bribes.From thence to heaven's bribeless hall. Sir W. Raleigh.
bookstore: A store where books are kept for sale; -- called in England abookseller's shop.
buck: To break up or pulverize, as ores.
befrill: To furnish or deck with a frill.
brelan carre: In French games, a double pair royal.
boustrophedon: An ancient mode of writing, in alternate directions, one linefrom left to right, and the next from right to left (as fields areplowed), as in early Greek and Hittite.
boston: A game at cards, played by four persons, with two packs offifty-two cards each; -- said to be so called from Boston,Massachusetts, and to have been invented by officers of the Frencharmy in America during the Revolutionary war.
bimaculate: Having, or marked with, two spots.
branchiura: A group of Entomostraca, with suctorial mouths, includingspecies parasitic on fishes, as the carp lice (Argulus).
boanerges: Any declamatory and vociferous preacher or orator.
browed: Having (such) a brow; -- used in composition; as, dark-browed,stern-browed.
battailant: Prepared for battle; combatant; warlike. Spenser.-- n.
bronchial: Belonging to the bronchi and their ramifications in the lungs.Bronchial arteries, branches of the descending aorta, accompanyingthe bronchia in all their ramifications.-- Bronchial cells, the air cells terminating the bronchia.-- Bronchial glands, glands whose functions are unknown, seatedalong the bronchia.-- Bronchial membrane, the mucous membrane lining the bronchia.-- Bronchial tube, the bronchi, or the bronchia.
bioscope: A view of life; that which gives such a view.
behalf: Advantage; favor; stead; benefit; interest; profit; support;defense; vindication.In behalf of his mistress's beauty. Sir P. Sidney.Against whom he had contracted some prejudice in behalf of hisnation. Clarendon.In behalf of, in the interest of.-- On behalf of, on account of; on the part of.
bonesetter: One who sets broken or dislocated bones; -- commonly applied toone, not a regular surgeon, who makes an occupation of setting bones.-- Bone"set*ting, n.
berylloid: A solid consisting of a double twelve-sided pyramid; -- socalled because the planes of this form occur on crystals of beryl.
bimolecular: Pertaining to, or formed from, two molecules; as, a bimolecularreaction (a reaction between two molecules).
bear state: Arkansas; -- a nickname, from the many bears once inhabitingits forests.
by-bidder: One who bids at an auction in behalf of the auctioneer orowner, for the purpose of running up the price of articles. [U.S.]
benthos: The bottom of the sea, esp. of the deep oceans; hence (Bot. &Zoöl.), the fauna and flora of the sea bottom; -- opposed toplankton.
boshvark: The bush hog. See under Bush, a thicket.
boxhaul: To put (a vessel) on the other tack by veering her short roundon her heel; -- so called from the circumstance of bracing the headyards abox (i. e., sharp aback, on the wind). Totten.
backsliding: Slipping back; falling back into sin or error; sinning.Turn, O backsliding children, saith the Lord. Jer. iii. 14.
brother-in-law: The brother of one's husband or wife; also, the husband ofone's sister; sometimes, the husband of one's wife's sister.
barth: A place of shelter for cattle. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
blockish: Like a block; deficient in understanding; stupid; dull."Blockish Ajax." Shak.-- Block"ish*ly, adv.-- Block"ish*ness, n.
bass viol: A stringed instrument of the viol family, used for playingbass. See 3d Bass, n., and Violoncello.
barred owl: A large American owl (Syrnium nebulosum); -- so called from thetransverse bars of a dark brown color on the breast.
bolting: A darting away; a starting off or aside.
blea: The part of a tree which lies immediately under the bark; thealburnum or sapwood.
barry: , Divided into bars; -- said of the field.
bolter: One who bolts; esp.: (a) A horse which starts suddenly aside.(b) A man who breaks away from his party.
bulbul: The Persian nightingale (Pycnonotus jocosus). The name is alsoapplied to several other Asiatic singing birds, of the familyTimaliidæ. The green bulbuls belong to the Chloropsis and alliedgenera. [Written also buhlbuhl.]
baken: p. p. of Bake. [Obs. or. Archaic]
beneficial: Receiving, or entitled to have or receive, advantage, use, orbenefit; as, the beneficial owner of an estate. Kent.
becuna: A fish of the Mediterranean (Sphyræna spet). See Barracuda.
by-respect: Private end or view; by-interest. [Obs.] Dryden.
barrel process: A process of extracting gold or silver by treating the ore in arevolving barrel, or drum, with mercury, chlorine, cyanide solution,or other reagent.
brog: A pointed instrument, as a joiner's awl, a brad awl, a needle,or a small ship stick.
bing: A heap or pile; as, a bing of wood. "Potato bings." Burns. "Abing of corn." Surrey. [Obs. or Dial. Eng. & Scot.]
bachelorhood: The state or condition of being a bachelor; bachelorship.
beau monde: The fashionable world; people of fashion and gayety. Prior.
bovey coal: A kind of mineral coal, or brown lignite, burning with a weakflame, and generally a disagreeable odor; -- found at Bovey Tracey,Devonshire, England. It is of geological age of the oölite, and notof the true coal era.
busky: See Bosky, and 1st Bush, n. Shak.
bifoliolate: Having two leaflets, as some compound leaves.
beluga: A cetacean allied to the dolphins.
brooklime: A plant (Veronica Beccabunga), with flowers, usually blue, inaxillary racemes. The American species is V. Americana. [Formerlywritten broklempe or broklympe.]
boilery: A place and apparatus for boiling, as for evaporating brine insalt making.
begone: Go away; depart; get you gone.
brazilian: Of or pertaining to Brasil.-- n.
