botargo: A sort of cake or sausage, made of the salted roes of themullet, much used on the coast of the Mediterranean as an incentiveto drink.
bardship: The state of being a bard.
beseechment: The act of beseeching or entreating earnestly. [R.] Goodwin.
barse: The common perch. See 1st Bass. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
blackbird: In England, a species of thrush (Turdus merula), a singing birdwith a fin note; the merle. In America the name is given to severalbirds, as the Quiscalus versicolor, or crow blackbird; the Agelæusphoeniceus, or red-winged blackbird; the cowbird; the rusty grackle,etc. See Redwing.
brike: A breach; ruin; downfall; peril. [Obs.] Chaucer.
bootmaker: One who makes boots.-- Boot"mak`ing, n.
blenheim spaniel: A small variety of spaniel, kept as a pet.
bob wig: A short wig with bobs or short curls; -- called also bobtailwig. Spectator.
babillard: The lesser whitethroat of Europe; -- called also babblingwarbler.
booted: Having an undivided, horny, bootlike covering; -- said of thetarsus of some birds.
betterment: An improvement of an estate which renders it better than mererepairing would do; -- generally used in the plural. [U. S.] Bouvier.
beaufet: A niche, cupboard, or sideboard for plate, china, glass, etc.;a buffet.A beaufet . . . filled with gold and silver vessels. Prescott.
book-learned: Versed in books; having knowledge derived from books. [Often ina disparaging sense.]Whate'er these book-learned blockheads say, Solon's the veriest foolin all the play. Dryden.
boxkeeper: An attendant at a theater who has charge of the boxes.
bracket: An architectural member, plain or ornamental, projecting from awall or pier, to support weight falling outside of the same; also, adecorative feature seeming to discharge such an office.
brachydiagonal: Pertaining to the shorter diagonal, as of a rhombic prism.Brachydiagonal axis, the shorter lateral axis of an orthorhombiccrystal.
bathing: Act of taking a bath or baths. Bathing machine, a small room onwheels, to be driven into the water, for the convenience of bathers,who undress and dress therein.
basic slag: A by-product from the manufacture of steel by the basicprocess, used as a fertilizer. It is rich in lime and contains 14 to20 per cent of phosphoric acid. Called also Thomas slag, phosphaticslag, and odorless phosphate.
bisulcate: Cloven; said of a foot or hoof.
bunting: A bird of the genus Emberiza, or of an allied genus, related tothe finches and sparrows (family Fringillidæ).
beneficialness: The quality of being beneficial; profitableness.
blarney: Smooth, wheedling talk; flattery. [Colloq.] Blarney stone, astone in Blarney castle, Ireland, said to make those who kiss itproficient in the use of blarney.
buffoonery: The arts and practices of a buffoon, as low jests, ridiculouspranks, vulgar tricks and postures.Nor that it will ever constitute a wit to conclude a tart piece ofbuffoonery with a "What makes you blush" Spectator.
burry: Abounding in burs, or containing burs; resembling burs; as,burry wool.
battering train: A train of artillery for siege operations.
bunch: A small isolated mass of ore, as distinguished from acontinuous vein. Page.
bimarginate: Having a double margin, as certain shells.
bloat: To grow turgid as by effusion of liquid in the cellular tissue;to puff out; to swell. Arbuthnot.
brickfielder: Orig., at Sydney, a cold and violent south or southwest wind,rising suddenly, and regularly preceded by a hot wind from the north;-- now usually called southerly buster. It blew across theBrickfields, formerly so called, a district of Sydney, and carriedclouds of dust into the city.
bean: A name given to the seed of certain leguminous herbs, chieflyof the genera Faba, Phaseolus, and Dolichos; also, to the herbs.
bombproof: Secure against the explosive force of bombs.-- n.
bloodstick: A piece of hard wood loaded at one end with lead, and used tostrike the fleam into the vein. Youatt.
berycoid: Of or pertaining to the Berycidæ, a family of marine fishes.
bonnet rouge: The red cap adopted by the extremists in the French Revolution,which became a sign of patriotism at that epoch; hence, arevolutionist; a Red Republican.
brelan favori: In French games, a pair royal composed of 2 cards in the handand the card turned.
bolide: A kind of meteor; a bolis.
butterfish: A name given to several different fishes, in allusion to theirslippery coating of mucus, as the Stromateus triacanthus of theAtlantic coast, the Epinephelus punctatus of the southern coast, therock eel, and the kelpfish of New Zealand.
better: To become better; to improve. Carlyle.
birthright: Any right, privilege, or possession to which a person isentitled by birth, such as an estate descendible by law to an heir,or civil liberty under a free constitution; esp. the rights orinheritance of the first born.Lest there be any . . . profane person, as Esau, who for one morselof meat sold his birthright. Heb. xii. 16.
bermuda grass: A kind of grass (Cynodon Dactylon) esteemed for pasture in theSouthern United States. It is a native of Southern Europe, but is nowwide-spread in warm countries; -- called also scutch grass, and inBermuda, devil grass.
bedswerver: One who swerves from and is unfaithful to the marriage vow.[Poetic] Shak.
billabong: In Australia, a blind channel leading out from a river; --sometimes called an anabranch. This is the sense of the word as usedin the Public Works Department; but the term has also been locallyapplied to mere back-waters forming stagnant pools and to certainwater channels arising from a source.
battery: The unlawful beating of another. It includes every willful,angry and violent, or negligent touching of another's person orclothes, or anything attached to his person or held by him.
bipeltate: Having a shell or covering like a double shield.
bean caper: A deciduous plant of warm climates, generally with fleshyleaves and flowers of a yellow or whitish yellow color, of the genusZygophyllum.
blacklist: To put in a black list as deserving of suspicion, censure, orpunishment; esp. to put in a list of persons stigmatized as insolventor untrustworthy, -- as tradesmen and employers do for mutualprotection; as, to blacklist a workman who has been discharged. SeeBlack list, under Black, a.If you blacklist us, we will boycott you. John Swinton.
business: The position, distribution, and order of persons and propertieson the stage of a theater, as determined by the stage manager inrehearsal.
baffler: One who, or that which, baffles.
billage: and v. t. & i. Same as Bilge.
burton: A peculiar tackle, formed of two or more blocks, or pulleys,the weight being suspended of a hook block in the bight of therunning part.
burdock: A genus of coarse biennial herbs (Lappa), bearing small burswhich adhere tenaciously to clothes, or to the fur or wool ofanimals.
bonnet: An additional piece of canvas laced to the foot of a jib orforesail in moderate winds. Hakluyt.
barometry: The art or process of making barometrical measurements.
bacchanalia: A feast or an orgy in honor of Bacchus.
brettice: The wooden boarding used in supporting the roofs and walls ofcoal mines. See Brattice.
bemeet: To meet. [Obs.]Our very loving sister, well bemet. Shak.
by-election: An election held by itself, not at the time of a generalelection.
bactrian: Of or pertaining to Bactria in Asia.-- n.
baconian: Of or pertaining to Lord Bacon, or to his system of philosophy.Baconian method, the inductive method. See Induction.
barroom: A room containing a bar or counter at which liquors are sold.
bossism: The rule or practices of bosses, esp. political bosses. [Slang,U. S.]
broomy: Of or pertaining to broom; overgrowing with broom; resemblingbroom or a broom.If land grow mossy or broomy. Mortimer.
brambling: The European mountain finch (Fringilla montifringilla); --called also bramble finch and bramble.
blackly: In a black manner; darkly, in color; gloomily; threateningly;atrociously. "Deeds so blackly grim and horrid." Feltham.
biquintile: An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each otherby twice the fifth part of a great circle -- that is, twice 72degrees.
benefiter: One who confers a benefit; -- also, one who receives a benefit.
brilliant: The small size of type used in England printing.
blastosphere: The hollow globe or sphere formed by the arrangement of theblastomeres on the periphery of an impregnated ovum.
bullen-nail: A nail with a round head and short shank, tinned and lacquered.
biuret: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, C2O2N3H5, formedby heating urea. It is intermediate between urea and cyanuric acid.
boomslange: A large South African tree snake (Bucephalus Capensis).Although considered venomous by natives, it has no poison fangs.
bisilicate: A salt of metasilicic acid; -- so called because the ratio ofthe oxygen of the silica to the oxygen of the base is as two to one.The bisilicates include many of the most common and importantminerals.
borrel: Ignorant, unlearned; belonging to the laity. [Obs.] Chaucer.
by-pass: A by-passage, for a pipe, or other channel, to divertcirculation from the usual course.
bursch: A youth; especially, a student in a german university.
bowwow: An onomatopoetic name for a dog or its bark.-- a.
blindness: State or condition of being blind, literally or figuratively.Darwin. Color blindness, inability to distinguish certain color. SeeDaltonism.
beefy: Having much beef; of the nature of beef; resembling beef;fleshy.
blackmailing: The act or practice of extorting money by exciting fears ofinjury other than bodily harm, as injury to reputation.
bandle: An Irish measure of two feet in length.
bollandists: The Jesuit editors of the "Acta Sanctorum", or Lives of theSaints; -- named from John Bolland, who began the work.
brant-fox: A kind of fox found in Sweden (Vulpes alopex), smaller than thecommon fox (V. vulgaris), but probably a variety of it.
booser: A toper; a guzzler. See Boozer.
besit: To suit; to fit; to become. [Obs.]
bungarum: A venomous snake of India, of the genus Bungarus, allied to thecobras, but without a hood.
brackish: Saltish, or salt in a moderate degree, as water in saline soil.Springs in deserts found seem sweet, all brackish though they be.Byron.
blend: To mingle; to mix; to unite intimately; to pass or shadeinsensibly into each other, as colors.There is a tone of solemn and sacred feeling that blends with ourconviviality. Irving.
blastoderm: The germinal membrane in an ovum, from which the embryo isdeveloped.
bookman: A studious man; a scholar. Shak.
bagging: Reaping peas, beans, wheat, etc., with a chopping stroke.[Eng.]
botocudos: A Brazilian tribe of Indians, noted for their use of poisons; -- also called Aymborés.
balk: One of the beams connecting the successive supports of atrestle bridge or bateau bridge.
backer: One who, or that which, backs; especially one who backs aperson or thing in a contest.
burdensome: Grievous to be borne; causing uneasiness or fatigue;oppressive.The debt immense of endless gratitude So burdensome. Milton.
basutos: A warlike South African people of the Bantu stock, divided intomany tribes, subject to the English. They formerly practicedcannibalism, but have now adopted many European customs.
bogie: A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around avertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railwaytrack.
bouge: To stave in; to bilge. [Obs.] Holland.
bos: A genus of ruminant quadrupeds, including the wild and domesticcattle, distinguished by a stout body, hollow horns, and a large foldof skin hanging from the neck.
befall: To happen to.I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me.Shak.
brainless: Without understanding; silly; thougthless; witless.-- Brain"less*ness, n.
boughten: Purchased; not obtained or produced at home. Coleridge.
big: Barley, especially the hardy four-rowed kind."Bear interchanges in local use, now with barley, now with bigg." NewEnglish Dict.
balloonry: The art or practice of ascending in a balloon; aëronautics.
brougham: A light, close carriage, with seats inside for two or four, andthe fore wheels so arranged as to turn short.
bluffness: The quality or state of being bluff.
burghbote: A contribution toward the building or repairing of castles orwalls for the defense of a city or town.
botuliform: Having the shape of a sausage. Henslow.
breech sight: A device attached to the breech of a firearm, to guide the eye,in conjunction with the front sight, in taking aim.
barberry: A shrub of the genus Berberis, common along roadsides and inneglected fields. B. vulgaris is the species best known; its oblongred berries are made into a preserve or sauce, and have been deemedefficacious in fluxes and fevers. The bark dyes a fine yellow, esp.the bark of the root. [Also spelt berberry.]
bittern: A wading bird of the genus Botaurus, allied to the herons, ofvarious species.
buttonwood: The Platanus occidentalis, or American plane tree, a largetree, producing rough balls, from which it is named; -- called alsobuttonball tree, and, in some parts of the United States, sycamore.The California buttonwood is P. racemosa.
bandit: An outlaw; a brigand.No savage fierce, bandit, or mountaineer. Milton.
bethump: To beat or thump soundly. Shak.
brewage: Malt liquor; drink brewed. "Some well-spiced brewage." Milton.A rich brewage, made of the best Spanish wine. Macaulay.
busby: A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is offur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment,hanging from the top over the right shoulder.
begohm: A unit of resistance equal to one billion ohms, or one thousandmegohms.
banderilla: A barbed dart carrying a banderole which the banderillerothrusts into the neck or shoulder of the bull in a bullfight.
bombazine: A twilled fabric for dresses, of which the warp is silk, andthe weft worsted. Black bombazine has been much used for mourninggarments. [Sometimes spelt bombasin, and bombasine.] Tomlinson.
bee: p. p. of Be; -- used for been. [Obs.] Spenser.
brookite: A mineral consisting of titanic oxide, and hence identical withrutile and octahedrite in composition, but crystallizing in theorthorhombic system.
boulevardier: A frequenter of a city boulevard, esp. in Paris.  F. Harrison.
binal: Twofold; double. [R.] "Binal revenge, all this." Ford.
broncho: A native or a Mexican horse of small size. [Western U.S.]
blessedness: The state of being blessed; happiness; felicity; bliss;heavenly joys; the favor of God.The assurance of a future blessedness. Tillotson.Single blessedness, the unmarried state. "Grows, lives, and dies insingle blessedness." Shak.
biternate: Doubly ternate, as when a petiole has three ternate leaflets.-- Bi*ter"nate*ly, adv. Gray.
bruin: A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.
basset: A game at cards, resembling the modern faro, said to have beeninvented at Venice.Some dress, some dance, some play, not to forget Your piquet parties,and your dear basset. Rowe.
boud: A weevil; a worm that breeds in malt, biscuit, etc. [Obs.]Tusser., n. Etym: [F., fr. bouder to pout, be sulky.]
bimuscular: Having two adductor muscles, as a bivalve mollusk.
bicker: A small wooden vessel made of staves and hoops, like a tub.[Prov. Eng.]
bubonic: Of or pertaining to a bubo or buboes; characterized by buboes.
bemoil: To soil or encumber with mire and dirt. [Obs.] Shak.
broadleaf: A tree (Terminalia latifolia) of Jamaica, the wood of which isused for boards, scantling, shingles, etc; -- sometimes called thealmond tree, from the shape of its fruit.
barology: The science of weight or gravity.
beprose: To reduce to prose. [R.] "To beprose all rhyme." Mallet.
bourbonism: The principles of those adhering to the house of Bourbon;obstinate conservatism.
barter: To traffic or trade, by exchanging one commodity for another,in distinction from a sale and purchase, in which money is paid forthe commodities transferred; to truck.
bolection: A projecting molding round a panel. Same as Bilection. Gwilt.
basin: An isolated or circumscribed formation, particularly where thestrata dip inward, on all sides, toward a center; -- especiallyapplied to the coal formations, called coal basins or coal fields.
buffy: Resembling, or characterized by, buff. Buffy coat, thecoagulated plasma of blood when the red corpuscles have so settledout that the coagulum appears nearly colorless. This is common indiseased conditions where the corpuscles run together more rapidlyand in denser masses than usual. Huxley.
butteris: A steel cutting instrument, with a long bent shank set in ahandle which rests against the shoulder of the operator. It isoperated by a thrust movement, and used in paring the hoofs ofhorses.
bothersome: Vexatious; causing bother; causing trouble or perplexity;troublesome.
babery: Finery of a kind to please a child. [Obs.] "Painted babery."Sir P. Sidney.
bizarre: Odd in manner or appearance; fantastic; whimsical; extravagant;grotesque. C. Kingsley.
birk: A birch tree. [Prov. Eng.] "The silver birk." Tennyson.
blatant: Bellowing, as a calf; bawling; brawling; clamoring;disagreeably clamorous; sounding loudly and harshly. "Harsh andblatant tone." R. H. Dana.A monster, which the blatant beast men call. Spenser.Glory, that blatant word, which haunts some military minds like thebray of the trumpet. W. Irving.
beriberi: An acute disease occurring in India, characterized by multipleinflammatory changes in the nerves, producing great musculardebility, a painful rigidity of the limbs, and cachexy.
brasque: A paste made by mixing powdered charcoal, coal, or coke withclay, molasses, tar, or other suitable substance. It is used forlining hearths, crucibles, etc. Called also steep.
brooch: A painting all of one color, as a sepia painting, or an Indiapainting.
bullition: The action of boiling; boiling. [Obs.] See Ebullition. Bacon.
bicycle: A light vehicle having two wheels one behind the other. It hasa saddle seat and is propelled by the rider's feet acting on cranksor levers.
blackguardly: In the manner of or resembling a blackguard; abusive;scurrilous; ruffianly.
bacchant: Bacchanalian; fond of drunken revelry; wine-loving; reveling;carousing. Byron.
buccal: Of or pertaining to the mouth or cheeks.
birken: To whip with a birch or rod. [Obs.]
bojanus organ: A glandular organ of bivalve mollusca, serving in part as akidney.
brin: One of the radiating sticks of a fan. The outermost are largerand longer, and are called panaches. Knight.
bruit: An abnormal sound of several kinds, heard on auscultation.
bascinet: A light helmet, at first open, but later made with a visor.[Written also basinet, bassinet, basnet.]
bilocation: Double location; the state or power of being in two places atthe same instant; -- a miraculous power attributed to some of thesaints. Tylor.
brachiopod: One of the Brachiopoda, or its shell.
belute: To bespatter, as with mud. [R.] Sterne.
bahar: A weight used in certain parts of the East Indies, varyingconsiderably in different localities, the range being from 223 to 625pounds.
belong: To be deserved by. [Obs.]More evils belong us than happen to us. B. Jonson.
bow-saw: A saw with a thin or narrow blade set in a strong frame.
bilestone: A gallstone, or biliary calculus. See Biliary. E. Darwin.
bombastry: Swelling words without much meaning; bombastic language;fustian.Bombastry and buffoonery, by nature lofty and light, soar highest ofall. Swift.
baker-legged: Having legs that bend inward at the knees.
beam: A heavy iron lever having an oscillating motion on a centralaxis, one end of which is connected with the piston rod from which itreceives motion, and the other with the crank of the wheel shaft; --called also working beam or walking beam.
beg: A title of honor in Turkey and in some other parts of the East;a bey.
boletus: A genus of fungi having the under side of the pileus or capcomposed of a multitude of fine separate tubes. A few are edible, andothers very poisonous.
bryology: That part of botany which relates to mosses.
benison: Blessing; beatitude; benediction. Shak.More precious than the benison of friends. Talfourd.
bdellomorpha: An order of Nemertina, including the large leechlike worms(Malacobdella) often parasitic in clams.
black spanish: One of an old and well-known Mediterranean breed of domesticfowls with glossy black plumage, blue legs and feet, bright red comband wattles, and white face. They are remarkable as egg layers.
blue-eyed grass: a grasslike plant (Sisyrinchium anceps), with small flowers ofa delicate blue color.
blastocoele: The cavity of the blastosphere, or segmentation cavity.
broadcast: A casting or throwing seed in all directions, as from the handin sowing.
bobbish: Hearty; in good spirits. [Low, Eng.] Dickens.
backwoodsman: A men living in the forest in or beyond the new settlements,especially on the western frontiers of the older portions of theUnited States. Fisher Ames.
birthday: Of or pertaining to the day of birth, or its anniversary; as,birthday gifts or festivities.
braggart: A boaster.O, I could play the woman with mine eyes, And braggart with mytongue. Shak.
box tail: In a flying machine, a tail or rudder, usually fixed,resembling a box kite.
basketry: The art of making baskets; also, baskets, taken collectively.
blae: Dark blue or bluish gray; lead-colored. [Scot.]
behead: To sever the head from; to take off the head of.
betrothal: The act of betrothing, or the fact of being betrothed; a mutualpromise, engagement, or contract for a future marriage between thepersons betrothed; betrothment; affiance. "The feast of betrothal."Longfellow.
brazen: To carry through impudently or shamelessly; as, to brazen thematter through.Sabina brazened it out before Mrs. Wygram, but inwardly she wasresolved to be a good deal more circumspect. W. Black.
bruise: To fight with the fists; to box.Bruising was considered a fine, manly, old English custom. Thackeray.
batten: To grow fat; to grow fat in ease and luxury; to glut one'sself. Dryden.The pampered monarch lay battening in ease. Garth.Skeptics, with a taste for carrion, who batten on the hideous factsin history, -- persecutions, inquisitions. Emerson.
broiling: Excessively hot; as, a broiling sun.-- n.
brachypteres: A group of birds, including auks, divers, and penguins.
brusher: One who, or that which, brushes.
banteng: The wild ox of Java (Bibos Banteng).
bosporian: Of or pertaining to the Thracian or the Cimmerian Bosporus.The Alans forced the Bosporian kings to pay them tribute andexterminated the Taurians. Tooke.
bleachery: A place or an establishment where bleaching is done.
broad church: A portion of the Church of England, consisting of persons whoclaim to hold a position, in respect to doctrine and fellowship,intermediate between the High Church party and the Low Church, orevangelical, party. The term has been applied to otherbodies of menholding liberal or comprehensive views of Christian doctrine andfellowship.Side by side with these various shades of High and Low Church,another party of a different character has always existed in theChurch of England. It is called by different names: Moderate,Catholic, or Broad Church, by its friends; Latitudinarian orIndifferent, by its enemies. Its distinctive character is the desireof comprehension. Its watch words are charity and toleration.Conybeare.
bellyband: A band of canvas, to strengthen a sail.
bleat: To make the noise of, or one like that of, a sheep; to cry likea sheep or calf.Then suddenly was heard along the main, To low the ox, to bleat thewoolly train. PopeThe ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baas, will never answer acalf when he bleats. Shak.
bourse: An exchange, or place where merchants, bankers, etc., meet forbusiness at certain hours; esp., the Stock Exchange of Paris.
breechcloth: A cloth worn around the breech.
bosomy: Characterized by recesses or sheltered hollows.
baneberry: A genus (Actæa) of plants, of the order Ranunculaceæ, native inthe north temperate zone. The red or white berries are poisonous.
best: Utmost; highest endeavor or state; most nearly perfect thing,or being, or action; as, to do one's best; to the best of ourability. At best, in the utmost degree or extent applicable to thecase; under the most favorable circumstances; as, life is at bestvery short.-- For best, finally. [Obs.] "Those constitutions . . . are nowestablished for best, and not to be mended." Milton.-- To get the best of, to gain an advantage over, whether fairly orunfairly.-- To make the best of. (a) To improve to the utmost; to use ordispose of to the greatest advantage. "Let there be freedom to carrytheir commodities where they can make the best of them." Bacon. (b)To reduce to the least possible inconvenience; as, to make the bestof ill fortune or a bad bargain.
bere: , v. t. Etym: [Cf. OIcel. berja to strike.] To pierce. [Obs.]Chaucer.
bailiwick: The precincts within which a bailiff has jurisdiction; thelimits of a bailiff's authority.
brownwort: A species of figwort or Scrophularia (S. vernalis), and otherspecies of the same genus, mostly perennials with inconspicuouscoarse flowers.
blusterer: One who, or that which, blusters; a noisy swaggerer.
bedight: To bedeck; to array or equip; to adorn. [Archaic] Milton.
bifold: Twofold; double; of two kinds, degrees, etc. Shak.
bunter: A woman who picks up rags in the streets; hence, a low, vulgarwoman. [Cant]Her . . . daughters, like bunters in stuff gowns. Goldsmith.
bowling: The act of playing at or rolling bowls, or of rolling the ballat cricket; the game of bowls or of tenpins. Bowling alley, a coveredplace for playing at bowls or tenpins.-- Bowling green, a level piece of greensward or smooth ground forbowling, as the small park in lower Broadway, New York, where theDutch of New Amsterdam played this game.
brained: Supplied with brains.If th' other two be brained like us. Shak.
blinker: A kind of goggles, used to protect the eyes form glare, etc.
bateful: Exciting contention; contentious. [Obs.] "It did batefulquestion frame. " Sidney.
breasthook: A thick piece of timber in the form of a knee, placed acrossthe stem of a ship to strengthen the fore part and unite the bows oneach side. Totten.
binominal: Of or pertaining to two names; binomial.
bedew: To moisten with dew, or as with dew. "Falling tears his facebedew." Dryden.
balsa: A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of SouthAmerica.
biseptate: With two partitions or septa. Gray.
blesbok: A South African antelope (Alcelaphus albifrons), having a largewhite spot on the forehead.
beneficently: In a beneficent manner; with beneficence.
bachelorship: The state of being a bachelor.
biting in: The process of corroding or eating into metallic plates, bymeans of an acid. See Etch. G. Francis.
bloodbird: An Australian honeysucker (Myzomela sanguineolata); -- socalled from the bright red color of the male bird.
bibulously: In a bibulous manner; with profuse imbibition or absorption. DeQuincey.
bantling: A young or small child; an infant. [Slightly contemptuous ordepreciatory.]In what out of the way corners genius produces her bantlings. W.Irving.
bloody sweat: A sweat accompanied by a discharge of blood; a disease, calledsweating sickness, formerly prevalent in England and other countries.
bypath: A private path; an obscure way; indirect means.God known, my son, By what bypaths, and indirect crooked ways, I metthis crown. Shak.
ballotin: An officer who has charge of a ballot box. [Obs.] Harrington.
brahmoism: The religious system of Brahmo-somaj. Balfour.
befringe: To furnish with a fringe; to form a fringe upon; to adorn aswith fringe. Fuller.
bestick: To stick over, as with sharp points pressed in; to mark byinfixing points or spots here and there; to pierce.Truth shall retire Bestuck with slanderous darts. Milton.
baromacrometer: An instrument for ascertaining the weight and length of anewborn infant.
bamboo: A plant of the family of grasses, and genus Bambusa, growing intropical countries.
bident: An instrument or weapon with two prongs.
bootee: A half boot or short boot.
blitheness: The state of being blithe. Chaucer.
beckon: To make a significant sign to; hence, to summon, as by a motionof the hand.His distant friends, he beckons near. Dryden.It beckons you to go away with it. Shak.
blast lamp: A lamp provided with some arrangement for intensifyingcombustion by means of a blast.
blore: The act of blowing; a roaring wind; a blast. [Obs.]A most tempestuous blore. Chapman.
barrigudo: A large, dark-colored, South American monkey, of the genusLagothrix, having a long prehensile tail.
boozer: One who boozes; a toper; a guzzler of alcoholic liquors; abouser.
bullionist: An advocate for a metallic currency, or a paper currency alwaysconvertible into gold.
blab: To utter or tell unnecessarily, or in a thoughtless manner; topublish (secrets or trifles) without reserve or discretion. Udall.And yonder a vile physician blabbing The case of his patient.Tennyson.
braccate: Furnished with feathers which conceal the feet.
butylene: Any one of three metameric hydrocarbons, C4H8, of the ethyleneseries. They are gaseous or easily liquefiable.
barber: One whose occupation it is to shave or trim the beard, and tocut and dress the hair of his patrons. Barber's itch. See under Itch.
bubale: A large antelope (Alcelaphus bubalis) of Egypt and the Desertof Sahara, supposed by some to be the fallow deer of the Bible.
bisaccate: Having two little bags, sacs, or pouches.
boohoe: To bawl; to cry loudly. [Low] Bartlett.
brucine: A poweful vegetable alkaloid, found, associated withstrychnine, in the seeds of different species of Strychnos,especially in the Nux vomica. It is less powerful than strychnine.Called also brucia and brucina.
brakeman: A man in charge of a brake or brakes.
britisher: An Englishman; a subject or inhabitant of Great Britain, esp.one in the British military or naval service. [Now used jocosely]
blanch holding: A mode of tenure by the payment of a small duty in white rent(silver) or otherwise.
backlog: A large stick of wood, forming the of a fire on the hearth.[U.S.]There was first a backlog, from fifteen to four and twenty inches indiameter and five feet long, imbedded in the ashes. S. G. Goodrich.
boozy: A little intoxicated; fuddled; stupid with liquor; bousy.[Colloq.] C. Kingsley.
barcon: A vessel for freight; -- used in Mediterranean.
bare: That part of a roofing slate, shingle, tile, or metal plate,which is exposed to the weather.
barranca: A ravine caused by heavy rains or a watercourse. [Texas & N.Mex.]
bode: To indicate by signs, as future events; to be the omen of; toportend to presage; to foreshow.A raven that bodes nothing but mischief. Goldsmith.Good onset bodes good end. Spenser.
bimana: Animals having two hands; -- a term applied by Cuvier to man asa special order of Mammalia.
bacciform: Having the form of a berry.
bartlett: A Bartlett pear, a favorite kind of pear, which originated inEngland about 1770, and was called Williams' Bonchrétien. It wasbrought to America, and distributed by Mr. Enoch Bartlett, ofDorchester, Massachusetts.
borborygm: A rumbling or gurgling noise produced by wind in the bowels.Dunglison.
bulldog: A variety of dog, of remarkable ferocity, courage, and tenacityof grip; -- so named, probably, from being formerly employed inbaiting bulls.
becker: A European fish (Pagellus centrodontus); the sea bream orbraise.
bonapartism: The policy of Bonaparte or of the Bonapartes.
buoyage: Buoys, taken collectively; a series of buoys, as for theguidance of vessels into or out of port; the providing of buoys.
beccafico: A small bird. (Silvia hortensis), which is highly prized by theItalians for the delicacy of its flesh in the autumn, when it has fedon figs, grapes, etc.
bloodletting: The act or process of letting blood or bleeding, as by openinga vein or artery, or by cupping or leeches; -- esp. applied tovenesection.
bonce: A boy's game played with large marbles.
bell-faced: Having the striking surface convex; -- said of hammers.
beslime: To daub with slime; to soil. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
basic process: A Bessemer or open-hearth steel-making process in which alining that is basic, or not siliceous, is used, and additions ofbasic material are made to the molten charge during treatment.Opposed to acid process, above. Called also Thomas process.
blue-john: A name given to fluor spar in Derbyshire, where it is used forornamental purposes.
blancard: A kind of linen cloth made in Normandy, the thread of which ispartly blanches before it is woven.
blet: A form of decay in fruit which is overripe.
bikh: The East Indian name of a virulent poison extracted fromAconitum ferox or other species of aconite: also, the plant itself.
badger-legged: Having legs of unequal length, as the badger was thought tohave. Shak.
bacterium: A microscopic vegetable organism, belonging to the class Algæ,usually in the form of a jointed rodlike filament, and found inputrefying organic infusions. Bacteria are destitute of chlorophyll,and are the smallest of microscopic organisms. They are very widelydiffused in nature, and multiply with marvelous rapidity, both byfission and by spores. Certain species are active agents infermentation, while others appear to be the cause of certaininfectious diseases. See Bacillus.
baryto-calcite: A mineral of a white or gray color, occurring massive orcrystallized. It is a compound of the carbonates of barium andcalcium.
blastide: A small, clear space in the segments of the ovum, the precursorof the nucleus.
bismuthyl: Hydrous carbonate of bismuth, an earthy mineral of a dull whiteor yellowish color. [Written also bismuthite.]
basidiospore: A spore borne by a basidium.-- Ba*sid`i*o*spor"ous (, a.
biannual: Occurring twice a year; half-yearly; semiannual.
blonde: A kind of silk lace originally of the color of raw silk, nowsometimes dyed; -- called also blond lace.
bask: To lie in warmth; to be exposed to genial heat.Basks in the glare, and stems the tepid wave. Goldsmith.
blindfold: To cover the eyes of, as with a bandage; to hinder from seeing.And when they had blindfolded him, they struck him on the face. Lukexxii. 64.
blackguardism: The conduct or language of a blackguard; rufflanism.
barm: Foam rising upon beer, or other malt liquors, when fermenting,and used as leaven in making bread and in brewing; yeast. Shak.
bedewer: One who, or that which, bedews.
brevier: A size of type between bourgeous and minion.
bushranger: One who roams, or hides, among the bushes; especially, inAustralia, an escaped criminal living in the bush.
bowie knife: A knife with a strong blade from ten to fifteen inches long,and double-edged near the point; -- used as a hunting knife, andformerly as a weapon in the southwestern part of the United States.It was named from its inventor, Colonel James Bowie. Also, byextension, any large sheath knife.
bedraggle: To draggle; to soil, as garments which, in walking, aresuffered to drag in dust, mud, etc. Swift.
bowdlerize: To expurgate, as a book, by omitting or modifying the partsconsidered offensive.
bitheism: Belief in the existence of two gods; dualism.
bon silene: A very fragrant tea rose with petals of various shades of pink.
balky: Apt to balk; as, a balky horse.
bilingualism: Quality of being bilingual.The bilingualism of King's English. Earle.
bowgrace: A frame or fender of rope or junk, laid out at the sides orbows of a vessel to secure it from injury by floating ice.
blain: A bladder growing on the root of the tongue of a horse, againstthe windpipe, and stopping the breath.
bowel: Hence, figuratively: The interior part of anything; as, thebowels of the earth.His soldiers . . . cried out amain, And rushed into the bowels of thebattle. Shak.
bearded: Having a beard. "Bearded fellow." Shak. "Bearded grain."Dryden. Bearded vulture, Bearded eagle. (Zoöl.) See Lammergeir.-- Bearded tortoise. (Zoöl.) See Matamata.
bib: An arctic fish (Gadus luscus), allied to the cod; -- calledalso pout and whiting pout.
backgammon: A game of chance and skill, played by two persons on a "board"marked off into twenty-four spaces called "points". Each player hasfifteen pieces, or "men", the movements of which from point to pointare determined by throwing dice. Formerly called tables. Backgammonboard , a board for playing backgammon, often made in the form of tworectangular trays hinged together, each tray containing two "tables".
bream: A European fresh-water cyprinoid fish of the genus Abramis,little valued as food. Several species are known.
belligerent: A nation or state recognized as carrying on war; a personengaged in warfare.
biquadrate: The fourth power, or the square of the square. Thus 4x4=16, thesquare of 4, and 16x16=256, the biquadrate of 4.
bay salt: Salt which has been obtained from sea water, by evaporation inshallow pits or basins, by the heat of the sun; the large crystallinesalt of commerce. Bacon. Ure.
bittersweet: Sweet and then bitter or bitter and then sweet; esp. sweet witha bitter after taste; hence (Fig.), pleasant but painful.
bouts-rimes: Words that rhyme, proposed as the ends of verses, to be filledout by the ingenuity of the person to whom they are offered.
ben: Within; in; in or into the interior; toward the innerapartment. [Scot.]
botanize: To seek after plants for botanical investigation; to studyplants.
breathful: Full of breath; full of odor; fragrant. [Obs.]
blackmailer: One who extorts, or endeavors to extort, money, by blackmailing.
believable: Capable of being believed; credible.-- Be*liev"a*ble*ness, n.-- Be*liev`a*bil"i*ty (, n.
boyishness: The manners or behavior of a boy.
blather: To talk foolishly, or nonsensically.  G. Eliot.
buttons: A boy servant, or page, -- in allusion to the buttons on hislivry. [Colloq.] Dickens.
bipennis: An ax with an edge or blade on each side of the handle.
bemuffle: To cover as with a muffler; to wrap up.Bemuffled with the externals of religion. Sterne.
bolo: A kind of large knife resembling a machete. [Phil. Islands]
biglandular: Having two glands, as a plant.
bayou: An inlet from the Gulf of Mexico, from a lake, or from a largeriver, sometimes sluggish, sometimes without perceptible movementexcept from tide and wind. [Southern U. S.]A dark slender thread of a bayou moves loiteringly northeastward intoa swamp of huge cypresses. G. W. Cable.
brachium: The upper arm; the segment of the fore limb between theshoulder and the elbow.
blubbered: Swollen; turgid; as, a blubbered lip. Spenser.
byssus: A tuft of long, tough filaments which are formed in a groove ofthe foot, and issue from between the valves of certain bivalvemollusks, as the Pinna and Mytilus, by which they attach themselvesto rocks, etc.
bibasic: Having to hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by positive orbasic atoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of acids. See Dibasic.
banjorine: A kind of banjo, with a short neck, tuned a fourth higher thanthe common banjo; -- popularly so called.
blot: To take a blot; as, this paper blots easily.
bowne: To make ready; to prepare; to dress. [Obs.]We will all bowne ourselves for the banquet. Sir W. Scott.
bureaucrat: An official of a bureau; esp. an official confirmed in a narrowand arbitrary routine. C. Kingsley.
berate: To rate or chide vehemently; to scold. Holland. Motley.
breakneck: Producing danger of a broken neck; as, breakneck speed.
barnburner: A member of the radical section of the Democratic party in NewYork, about the middle of the 19th century, which was hostile toextension of slavery, public debts, corporate privileges, etc., andsupported Van Buren against Cass for president in 1848; --opposed toHunker. [Political Cant, U. S.]
bulker: A person employed to ascertain the bulk or size of goods, inorder to fix the amount of freight or dues payable on them.
breadstuff: Grain, flour, or meal of which bread is made.
beasthood: State or nature of a beast.
bullheaded: Having a head like that of a bull. Fig.: Headstrong; obstinate;dogged.
bord service: Service due from a bordar; bordage.
boot: The metal casing and flange fitted about a pipe where it passesthrough a roof. Boot catcher, the person at an inn whose business itwas to pull off boots and clean them. [Obs.] Swift.-- Boot closer, one who, or that which, sews the uppers of boots.-- Boot crimp, a frame or device used by bootmakers for drawing andshaping the body of a boot.-- Boot hook, a hook with a handle, used for pulling on boots.-- Boots and saddles (Cavalry Tactics), the trumpet call which isthe first signal for mounted drill.-- Sly boots. See Slyboots, in the Vocabulary.
baccalaureate: Pertaining to a bachelor of arts. Baccalaureate sermon, in someAmerican colleges, a sermon delivered as a farewell discourse to agraduating class.
bedizen: To dress or adorn tawdrily or with false taste.Remnants of tapestried hangings, . . . and shreds of pictures withwhich he had bedizened his tatters. Sir W. Scott.
brachyura: A group of decapod Crustacea, including the common crabs,characterized by a small and short abdomen, which is bent up beneaththe large cephalo-thorax. [Also spelt Brachyoura.] See Crab, andIllustration in Appendix.
backsaw: A saw (as a tenon saw) whose blade is stiffened by an addedmetallic back.
blenk: To blink; to shine; to look. [Obs.]
bourbonist: One who adheres to the house of Bourbon; a legitimist.
backward: The state behind or past. [Obs.]In the dark backward and abysm of time. Shak.
blushing: Showing blushes; rosy red; having a warm and delicate colorlike some roses and other flowers; blooming; ruddy; roseate.The dappled pink and blushing rose. Prior.
blastophore: That portion of the spermatospore which is not converted intospermatoblasts, but carries them.
by-speech: An incidental or casual speech, not directly relating to thepoint. "To quote by-speeches." Hooker.
blackband: An earthy carbonate of iron containing considerablecarbonaceous matter; -- valuable as an iron ore.
bowl: An ancient game, popular in Great Britain, played with biasedballs on a level plat of greensward.Like an uninstructed bowler, . . . who thinks to attain the jack bydelivering his bowl straightforward upon it. Sir W. Scott.
bagpipe: A musical wind instrument, now used chiefly in the Highlands ofScotland.
bullfinch: A bird of the genus Pyrrhula and other related genera,especially the P. vulgaris or rubicilla, a bird of Europe allied tothe grosbeak, having the breast, cheeks, and neck, red.
blastematic: Connected with, or proceeding from, the blastema; blastemal.
battalion: A regiment, or two or more companies of a regiment, esp. whenassembled for drill or battle.
baseless: Without a base; having no foundation or support. "The baselessfabric of this vision." Shak.
bumblebee: A large bee of the genus Bombus, sometimes called humblebee; --so named from its sound.
boisterousness: The state or quality of being boisterous; turbulence; disorder;tumultuousness.
barbated: Having barbed points.A dart uncommonly barbated. T. Warton.
bluenose: A nickname for a Nova Scotian.
balayeuse: A protecting ruffle or frill, as of silk or lace, sewed closeto the lower edge of a skirt on the inside.
billet-doux: A love letter or note.A lover chanting out a billet-doux. Spectator.
bepurple: To tinge or dye with a purple color.
blithe: Gay; merry; sprightly; joyous; glad; cheerful; as, a blithespirit.The blithe sounds of festal music. Prescott.A daughter fair, So buxom, blithe, and debonair. Milton.
bluefin: A species of whitefish (Coregonus nigripinnis) found in LakeMichigan.
bordeaux: Pertaining to Bordeaux in the south of France.-- n.
bakingly: In a hot or baking manner.
bletting: A form of decay seen in fleshy, overripe fruit. Lindley.
brutalization: The act or process of making brutal; state of being brutalized.
bucket: One of the receptacles on the rim of a water wheel into whichthe water rushes, causing the wheel to revolve; also, a float of apaddle wheel.
bifurcation: A forking, or division into two branches.
boation: A crying out; a roaring; a bellowing; reverberation. [Obs.]The guns were heard . . . about a hundred Italian miles, in longboations. Derham.
balata: A West Indian sapotaceous tree (Bumelia retusa).
body: The shank of a type, or the depth of the shank (by which thesize is indicated); as, a nonpareil face on an agate body.
barium: One of the elements, belonging to the alkaline earth group; ametal having a silver-white color, and melting at a very hightemperature. It is difficult to obtain the pure metal, from thefacility with which it becomes oxidized in the air. Atomic weight,137. Symbol, Ba. Its oxide called baryta. [Rarely written barytum.]
brazil nut: An oily, three-sided nut, the seed of the Bertholletia excelsa;the cream nut.
bell process: The process of washing molten pig iron by adding iron oxide,proposed by I. Lowthian Bell of England about 1875.
besotted: Made sottish, senseless, or infatuated; characterized bydrunken stupidity, or by infatuation; stupefied. "Besotted devotion."Sir W. Scott.-- Be*sot"ted*ly, adv.-- Be*sot"ted*ness, n. Milton.
barracan: A thick, strong stuff, somewhat like camlet; -- still used forouter garments in the Levant.
bepinch: To pinch, or mark with pinches. Chapman.
blindstory: The triforium as opposed to the clearstory.
bell crank: A lever whose two arms form a right angle, or nearly a rightangle, having its fulcrum at the apex of the angle. It is used inbell pulls and in changing the direction of bell wires at angles ofrooms, etc., and also in machinery.
blowhole: An air hole in a casting.
bergstock: A long pole with a spike at the end, used in climbingmountains; an alpenstock.
barratry: The practice of exciting and encouraging lawsuits and quarrels.[Also spelt barretry.] Coke. Blackstone.
benzoic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, benzoin. Benzoic acid, orflowers of benzoin, a peculiar vegetable acid, C6H5.CO2H, obtainedfrom benzoin, and some other balsams, by sublimation or decoction. Itis also found in the urine of infants and herbivorous animals. Itcrystallizes in the form of white, satiny flakes; its odor isaromatic; its taste is pungent, and somewhat acidulous.-- Benzoic aldehyde, oil of bitter almonds; the aldehyde, C6H5.CHO,intermediate in composition between benzoic or benzyl alcohol, andbenzoic acid. It is a thin colorless liquid.
base-court: An inferior court of law, not of record.
bustling: Agitated; noisy; tumultuous; characterized by confusedactivity; as, a bustling crowd. "A bustling wharf." Hawthorne.
bemangle: To mangle; to tear asunder. [R.] Beaumont.
balefulness: The quality or state of being baleful.
battel: A single combat; as, trial by battel. See Wager of battel,under Wager.
bluebeard: The hero of a mediæval French nursery legend, who, leavinghome, enjoined his young wife not to open a certain room in hiscastle. She entered it, and found the murdered bodies of his formerwives.-- Also used adjectively of a subject which it is forbidden toinvestigate.The Bluebeard chamber of his mind, into which no eye but his own mustlook. Carlyle.
bowery: Shading, like a bower; full of bowers.A bowery maze that shades the purple streams. Trumbull.
buy: To negotiate or treat about a purchase.I will buy with you, sell with you. Shak.
backband: The band which passes over the back of a horse and holds up theshafts of a carriage.
bleached: Whitened; make white.Let their bleached bones, and blood's unbleaching stain, Long markthe battlefield with hideous awe. Byron.
bellarmine: A stoneware jug of a pattern originated in the neighborhood ofCologne, Germany, in the 16th century. It has a bearded face or masksupposed to represent Cardinal Bellarmine, a leader in the RomanCatholic Counter Reformation, following the Reformation; -- calledalso graybeard, longbeard.
belleek ware: A porcelainlike kind of decorative pottery with a high gloss,which is sometimes iridescent. A very fine kind is made at Belleek inIreland.
blare: To sound loudly and somewhat harshly. "The trumpet blared."Tennyson.
batture: An elevated river bed or sea bed.
badderlocks: A large black seaweed (Alaria esculenta) sometimes eaten inEurope; -- also called murlins, honeyware, and henware.
by-walk: secluded or private walk.He moves afterward in by-walks. Dryden.
blink beer: Beer kept unbroached until it is sharp. Crabb.
betoss: To put in violent motion; to agitate; to disturb; to toss. "Mybetossed soul." Shak.
bailment: The action of bailing a person accused.Bailment . . . is the saving or delivery of a man out of prisonbefore he hath satisfied the law. Dalton.
bordure: A border one fifth the width of the shield, surrounding thefield. It is usually plain, but may be charged.
bustard: A bird of the genus Otis.
betitle: To furnish with a title or titles; to entitle. [Obs.] Carlyle.
blowth: A blossoming; a bloom. [Obs. or Archaic] "In the blowth andbud." Sir W. Raleigh.
boskiness: Boscage; also, the state or quality of being bosky.
bastard: Abbreviated, as the half title in a page preceding the fulltitle page of a book. Bastard ashlar (Arch.), stones for ashlar work,roughly squared at the quarry.-- Bastard file, a file intermediate between the coarsest and thesecond cut.-- Bastard type (Print.), type having the face of a larger or asmaller size than the body; e.g., a nonpareil face on a brevier body.-- Bastard wing (Zoöl.), three to five quill feathers on a smalljoint corresponding to the thumb in some mam malia; the alula.
boasting: The act of glorying or vaunting; vainglorious speaking;ostentatious display.When boasting ends, then dignity begins. Young.
butting: An abuttal; a boundary.Without buttings or boundings on any side. Bp. Beveridge.
baldwin: A kind of reddish, moderately acid, winter apple. [U.S.]
by-view: A private or selfish view; self-interested aim or purpose.No by-views of his own shall mislead him. Atterbury.
behoof: Advantage; profit; benefit; interest; use.No mean recompense it brings To your behoof. Milton.
brush turkey: A large, edible, gregarious bird of Australia (TalegallaLathami) of the family Megapodidæ. Also applied to several alliedspecies of New Guinea.
ballet: A light part song, or madrigal, with a fa la burden or chorus,-- most common with the Elizabethan madrigal composers.
bogwood: The wood of trees, esp. of oaks, dug up from peat bogs. It isof a shining black or ebony color, and is largely used for makingornaments.
brachycatalectic: A verse wanting two syllables at its termination.
burion: The red-breasted house sparrow of California (Carpodacusfrontalis); -- called also crimson-fronted bullfinch. [Written alsoburrion.]
bias: In a slanting manner; crosswise; obliquely; diagonally; as, tocut cloth bias.
beeswax: The wax secreted by bees, and of which their cells areconstructed.
bellycheer: Good cheer; viands. [Obs.] "Bellycheer and banquets." Rowlands."Loaves and bellycheer." Milton.
biplane: An aëroplane with two main supporting surfaces one above theother.
ballade: A form of French versification, sometimes imitated in English,in which three or four rhymes recur through three stanzas of eight orten lines each, the stanzas concluding with a refrain, and the wholepoem with an envoy.
bitterwood: A West Indian tree (Picræna excelsa) from the wood of which thebitter drug Jamaica quassia is obtained.
berdash: ,n.A kind of neckcloth. [Obs.]A treatise against the cravat and berdash. Steele.
begnaw: To gnaw; to eat away; to corrode.The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul. Shak.
ballarag: To bully; to threaten. [Low] T. Warton.
befortune: To befall. [Poetic]I wish all good befortune you. Shak.
breasting: The curved channel in which a breast wheel turns. It is closelyadapted to the curve of the wheel through about a quarter of itscircumference, and prevents the escape of the water until it hasspent its force upon the wheel. See Breast wheel.
breastknot: A pin worn of the breast for a fastening, or for ornament; abrooch.
braiser: A kettle or pan for braising.
booting: Advantage; gain; gain by plunder; booty. [Obs.] Sir. J.Harrington.
buttonmold: A disk of bone, wood, or other material, which is made into abutton by covering it with cloth. [Written also buttonmould.] Fossilbuttonmolds, joints of encrinites. See Encrinite.
bairam: The name of two Mohammedan festivals, of which one is held atthe close of the fast called Ramadan, and the other seventy daysafter the fast.
beshow: A large food fish (Anoplopoma fimbria) of the north Pacificcoast; -- called also candlefish.
bignoniaceous: Of pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of whichthe trumpet flower is an example.
beginner: One who begins or originates anything. Specifically: A young orinexperienced practitioner or student; a tyro.A sermon of a new beginner. Swift.
bunchy: Yielding irregularly; sometimes rich, sometimes poor; as, abunchy mine. Page.
bacon: The back and sides of a pig salted and smoked; formerly, theflesh of a pig salted or fresh. Bacon beetle (Zoöl.), a beetle(Dermestes lardarius) which, especially in the larval state, feedsupon bacon, woolens, furs, etc. See Dermestes.-- To save one's bacon, to save one's self or property from harm orless. [Colloq.]
bipyramidal: Consisting of two pyramids placed base to base; having apyramid at each of the extremities of a prism, as in quartz crystals.
brumal: Of or pertaining to winter. "The brumal solstice." Sir T.Browne.
burkism: The practice of killing persons for the purpose of sellingtheir bodies for dissection.
butyraceous: Having the qualities of butter; resembling butter.
brutalize: To make brutal; beasty; unfeeling; or inhuman.
boa: A genus of large American serpents, including the boaconstrictor, the emperor boa of Mexico (B. imperator), and thechevalier boa of Peru (B. eques).
browbeating: The act of bearing down, abashing, or disconcerting, with sternlooks, suspercilious manners, or confident assertions.The imperious browbeating and scorn of great men. L'Estrange.
bargemastter: The proprietor or manager of a barge, or one of the crew of abarge.
brimless: Having no brim; as, brimless caps.
babbler: A name given to any one of family (Timalinæ) of thrushlikebirds, having a chattering note.
bugloss: A plant of the genus Anchusa, and especially the A.officinalis, sometimes called alkanet; oxtongue. Small wild bugloss,the Asperugo procumbens and the Lycopsis arvensis.-- Viper's bugloss, a species of Echium.
brigue: A cabal, intrigue, faction, contention, strife, or quarrel.[Obs.] Chesterfield.
benedicite: A canticle (the Latin version of which begins with this word)which may be used in the order for morning prayer in the Church ofEngland. It is taken from an apocryphal addition to the third chapterof Daniel.
babish: Like a babe; a childish; babyish. [R.] "Babish imbecility."Drayton.-- Bab"ish*ly, adv.-- Bab"ish*ness, n. [R.]
bellicose: Inclined to war or contention; warlike; pugnacious.Arnold was, in fact, in a bellicose vein. W. Irving.
bullhead: A small black water insect. E. Phillips. Bullhead whiting(Zoöl.), the kingfish of Florida (Menticirrus alburnus).
bivalent: Equivalent in combining or displacing power to two atoms ofhydrogen; dyad.
bo: An exclamation used to startle or frighten. [Spelt also boh andboo.]
butternut: An American tree (Juglans cinerea) of the Walnut family, andits edible fruit; -- so called from the oil contained in the latter.Sometimes called oil nut and white walnut.
belime: To besmear or insnare with birdlime.
blissful: Full of, characterized by, or causing, joy and felicity; happyin the highest degree. "Blissful solitude." Milton.-- Bliss"ful*ly, adv.-- Bliss"ful*ness, n.
bancal: An ornamental covering, as of carpet or leather, for a bench orform.
balbuties: The defect of stammering; also, a kind of incompletepronunciation.
bogie engine: A switching engine the running gear and driving gear of whichare on a bogie, or truck.
brink: The edge, margin, or border of a steep place, as of aprecipice; a bank or edge, as of a river or pit; a verge; a border;as, the brink of a chasm. Also Fig. "The brink of vice." Bp. Porteus."The brink of ruin." Burke.The plashy brink of weedy lake. Bryant.
bejuco: Any climbing woody vine of the tropics with the habit of aliane; in the Philippines, esp. any of various species of Calamus,the cane or rattan palm.
bullfrog: A very large species of frog (Rana Catesbiana), found in NorthAmerica; -- so named from its loud bellowing in spring.
bandala: A fabric made in Manilla from the older leaf sheaths of theabaca (Musa textilis).
belsire: A grandfather, or ancestor. "His great belsire Brute." [Obs.]Drayton.
botchy: Marked with botches; full of botches; poorly done. "This botchybusiness." Bp. Watson.
blasphemer: One who blasphemes.And each blasphemer quite escape the rod, Because the insult's not onman, but God Pope.
battuta: The measuring of time by beating.
baggager: One who takes care of baggage; a camp follower. [Obs.] Sir W.Raleigh.
blaspheme: To utter blasphemy.He that shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost hath neverforgiveness. Mark iii. 29.
billowy: Of or pertaining to billows; swelling or swollen into largewaves; full of billows or surges; resembling billows.And whitening down the many-tinctured stream, Descends the billowyfoam. Thomson.
bottlehead: A cetacean allied to the grampus; -- called also bottle-nosedwhale.
boutonniere: A bouquet worn in a buttonhole.
barebacked: Having the back uncovered; as, a barebacked horse.
binding post: A metallic post attached to electrical apparatus forconvenience in making connections.
baignoire: A box of the lowest tier in a theater.  Du Maurier.
bartizan: A small, overhanging structure for lookout or defense, usuallyprojecting at an angle of a building or near an entrance gateway.
bitter: AA turn of the cable which is round the bitts. Bitter end, thatpart of a cable which is abaft the bitts, and so within board, whenthe ship rides at anchor.
beleaguer: To surround with an army so as to preclude escape; to besiege;to blockade.The wail of famine in beleaguered towns. Longfellow.
bloodshot: Red and inflamed; suffused with blood, or having the vesselsturgid with blood, as when the conjunctiva is inflamed or irritated.His eyes were bloodshot, . . . and his hair disheveled. Dickens.
bagpiper: One who plays on a bagpipe; a piper. Shak.
biggen: To make or become big; to enlarge. [Obs. or Dial.] Steele.
bristletail: An insect of the genera Lepisma, Campodea, etc., belonging tothe Thysanura.
bugleweed: A plant of the Mint family and genus Lycopus; esp. L.Virginicus, which has mild narcotic and astringent properties, and issometimes used as a remedy for hemorrhage.
booking clerk: A clerk who registers passengers, baggage, etc., forconveyance, as by railway or steamship, or who sells passage ticketsat a booking office.
boraginaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants(Boraginaceæ) which includes the borage, heliotrope, beggar's lice,and many pestiferous plants.
bulbil: A small or secondary bulb; hence, now almost exclusively: Anaërial bulb or deciduous bud, produced in the leaf axils, as in thetiger lily, or relpacing the flowers, as in some onions, and capable,when separated, of propagating the plant; -- called also bulblet andbrood bud.
bookmark: Something placed in a book to guide in finding a particularpage or passage; also, a label in a book to designate the owner; abookplate.
bewildered: Greatly perplexed; as, a bewildered mind.
blase: Having the sensibilities deadened by excess or frequency ofenjoyment; sated or surfeited with pleasure; used up.
boniness: The condition or quality of being bony.
barraclade: A home-made woolen blanket without nap. [Local, New York]Bartlett.
branchiate: Furnished with branchiæ; as, branchiate segments.
benedictionary: A collected series of benedictions.The benedictionary of Bishop Athelwold. G. Gurton's Needle.
bechuanas: A division of the Bantus, dwelling between the Orange andZambezi rivers, supposed to be the most ancient Bantu population ofSouth Africa. They are divided into totemic clans; they areintelligent and progressive.
beryllium: A metallic element found in the beryl. See Glucinum.
bakehouse: A house for baking; a bakery.
breastheight: The interior slope of a fortification, against which thegarnison lean in firing.
biliprasin: A dark green pigment found in small quantity in humangallstones.
breech action: The breech mechanism in breech-loading small arms and certainspecial guns, as automatic and machine guns; --used frequently inreferring to the method by which the movable barrels of breech-loading shotguns are locked, unlocked, or rotated to loadingposition.
balneotherapy: The treatment of disease by baths.
bumkin: A projecting beam or boom; as: (a) One projecting from each bowof a vessel, to haul the fore tack to, called a tack bumpkin. (b) Onrfrom each quarter, for the main-brace blocks, and called bracebumpkin. (c) A small outrigger over the stern of a boat, to extendthe mizzen. [Written also boomkin.]
bragly: In a manner to be bragged of; finely; proudly. [Obs.] Spenser.
bold eagle: an Australian eagle (Aquila audax), which destroys lambs andeven the kangaroo.-- To make bold, to take liberties or the liberty; to venture.
bromyrite: Silver bromide, a rare mineral; -- called also bromargyrite.
bertha: A kind of collar or cape worn by ladies.
bosomed: Having, or resembling, bosom; kept in the bosom; hidden.
backset: To plow again, in the fall; -- said of prairie land broken upin the spring. [Western U.S.]
bowssen: To drench; to soak; especially, to immerse (in water believedto have curative properties). [Obs.]There were many bowssening places, for curing of mad men. . . . Ifthere appeared small amendment he was bowssened again and again.Carew.
byzantine: Of or pertaining to Byzantium.-- n.
bespurt: To spurt on or over; to asperse. [Obs.] Milton.
beauship: The state of being a beau; the personality of a beau. [Jocular]Dryden.
burler: One who burls or dresses cloth.
blackwood: A name given to several dark-colored timbers. The East Indianblack wood is from the tree Dalbergia latifolia. Balfour.
brothelry: Lewdness; obscenity; a brothel. B. Jonson.
banian: The Indian fig. See Banyan. Banian days (Naut.), days in whichthe sailors have no flesh meat served out to them. This use seems tobe borrowed from the Banians or Banya race, who eat no flesh.
box: A tree or shrub, flourishing in different parts of the world.The common box (Buxus sempervirens) has two varieties, one of which,the dwaft box (B.suffruticosa), is much used for borders in gardens.The wood of the tree varieties, being very hard and smooth, isextensively used in the arts, as by turners, engravers, mathematicalinstrument makers, etc. Box elder, the ash-leaved maple (Negundoaceroides), of North America.-- Box holly, the butcher's broom (Russus aculeatus).-- Box thorn, a shrub (Lycium barbarum).-- Box tree, the tree variety of the common box.
by-product: A secondary or additional product; something produced, as inthe course of a manufacture, in addition to the principal product.
